DOC.HEAD: U.S. Attorney: Earth First! Permit Legal, in the Public Interest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with hearing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A legal foundation asked a federal judge Tuesday to forbid Earth First! from holding its annual gathering in a Montana forest, saying the U.S. Forest Service illegally issued the environmental group a permit. The Denver-based Mountain States Legal Foundation is seeking a permanent injunction barring the July 7-15 gathering in Beaverhead National Forest in southwestern Montana. U.S. District Judge Charles Lovell took the foundation's request under advisement, and indicated he would decide later this week whether the permit was legal. The foundation and 77 other groups representing ranchers, loggers, miners and off-road vehicle users say the service should not allow Earth First! in the forest, saying the group advocates illegal sabotage against developers of wildlands. ``We know who these people are; we know what they want to do,'' William Pendley, an attorney for foundation, told Lovell. Pendley argued that Earth First! encourages tree-spiking, the spiking of motorcycle trails, harassment of survey crews, destruction of logging equipment and other sabotage. He presented copies of pages from an Earth First! publication that contained detailed instructions on these acts. Lovell agreed that tree-spiking and other acts of sabotage were serious crimes, but asked Pendley for evidence that those attending the gathering planned to commit such acts. Pendley said he had no evidence that illegal activities would occur at the gathering, but said ``what we have is evidence of what they have done in the past.'' In a complaint filed Monday, the foundation said the Forest Service should prepare an environmental impact statement on the Earth First! request. However Assistant U.S. Attorney Bernie Hubley argued Tuesday the group would be easier to control under the permit. ``Without a permit, the Forest Service says the impact on the environment would be even more unpredictable,'' Hubley told Lovell. Hubley said the Forest Service not only followed the law in issuing the permit, but also decided it would be in the public's best interest to have Earth First! members meeting at one controlled site. Organizers of next week's Round River Rendezvous in the Beaverhead Forest say they're expecting hundreds of Earth First! members from across the country. Pendley said his clients were worried about possible harm to timber, cattle, and other resources. Hubley said those fears are unfounded, and that the foundation and fellow plaintiffs therefore had no standing to ask for an injunction. Philip Knight, an Earth First! member in Bozeman who helped organize the gathering, said it would go forward regardless of the court case. ``I don't see any way they can stop it,'' he said Monday. ``Word has gone out all over the country, and there are people from all over the country coming to it. ... We'll meet without the permit if we have to.'' Knight said Earth First! cannot control actions by all of its members, and said the group as a whole shouldn't be penalized for the actions of a few. ``At past rendezvouses, there have been no such incidents involved,'' he said. ``Anyone engaging in it, I condemn them right now.'' Beaverhead National Forest officials approved a permit in April for Earth First! to gather on a 30-acre site, and required the group to post a $1,000 bond and prepare an emergency medical plan for those attending. Knight said Earth First! has complied with the requirements.

DOC.HEAD: Even Hawkish Thatcher Set To Cash In On Peace Dividend
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Clad in helmet and flying suit, Defense Secretary Tom King gave a thumbs-up sign from the cockpit of a Tornado warplane ready for takeoff. He was the very picture of gritty determination. He needed to be. These are gloomy days for the Tornado, pride of the Royal Air Force. The fighter plane _ produced jointly by Britain, Italy and West Germany _ is now itself a target of weapons-cutting proposals. In a new global climate, even Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, traditionally the most hawkish leader in the 16-nation Western NATO alliance, is preparing to cash in on the so-called ``peace dividend'' by slicing defense spending in the face of a collapsing Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. King's morale-boosting visit to the sprawling Cottesmore airbase in central England, NATO's main Tornado training base, followed the announcement last month that Britain has canceled an order for 33 Tornado aircraft. The move was part of a $1 billion cut in this year's $37 billion defense budget. Mrs. Thatcher, who plays host to a NATO summit meeting Thursday and Friday in London, is adamant that the Western alliance's new role should include most of the old. She says it should remain a defense alliance with nuclear weapons and U.S. troops deployed in Europe. President Bush has also proposed cuts of $3 billion, taking inflation into account, for a $303 billion U.S. defense budget. But some congressmen want much larger reductions. The official reason given for canceling the Tornado order was the high cost, which rose as Britain's annual inflation rate soared unexpectedly to nearly 10 percent. But the post-Cold War climate made the decision easier for the government, and officials acknowledge privately that it is just the beginning of more sweeping cuts. The Conservative government is engaged in a major review of defense spending. It is widely expected to herald big cutbacks by Britain, long among the highest defense spenders in NATO. Armed Forces Minister Archie Hamilton sent shudders through the military hierachy last month by telling Parliament that some of the army's 75 regiments will probably have to be abolished or merged into others. The spending review is being carried out in secret. But according to widely reported leaks, Defense Procurement Minister Alan Clark has proposed a radical program, including eventually cutting the Royal Navy's surface fleet from 50 to 32 frigates and the 150,000-member army by about a third. The cuts reportedly would include phased withdrawals of many of the 66,700 British army and air force personnel based in West Germany. Britain's 1991-92 defense budget, planned before the dramatic political changes in Eastern Europe, was $39 billion. Now there is speculation it will be frozen at $37 billion. The British cut in spending for the Tornado followed reports of successive cancellations of orders by Jordan, Oman, Malaysia and Saudi Arabia. That country reportedly wants cheaper British-made Hawk aircraft and helicopters instead. British officials refused to confirm or deny the Saudi move. But British newspaper reports said it could mean Tornado production, which began in 1980, may end in early 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Blames Pilot; Union to Appeal
DOC.TEXT: The Air Line Pilots Association says it will ask federal investigators to reconsider their conclusion that the pilot of USAir Flight 5050 caused the plane to skid into New York's East River. The National Transportation Safety Board determined Tuesday that the Sept. 20, 1989, crash that killed two passengers probably was caused by the pilot's failure to detect a rudder control problem as well as pilot errors in aborting the takeoff. The board said that despite the problem with the rudder setting, simulator tests showed the new Boeing 737-400 could either have taken off safely or aborted its landing without going into the river. Fifty-five passengers and six crew members were rescued from the river after the plane slid and split apart off the end of the LaGuardia Airport runway. The pilots' union protested the board's decision, calling it ``a total travesty,'' and said it would appeal to the board for reconsideration. Board conclusions and recommendations carry no force of law but serve only to advise other agencies on steps to take for ensuring safety. Tom Kreamer, a USAir pilot who spoke for the union, said the board should have blamed the crash on a design error in the plane's control panel that allowed a rudder trim control to be improperly set. ``Boeing played an integral part in this accident,'' said Kreamer. The trim control determines the neutral setting for the rudder. After the crash, Boeing and Federal Aviation Administration officials ordered changes in the controls to prevent them from accidentally being reset by visitors in the cockpit or objects laid on the console. The board said it could not determine how the rudder trim became set in the full-left position before the USAir jet taxied onto the runway. ``This lays a tremendous burden on one individual in a very complex system,'' said board member John Lauber. But Lauber, with nods of agreement from other board members, said the conclusion was justified because there were so many lapses on the part of pilot Michael Martin during the incident. Martin aborted the takeoff as the plane started to drift to the left with copilot Constantin Kleissas at the controls for the first time on a commercial 737 flight. The board cited the pilot's decision to let his inexperienced copilot control the nighttime takeoff, Martin's failure to engage an automatic braking system, miscommunication in the cockpit, improper use of nosewheel steering and the failure to have air speeds called out during takeoff. The FAA suspended Martin and Kleissas' licenses, and the agency was critical of their failure to appear for drug tests immediately after the crash. Tests two days later were negative. Both men dropped appeals of the suspension. They continue to work for USAir and will be allowed to fly again if they pass recertification tests. Board member Jim Burnett joined in the 4-0 vote but filed an additional assertion that USAir's failure to assign ``an adequately prepared and seasoned flight crew'' was a contributing factor in the crash. Burnett said the board did not cite design of the control knob as a factor because the pilot had so many chances to discover and correct it and because Boeing and the FAA already were correcting the problem.

DOC.HEAD: Roemer Stands Firm, Abortion Opponents Rally
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer says he won't let a telegram from Mother Teresa or a demonstration by 3,000 abortion foes sway him from vetoing the toughest state abortion law in the nation. The measure approved overwhelmingly by the Legislature last week allows abortion only to save the life of the mother. It would send abortionists to prison for 10 years. Roemer has said he will veto the bill because it allows no exceptions in cases of incest or rape. ``I've been basically pro-life all my elected lifetime,'' he said Tuesday. ``The issue is a bill that's fair and the rights of the unborn are important. But so are the rights of the living. I don't know why this is a concept that is foreign to some.'' Earlier Tuesday, about 3,000 abortion opponents rallied on the Capitol steps to urge an override of Roemer's veto. The crowd heard a telegram from Mother Teresa and a letter legislators said came from the vice president. ``I thank you all for your quiet heroism and along with you I look forward to the day when all children before birth will again enjoy the protection of the law,'' said the letter. The governor's press office said he would probably veto the measure on Thursday or Friday. By law, the legislative session must end by midnight Monday. Roemer predicted his veto will be sustained. An override requires a two-thirds vote of each house. No veto has been overridden this century in Louisiana. He said that not even a telegram he received from Mother Teresa would sway him. ``It was a powerful message,'' Roemer said of the telegram. It read, ``I urge your assistance in protecting all of God's children. Please know, every child is from God and if they don't want them, I will take them.'' About 50 abortion-rights activists, including Norma McCorvey, the ``Jane Roe'' of the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision recognizing the right to an abortion, held a news conference at the Capitol against the measure. ``If the governor vetoes this bill, I urge the state Legislature not to override his veto,'' said McCorvey. ``The sisterhood is strong and very committed here in Louisiana.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0402, clears heading of garble.
Neighbors Support Woman Who Killed Her Drug-Addict Son
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 residents of a town near Marseille have signed petitions demanding the release of a woman jailed for killing her son, who reportedly had forced her to finance his drug addiction. Anne-Marie Siano, 49, has been jailed since June 22, five days after she allegedly shot to death her 25-year-old son, Dominique, in the town of Allauch. Among those signing the petition in the past few days were Mayor Roland Povinelly, members of the town council, and co-workers of Mrs. Siano, who worked in the mayor's office. Neighbors said Mrs. Siano and her crippled husband had been harassed and threatened by their son, who for three years repeatedly demanded money to buy more drugs. Mrs. Siano reportedly began to suffer from depression and her weight dropped to 77 pounds. Judge Patrick Ardid, in ordering Mrs. Siano's detention, said she should remain in custody pending the completion of investigations into the circumstances of the killing. Organizers of the petition campaign said Mrs. Siano had been a loyal mother and husband, and should be released as a humanitarian gesture.

DOC.HEAD: Quantum Leap Jumps into Top 20
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Five straight nights of ``Quantum Leap'' exposed the NBC series to an estimated 60 million viewers and gave it its highest rating yet. NBC entertainment president Brandon Tartikoff had scheduled nightly reruns of the time-travel series last week in a offbeat move to give better exposure to one of his favorite shows, but one that has yet to prove its mass appeal. ``Quantum Leap'' achieved its highest marks ever with Thursday's episode, which was the No. 12 program on television, according to figures Tuesday from the A.C. Nielsen Co. The reruns were broadcast Monday through Friday. The last original episode of NBC's ``FM,'' loosely patterned on a National Public Radio station, was the No. 5 show on TV and the only non-rerun in the top 10. ``Cheers'' on NBC was No. 1. ``A Different World,'' also on NBC, was No. 2. CBS' ``Designing Women'' and ABC's ``Roseanne'' tied for third. Fox Broadcasting had a bit of a letdown with ``The Simpsons'' and ``Married ... With Children.'' After landing for two weeks in the top 10, the animated Simpsons dropped to 11th place and the boorish Bundys of ``Married ... with Children'' fell into a three-way tie for 14th. In the overall network ratings battle, NBC was No. 1 with a 10.4 average, followed by ABC with an 8.7 and CBS with an 8.6. ABC's ``World News Tonight with Peter Jennings'' was the top-rated network news program for the 25th consecutive week, with a 9.5 average. CBS and Dan Rather were a distant second with 7.9 and NBC and Tom Brokaw were third with 7.1. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. Here are the top 10 programs, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 16.8; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 13.8; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, and ``Roseanne,'' ABC, (tie) 13.7; ``FM,'' NBC, 13.5; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 13.3; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, ``60 Minutes,'' CBS (tie), 13.2; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 13.1.

DOC.HEAD: Four Die In Prison Break, About 60 Convicts At Large
DOC.TEXT: Four inmates were killed and 15 seriously injured in a riot in a state penitentiary on Tuesday, and about 60 convicts escaped in the confusion, the government news agency Notimex reported. The agency quoted Chihuahua State's interior secretary, Sergio Granados Pineda, as saying the riot began when drug traffickers tried to set free jailed confederates. It said authorities were searching for the escapees with helicopters, airplanes and automobiles and that roadblocks have been set up on major highways. The penitentiary is in the state capital of Chihuahua, 225 miles south of El Paso, Texas. The army, city, state and federal police assisted in putting down the riot, the agency qouted Granados Pineda as saying. The official said the exact number of escapees was unknown, but estimated it at 60. He said some were serving the maximum Mexican prison sentence of 40 years.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Criticism, Gorbachev Still Most Trusted Leader in Party
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is drawing unprecedented attacks from all shades of reds at a turbulent Communist Party congress, but even his critics say they will vote to keep him in the top party job. ``If we have to vote, I shall vote for Gorbachev, simply because there is no other alternative,'' said delegate Vitaly G. Karpenko, echoing a sentiment heard across the spectrum in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses. The 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party is expected to elect the party general secretary before it adjourns sometime next week, and the smart rubles are riding on Gorbachev, who first won the job five years ago. Hard-liners and radical reformers are gravitating toward Gorbachev because both sides believe only he can prevent the disintegration of the party. Some more philosophical delegates also say that despite Gorbachev's reforms, the party seems to have room at the top for just one major figure. Gorbachev's most prominent hard-line critic, Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, said in nationally televised address two weeks ago that Gorbachev should not continue to hold the government post of president and at the same time head the Communist Party. But on Tuesday, in a blistering critique of Gorbachev's reforms, Ligachev carefully avoided a personal attack on the Soviet leader and did not repeat his demand to elect someone who could devote full time to party work. KGB chairman Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, who followed Ligachev's lead in attacking the reform movement, nevertheless told reporters he would back Gorbachev for general secretary. Karpenko, a reformer, also criticized Gorbachev for ``combining the posts of president and party leader'' and said, ``Gorbachev's position is not radical enough.'' However, he added, ``It is Gorbachev who will be able to consolidate the country.'' ``I can't name any other candidate now,'' said Karpenko, a newspaper editor from Kiev. ``It is a great fault of the system that we do not have other leaders. If there is one leader, all the others have to stay in the shadows,'' he said. Valentin A. Gaivopovski, a worker from the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, also said he planned to back Gorbachev despite reservations. ``We do not have another leader of the same caliber,'' Gaivoposki said, appearing with Karpenko at a news conference Tuesday by Ukrainian delegates. ``I think we will probably re-elect Gorbachev, although I think that as a person he is probably not without his mistakes and defects,'' said Gaivopovski. He praised Gorbachev's ``political qualities'' but faulted his ``ability to see through flattery, to spot fraud and deceit ... I think that Gorbachev as a leader is very one-sided.'' On the floor of the congress, delegates relied on Gorbachev to navigate the relatively unfamiliar shoals of democracy. They chose Gorbachev by a 3,166-1,046 margin to be chairman of the party rules committee, a body that will guide the outcome of the congress. By contrast, Ligachev won a similar vote to head the agriculture committee by the slimmer margin of 2,233-1,963. Delegates also favored Gorbachev when they demanded the removal of the acting congress chairman, Byelorussian Communist Party chief Yefrem Sokolov, accusing Sokolov of ignoring their wishes. Gorbachev told agitated delegates to calm down and said there was no need for a formal vote to replace Sokolov. ``If you think we need a different person, we can replace him with a more experienced person,'' Gorbachev said. Delegates cheered. ``If you allow, perhaps I'll change places with him,'' he continued. Delegates cheered again. Gorbachev exchanged places with a shame-faced Sokolov, then began to manipulate delegates balking at his wishes on minor proposals. At first, Gorbachev scolded unruly members, but managed to change mood and nudged them along with jokes and laughter. Asked to explain Gorbachev's appeal, Alexander Frolov, first secretary of the Surovsky region near the central Russian city of Tula, said: ``We have no other leader with more potential than Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev.'' Pressed to explain the mixed attitude to Gorbachev, Frolov fell back on an old Russian proverb: ``He who works is scolded.''

DOC.HEAD: Israelis, Venezuelans Arrested in Gun-Smuggling Scheme
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs on newspaper report on gun seized in assassination; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `The guns ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two Israelis who claimed they trained Colombians to use firearms have been charged with attempting to smuggle 122 high-quality semiautomatic pistols to South America, federal agents said Tuesday. The Israelis, brothers Geri and Shlomi Ben-Tov, both of Miami, had been secretly shipping weapons overseas for some time, said Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms supervisor Ron Mitchell. Also arrested in the case were two Venezuelans, Rodrigo Fernandez and Ilio Ulivi of Caracas, who allegedly received the pistols from the Israelis on Monday. All four face charges of violating gun and export control laws. ``This was an ongoing enterprise _ this was not the first shipment,'' Mitchell said. ``From the records I observed, it was the whole gamut of rifles and handguns.'' Investigators said they were not sure how many firearms were smuggled or how long the ring had existed because many of the records are coded in computers at the Israelis' office. At one point, Mitchell said, the Israelis told undercover investigators they were training Colombians in firearms use, but the agent could not say if they had any connection to the cocaine cartels. He said they did not appear to have any connection to another Israeli, Lt. Col. Yair Klein, who fled Colombia after being videotaped training alleged Medellin cartel gunmen. Meanwhile, an assault rifle seized in the arrest last year of four suspected assassins of Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galanhas has been traced by U.S. authorities to an official Israeli arms shipment, New York Newsday reported. Although supposedly destined for the defense forces of the Caribbean island of Antigua, a cache of guns from the shipment was discovered earlier this year on a ranch owned by the late Colombian drug boss Jose Rodriguez Gacha, Newsday said today. The Israeli government has maintained that it followed its normal procedure in the $353,700 sale of 500 Galil rifles and Uzi machine pistols and 200,000 rounds of ammunition to the 90-man Antigua defense force and that it does not know how the weapons were obtained by Gacha. Antigua said it never purchased the weapons, Newsday said. Colombian officials are investigating the Israeli-made Galil 7.62-mm assault rifle in connection with the Aug. 18 slaying of Galan, according to Colombian authorities and law enforcement documents cited by Newsday. The weapon was one of several firearms and explosives discovered by the Colombian police and military in two Bogota safehouses when they arrested the four suspected assassins on Sept. 21, the newspaper said. The four men accused in the Miami arms case appeared Tuesday before U.S. Magistrate Linnea Johnson, who ordered the two Venezuelans held without bond for a hearing Friday. The Ben-Tovs each were granted a $350,000 bond but could not immediately make bail. All four were being held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami. The guns confiscated Monday included 101 Glock and 21 Beretta semiautomatics, both equipped with 15-shot clips, and both weapons of choice in many U.S. law enforcement agencies. ``We just don't see Saturday Night specials anymore,'' said ATF spokesman Bruce Snyder. ``Because of the money available in the narcotics trafficking we see Glocks and Berettas, high quality, high-caliber firearms.'' The Ben-Tovs, using their import-export company Express Spare Parts & Equipment Inc., bought the weapons from a legal, licensed dealer in Miami that the ATF would not disclose. But neither they nor the Venezuelans had licenses to sell or export weapons, Mitchell said. The guns were bought for $46,500, but on the South American black market were worth approximately $200,000, the ATF said. While the Ben-Tovs indicated the guns were going by boat to Colombia, the two Venezuelans said the weapons were first headed to their homeland. Florida has long been a source for illegal weapons flowing to Colombia, said Snyder, who estimated ``thousands and thousands'' of guns end up in that South American country, many in the hands of drug traffickers. A recent random check of 158 guns confiscated in Colombian during 1989 found that 85 weapons, or 54 percent, originated in Florida. ``Traditionally it has been dope in, guns out, and this is another example of guns being exported from Florida,'' said Snyder.

DOC.HEAD: 90-Year-old Retiree Acquitted of Three Murders
DOC.TEXT: A 90-year-old who often argued with others at the retirement home where he lived has been acquitted of thrashing to death three fellow residents with his cane. Henry Thomas left the courtroom in his wheelchair Tuesday, a free man for the first time since his arrest in blood-spattered clothes the night of the New Year's Day 1989 slayings. ``Thank you to the jury and the judge,'' he said. Thomas had been charged with murdering three people with his heavy oak cane. Two residents died at the scene, and a third, left with a fractured skull, died a month later. Three others recovered from their injuries. The defense had raised doubts that Thomas carried out the killings or was even capable physically of the crime. Authorities said the retired fruit picker argued often with other residents at the Reflections I home that housed nine people some 30 miles northeast of Tampa. Thomas shared a 10-by-9-foot room with two people. They said he became angry when, for example, his belongings were moved. Thomas' lawyers helped him stand as the verdicts were read. He lifted an index finger in a salute to the judge as he was declared innocent. Defense attorney William Eble embraced Richard Thomas, Henry Thomas' son, and told him: ``Take care of your dad. Take him home.'' ``I turned this over to the Lord a long time ago. If this is his will, then I accept it,'' said Charles Tear, whose father, Frank Tear, died of injuries received in the attack at the home owned by Charles Tear's wife, Helen. Prosecutor Phil Van Allen had no comment after the verdict. Thomas had said he saw and heard intruders and fled out the front door when they began beating his roommates. Residents who survived had described the attacker as a young man.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The general approach that we're proposing seems to be getting wide acceptance.'' _ President Bush telling reporters that U.S. proposals for revamping nuclear strategy are being favorably received by the NATO allies.

``If we have to vote, I shall vote for Gorbachev, simply because there is no other alternative.'' _ Delegate Vitaly G. Karpenko at the Communist Party congress which is expected to vote to keep Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the top party job.

``I think there is support on the (Capitol) Hill for this, but people are going to start asking what is being cleaned up? What is being accomplished?'' _ Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash., as members of Congress were given a figure of around $30 billion for cleaning up radioactive waste at weapons plants over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,445.92, up 31.32 points, or 0.10 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: America Celebrates Midweek Fourth
With PM-Forgotten Flag, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Today's midweek Fourth of July meant only one day of independence from work for many Americans _ a day for the traditional fireworks and flagwaving as well as such offbeat activities as stone-skipping and sandcastle-building. Other events included a blue-claw crab race in Tuckerton, N.J., and the cutting of a gigantic cake in Philadelphia. Lasers, not fireworks, were to light up the sky over Atlantic City, N.J., tonight. Several communities staged their fireworks shows early this year. Pittsburgh set off its rockets Tuesday night to save an estimated $20,000 in overtime for police, paramedics and parks workers. ``The administration thinks the most patriotic thing to do is not to raise taxes,'' said Al Neri, spokesman for Mayor Sophie Masloff. Kennebunkport, Maine, also held its fireworks show the night before the Fourth _ for a presidential audience. President Bush, whose summer estate is along the town's oceanfront, watched from aboard a Coast Guard vessel. Bush's five-day stay in Maine was set to end before the holiday did. He flies to London tonight for a NATO summit. Detroit staged its fireworks extravaganza on Monday night. About 1 million people flocked to the banks of the Detroit River for the joint celebration with Windsor, Ontario, across the river. But Ridgewood, N.J., canceled its fireworks show for the first time in 40 years after police said they couldn't hire enough officers for crowd control. ``It was just getting out of hand,'' said police Capt. Anthony Cortazzo. Tourism industry officials were wondering how much they'd have to cheer about. ``We have a pretty good crowd now, but the holiday coming in the middle of the week is going to hurt some,'' said Mark Soifer, spokesman for Ocean City, N.J. But Jane Phillips, director of tourism for Wildwood, N.J., said some tourists were taking the unusual step of making reservations for a five-day weekend. ``This weekend is lining up bigger than years before,'' she said. On the boardwalk in Atlantic City, N.J., some people weren't satisfied with having just today off. ``I guess I should be at work,'' Sondra Washington of Philadelphia said Tuesday. ``The weather is too nice. One day isn't going to matter.'' For some cities, July Fourth was a time to think big. In Philadelphia, birthplace of the Declaration of Independence, former President Carter was to join Mayor W. Wilson Goode in cutting ``America's Birthday Cake,'' big enough to serve 25,000 people. Carter also was to receive the Philadelphia Liberty Medal, which carries a $100,000 prize. Myrtle Beach, S.C., officials hoped to get enough beachgoers together to build the world's longest sandcastle _ 10 miles long. The city lost by 1{ miles last month when Long Beach, Wash., built a world record 6.5-mile-long castle. The centerpiece of the sculpture was to be an American flag tinted with Kool-Aid or hair color. Adults were to engage in another children's pastime on Mackinac Island, Mich. _ skipping stones. Thousands were expected to participate in the annual International Stoneskipping contest at Windermere Beach. Among the contestants: Arthur ``Babe'' Ring, 75, who holds the world record, 29 plinks and pitty pats set Aug. 4, 1984, on the Russian River in California.

DOC.HEAD: 24 Pedestrians Reported Stung by Dart Shooter
DOC.TEXT: A man lurking the streets with a homemade blowgun has stung as many as 24 women with tiny darts fashioned out of pins or needles, police say. ``We have no idea why he's doing this,'' Deputy Inspector Robert Frankel said Tuesday. ``This whole thing is weird.'' Police had earlier reported 10 women were stung in the backs or the buttocks since June 26. Since then, 14 more women called to report they had been hit by the dart-blowing man, seven of them on Monday, police said. None of the women was seriously hurt, police said. The darts that have been recovered are being subjected to toxicology tests. No traces of poison or other substances have been found, police said. The victims, all dressed in business suits when they were hit, ranged in age from 21 to 44, and most were stung on crowded midtown Manhattan sidewalks in the afternoon, police said. Witnesses to two attacks said the man stood behind the victims and blew a dart through a straw-like device. The dart was described as a needle or straight pin with paper glued onto it.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Gain, Dollar Plunges
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange inched up Wednesday after narrowing its early gains in the afternoon, while the dollar plunged against the Japanese yen. The dollar ended at 150.30 yen, down 1.38 yen from Tuesday's 151.68-yen finish. It opened at 150.25 yen and ranged between 149.90 yen and 150.65 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 31.32 points, or 0.10 percent, ending the day at 32,445.92. The index rose 254.37 points on Tuesday. The Nikkei gained 100.66 points at the end of the morning session but gradually fell as market players sold high-tech issues due to the yen's appreciation, traders said. Currency dealers said the dollar's low opening followed its similar weakness against major currencies in overseas markets. Japanese investors indulged in heavy stop-loss selling based on their concern that U.S. interest rates are headed lower, said Masaya Ueno, a Fuji Bank dealer. Lower interest rates tend to make a country's currency less attractive to overseas investors. Other dealers said the currency moved in a narrow range as the market waited for Washington's announcement of the U.S. unemployment rate for June, scheduled for Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor `Guaranteed' Conviction in Marcos Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, `Mrs. Marcos ...' to CORRECT song title.
DOC.TEXT: Former federal prosecutor Rudolph Giuliani ``guaranteed'' a conviction against Ferdinand Marcos in the case that ended with the acquittals of his widow and Adnan Khashoggi. A State Department document obtained by The Associated Press on Tuesday said the U.S. Justice Department had concluded ``the evidence is sufficient to prevail. (Giuliani has ``guaranteed'' success.)'' The former Philippine president died in September before the case went to trial. But Imelda Marcos and Khashoggi were acquitted Monday of fraud and racketeering charges. Mrs. Marcos had been charged with helping loot the Philippine treasury of $222 million and secretly buy real estate, art and jewelry. Khashoggi, a Saudi financier, had been charged with helping her conceal real estate purchases. The State Department memorandum said Giuliani believed the evidence was so strong that there was no reason to offer Marcos a plea bargain. The 1988 document did not mention Mrs. Marcos or Khashoggi. Giuliani left his post as U.S. attorney in January 1989 and lost the mayoral race to David Dinkins last November. Now at a law firm, Giuliani did not return a phone call Tuesday. A secretary said it is his policy not to comment on cases from his tenure as U.S. attorney. After the verdicts, Mrs. Marcos joined Khashoggi, 54, at a noisy victory party in a restaurant complete with Arab food, champagne, two bands, belly dancers, a whirling dervish act and a huge cake to mark Mrs. Marcos' 61st birthday, which was Monday. Mrs. Marcos, famous for singing to her guests at parties, joined in a duet of ``Ako ay Pilipino (I am a Filipino)'' with Imelda Papin, a popular Philippines singer who left the country after the Marcoses' ouster in 1986. Mrs. Marcos went to sleep around dawn, said one of her lawyers, Benjamin Cassiday. On Tuesday, she left for the Hillsborough, N.J., home of her friend Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress who loaned her a New York City apartment during the three-month trial. The acquittal touched off speculation that Mrs. Marcos might return home and even mount a political challenge to President Corazon Aquino, who replaced Marcos. But Aquino said her government still considered Mrs. Marcos a security threat and would not allow her back. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said a 1989 order by the Immigration and Naturalization Service barring Mrs. Marcos from leaving the country remains in effect. He said the ban was based on the potential for ``destabilizing activity'' should she return to Manila. Khashoggi, meanwhile, headed to Palm Beach, Fla., and planned to fly to France and then to Saudi Arabia, to visit Islam's holiest shrine at Mecca.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Soviet-born comic Yakov Smirnoff has nothing funny to report from his first visit in 12 years to his homeland. ``It's a very depressed country,'' said Smirnoff, 39, who immigrated to the United States with his parents in 1977 and became a citizen on July 4, 1986. ``People are in a survival mode. There are still long lines for food, although the lines are even longer now. And if there are no lines, it's because there is no food,'' said the ``what-a-country!'' comic. Smirnoff returned in April to tape a TV special. ``I can live another 12 years without going back,'' he said in a recent interview in Las Vegas. ``I'm in love with America. It's my home, and I feel very much at home.''

Richard Lewis says viewer power got his series ``Anything But Love'' renewed after ABC had announced its cancellation. The renewal was a ``vote of confidence in the people on the street who loved the show and told us how disappointed they were that it was canceled,'' the comic said in this week's TV Guide. Lewis said his character, Marty Gold, and Hannah Miller, played by Jamie Lee Curtis, will ``definitely'' sleep together after a platonic first season. ``I don't think Marty will perform all that well in bed,'' he said. ``Studs don't get laughs on TV.'' He doesn't think heating up the Marty-Hannah relationship will cool down interest in the series. ``Look how long Ozzie and Harriet were on,'' he said. ``We're going to be the new Ozzie and Harriet. Only Ozzie had better posture than I have.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: k.d. lang is cq
DOC.TEXT: Radio stations in farm states Minnesota, Nebraska and Iowa boycotting Grammy-winning singer k.d. lang because of her appearance in a ``Meat Stinks'' advertising campaign. Patrick John, program director of KSUM-AM in Fairmont, said Monday his station won't play lang's music until she disavows People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, which put together the campaign. The singer is a vegetarian. John said KSUM serves a major pork producing region and its biggest supporters are farmers. Four stations in Sioux City, Iowa, and North Platte, Norfolk and Lexington, Neb., have also said they will boycott lang's music. A Sioux Falls, S.D., station tried a different approach. KXRB-AM gave away filet mignon to callers each time it played one of lang's songs Tuesday. ``We decided to take a different twist and still show our disapproval and give people the opportunity to enjoy beef at the same time,'' said Tony Randall, the station's farm director.

Stan Cottrell, who once ran 3,000 miles through China, is off on a jog from Berlin's Brandenburg Gate to Moscow's Red Square. ``When you run, you promote friendship first, and peace is the result of that friendship,'' Cottrell, 47, said before leaving for Germany to start his run today. The opening of the Berlin Wall and other changes in Eastern Europe made the run possible. Cottrell plans to complete the 1,300-mile run in 40 days. He will go through 40 cities, covering 26 to 44 miles a day. Cottrell has run more than 140,000 miles to promote peace. In 1984, he ran miles through China. The idea for the Berlin-to-Moscow run came two years ago, when he ran across Vietnam. ``I can't forget what the Russian official who stayed with me for several days said: `What you are doing with your run is one of the most powerful forms of diplomacy I have ever seen. Would you consider doing this in our country?''' ``Just ask me!'' Cottrell said he replied.

Snooky Lanson, a singing star of television's ``Your Hit Parade'' in the 1950s, is dead at age 76. Lanson, whose real name was Roy Landman, was nicknamed ``Snooky'' at age 2 after the Irving Berlin tune ``Snooky-Ookums.'' He got his first singing job with band leader Francis Craig at Nashville radio station WSM. In 1940, Lanson was hired by the Ray Noble Band, and a year later recorded the hit record ``By the Light of the Silvery Moon.'' In the late 1940s, he had a hit with ``The Old Master Painter,'' which helped him land the spot on ``Your Hit Parade.'' He sang on the show from 1950 to 1957. Lanson died Monday in Nashville where he had lived since 1967.

George B. Peters, a dean of men at the University of Pennsylvania in the 1950s and early 1960s, died following a long illness. He died Saturday at age 75. Peters became the university's first dean of men in 1954. In May 1955 he led a crackdown on students who threw eggs and stones at police when a traditional revelry called the Rowbottom got out of hand. A discipline committee Peters headed suspended 20 students and put six fraternities on social probation for up to nine months, meaning they could have no female visitors. He also served as a finish judge at the Penn Relays from 1934 to 1971. Peters became Penn's associate treasurer in 1961 and held the position until he retired in 1978. During World War II, he survived the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, and was awarded the Purple Heart. He was a lieutenant commander in the Navy aboard the USS Maryland.

DOC.HEAD: Maker Recalls Duck Pull Toys
DOC.TEXT: A New York manufacturer is recalling more than 54,000 duck decoy pull toys because they may pose a choking and sharp-point hazard to young children. The screw holding the duck's wing in place separated from the 10-inch decoy in tests, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Tuesday. The ducks, made of yellow and orange plastic by Artsana of America Inc., have been sold nationwide since 1987. The toys have four wheels, movable feet, wings, eyes and beak and make a quacking sound when pulled. The name ``Chicco'' is printed in blue just above the duck's right wing and the packing box is labeled in part: ``No. 63002.0 Decoy Duck Made in Italy,'' said the agency. Consumers are advised to return the ducks to the store where purchased for a refund.
DOC.HEAD: Congressman Pleads for Cut in Infant Formula Prices
DOC.TEXT: Infant formula makers should reduce their prices by 30 percent to prevent thousands of women and babies from being dropped from a federally-funded feeding program, says Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. Infant formula prices have s risen nearly 150 percent in the last 10 years, surpassing milk price increases of 36.4 percent, grocery increases of 50.8 percent, and the 59.1 percent rate of inflation, Wyden said Tuesday. About a third of the formula sold in this country goes to mothers enrolled in the Special Supplemental Feeding Program for Women, Infants and Children. Wyden said he wrote to the chief operating officers of the five leading formula makers asking for price reductions.
DOC.HEAD: GAO Report Says $45 Million In Government Property Missing From
DOC.TEXT: Lab

More than $45 million worth of equipment, ranging from typewriters to microcomputers, is missing from the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California, says the General Accounting Office. The GAO, asked to investigate charges that equipment was being stolen from the federal laboratory to buy illegal drugs, said in the report released this week that Livermore could not account for 27,528 items. The study is based on an inventory conducted last January, the GAO said. Chemicals that could be used to make drugs are stocked at the nuclear weapons research and development facility, but the GAO said it could not identify any losses of such chemicals. The GAO said it could not confirm whether the laboratory was missing any highly explosive materials and could say only that the loss from the lab's inventory of $10.2 million in precious metals was ``low.'' Missing items from Livermore, the GAO said, total about 16 percent of the property listed in the laboratory inventory. It noted many items are not listed in the inventory so losses from this group could not be confirmed. Lawrence Livermore, located in Livermore, Calif. is owned by the Department of Energy and operated by the University of California. In hearings two years ago before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, there were allegations that government-owned equipment was being stolen from Livermore to finance purchases of illegal drugs. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, was ordered to conduct an investigation to determine how much property was missing.

DOC.HEAD: Three Schools Will Become Teacher Training Grounds
With PM-Teachers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Schools in Los Angeles, Minneapolis and Rochester, N.Y., will be transformed into ``professional practice schools'' where fledgling teachers will get close, detailed attention instead of the usual sink-or-swim training. The initiative was announced Tuesday by the American Federation of Teachers at the 744,000-member union's annual convention. The schools selected by the union are Norwood Elementary in Los Angeles, Henry High School in Minneapolis, and Marshall High School in Rochester. Each school will receive $30,000 in grants from the Exxon Education Foundation. Starting next fall, the schools will operate on much the same philosophy as teaching hospitals in the training of doctors, said Bruce Goldberg, co-director of the 2-year-old AFT Center for Restructuring. Currently, most teacher trainees get sink-or-swim training with occasional help from a mentor teacher. ``The professional practice school model will give student teachers the opportunity to work in a clinical training site that supports collegiality and inquiry for students and teachers,'' said AFT president Albert Shanker. The notion of transforming schools into teacher training centers has been supported by several teacher colleges in recent years, said Goldberg. About 25 to 30 such collaborations have sprung up in the last couple of years, he said. But this represents the first direct involvement by the AFT and is the latest element in the union's push for radical school change.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Reveal Billions In Holdings, Refuse To Give Them Up
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party has for the first time released an estimate of its holdings, which run into the billions of dollars, and its leaders say they'll fight reformers who seek to strip the party of its assets. Such demands are intended ``to weaken the party, deprive it of its material basis and make it unable to engage in political struggle,'' party Central Committee official Nikolai Kruchina told Communist delegates Tuesday. Addressing the party's 28th Congress in the grandiose Kremlin Palace of Congresses, Kruchina insisted that a new Soviet property law guarantees that only an owner can dispose of property. The party said its property was valued at 4.9 billion rubles ($8.2 billion at the official rate). But the figure does not include the luxury dachas and special stores for the party's elite. It does count printing presses, schools, office buildings and vacation retreats, all valuable in the political struggle. On Tuesday, Communist officials claimed the party has accumulated its property with the dues of its members, who number 19 million. A document distributed to members also revealed that revenues will plummet this year by as much as 1 billion rubles ($1.7 billion), largely because the party will be forced to pay taxes on its network of 114 publishing houses for the first time. That will force drastic cutbacks in the staff of 293,000, the document says. Most of the party's wealth is in real estate, including 5,254 local party buildings, the document says. The party owns 212 million rubles' ($355 million) worth of schools for teaching Communist catechism as well as resorts and health spas worth nearly twice that. The document does not disclose the party's most closely held financial secret: the cost of luxurious second homes, chauffeured limousines and exotic groceries for the party elite. But Kruchina did say the party would no longer pay for officials' dachas. The most significant properties in the Communist portfolio are the publishing houses. In much of the country, the party owns the only printing presses, controlling publication of all newspapers, magazines and books. For example, the Communist Party claims ownership of the only printing plant capable of producing newspapers in the entire republic of Lithuania. Democratic activists who have been threatening to break away from the party if it does not reform in the coming weeks say they will fight for their share of the spoils. Party official Alla Nizotseva won strong applause from the delegates for rejecting that possibility. A leader of the progressive Democratic Platform, Moscow deputy mayor Sergei Stankevich, predicted Monday that the issue would be decided by the country's popularly elected legislative bodies. Many city councils and republic-wide parliaments, empowered by popular mandate, are increasingly challenging the once dictatorial Communist Party. The city councils of Moscow and Leningrad are among those now controlled by reformers. The delegates' document says the party has been earning 1 billion rubles ($1.7 billion dollars) a year on its publishing operations. But it says that the new Soviet tax law will cut that profit to 200 million rubles this year. An official at the Central Committee said the party has never previously paid taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Health Risks in America: Smoking in Kentucky, Drinking in Wisconsin
With PM-Nasty Habits-List
DOC.TEXT: People in Wisconsin lead a new coast-to-coast survey in obesity, binge drinking and drinking and driving. The source is the Centers for Disease Control's annual Behavioral Risk Factor Survey, a 36-state effort to measure America's nasty health habits. The CDC released the results this week. Americans in participating states were asked about the things they do to jeopardize their health, such as smoking, staying fat, going on drinking binges and not wearing seat belts. In Wisconsin, 28 percent of respondents said they were overweight, according to the CDC. Twenty-five percent reported ``binge drinking'' _ five or more drinks in a sitting in the previous month _ and 6 percent admitted drinking and driving. ``As far as for weight, it's really a Midwestern thing,'' said Michael Soref, coordinator of the Wisconsin survey. ``Whatever it is that makes the Midwest high on that ... applies to Wisconsin, too.'' In reporting the results, the CDC said unhealthy behavior patterns vary considerably from state to state. In Kentucky, 34 percent reported they were smokers, worst among the states. But just 1.4 percent reported drinking too much and driving in the previous month, one of the best rates in the nation. ``For drinking, this is a very conservative state, with a lot of religious conservatives. Alcohol has consistently been frowned upon, and that has a lot to do with it,'' said Phyllis Skonicki, manager of the Health Promotion Branch for the Kentucky Department of Health Services. ``The tobacco issue is something else in Kentucky,'' she said. ``We're one of the largest growing states in the nation. ... From the smallest farm to the largest, you're going to find some tobacco.'' Other survey extremes: _New Mexico is the slimmest state, with just 15 percent of the respondents overweight. _New Yorkers don't have much inclination to exercise _ or maybe they don't have much time. Seventy-four percent reported getting less than three 20-minute sessions of leisure-time physical activity a week. Washington state was best, at 45 percent. _Tobacco is taboo in Utah, where just 15 percent smoke. _Binge drinking is rarest in the nation's capital, just 7 percent. ``Heavy drinking'' _ 60 drinks a month _ ranged from 3 percent in North Dakota to 11 percent in New Hampshire. _Just 7 percent of Hawaiians ignore their seat belts, compared with 67 percent in South Dakota. _In Maine, 58 percent have had their cholesterol checked, compared with 41 percent in New Mexico. _And a 17-state survey of women and mammograms showed the greatest use in Maine, where 68 percent of women age 40 to 49 had had one. In Nebraska, it was 42 percent. The survey is intended to give states specific data to help them measure progress in health behavior, said Dr. Eric Mast, a CDC health surveillance specialist. The CDC hopes to have all 50 states and all U.S. territories in the survey soon.

DOC.HEAD: Father Sues for Bone Marrow Transplant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tamas cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A tavern owner is suing to force two of his children to undergo tests to determine whether a donation of their bone marrow could save their leukemia-stricken half-brother. Tamas Bosze of suburban Hoffman Estates has asked a judge to order Nancy Curran to allow blood tests on the 3-year-old twins he fathered. If their marrow is compatible, he also wants the judge to order the twins to donate some to save the life of 12-year-old Jean-Pierre Bosze, who was born to another woman. Curran, Bosze's former girlfriend, believes extracting bone marrow from the twins would be risky, and she has refused to allow compatibility testing. Arguments began in state court Monday and resume next week. The father's attorney argues the potential to save the boy outweighs the risk involved in extracting marrow. ``When there's a chance to save a young life, we can't overlook it, we've got to do everything we can,'' said Edward R. Jordan. ``If the twins can undergo a minimally invasive procedure to save their half-sibling, I think they should do it.'' Jean-Pierre's parents and another brother were tested and found to be incompatible, Jordan said. Another half-sister by a different mother is being tested. The boy's doctor, Jong H. Kwon, said that after intensive chemotherapy, Jean-Pierre has relapsed and that his best chance for survival is a bone-marrow transplant. The best chance of compatibility lies with the twins, he said. Kwon, a pediatric hematology oncologist at Lutheran General Hospital in suburban Park Ridge, said the risks in donating marrow include pain; anemia; a possible need for a blood transfusion, and infection. Curran has sole custody of the twins, and that gives her the right to decide whether they will donate marrow, her attorney, Beverly Pekala, said Tuesday. Bosze and Curran, a secretary, had lived together but broke up before the twins _ a boy and a girl _ were born. During their relationship, Bosze was married to another woman, who is Jean-Pierre's mother.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Three Killed In Rioting During Prison Break
DOC.TEXT: Armed inmates seeking to break out touched off a riot at a state penitentiary in which at least three people were killed and several dozen fled, authorities said. Most of the estimated 30 prisoners who escaped during Tuesday afternoon's confusion were later reported to have been captured, and authorities reported the 1,200-inmate facility quiet early today. The escapees from the prison in the state capital of Chihuahua included convicted murderers and drug traffickers. Reports conflicted on the number of convicts who fled and on the number of deaths and injuries in the incident. Chihuahua state attorney general Jose Miller said authorities had captured 19 of 32 fugitives, the independent news agency Excelsior reported. It quoted Miller as saying three inmates were killed and nine injured in the riot. The newspaper Diario de Chihuahua reported that two prisoners and two guards were killed during the melee, and 34 prisoners escaped. Twelve escapees were still being sought early today, it said. Sergio Granados Pineda, Chihuahua state's interior secretary, initially estimated that 60 prisoners had escaped and said four were killed and 15 injured, the government news agency Notimex reported. Authorities in Chihuahua, 225 south of El Paso, Texas, could not be reached for comment by The Associated Press. Miller was quoted by Excelsior as saying convicted drug trafficker Juan de Dios Levario Quiroz was suspected of instigating the riot. He said Levario was killed in the jailbreak. ``Apparently it was all planned. Several prisoners had guns and two vehicles awaited them outside,'' Diario de Chihuahua news editor Leo Zavala said by telephone. Prisoners apparently held guards at gunpoint, Excelsior quoted Miller as saying. The search for the escapees was conducted with helicopters, airplanes and automobiles ansd roadblocks were set up on major highways, Notimex said. Granados Pineda was quoted as saying the army helped city, state and federal police put down the riot. He said the prisoners were under control late Tuesday. He said some of the escapees were serving the maximum Mexican prison sentence of 40 years. Among the fugitives being sought late Tuesday night was Alfonso Parga Palafox, convicted of drug trafficking, seven murders in Mexico and five murders in the United States, Zavala said. Also free was Gerardo Noe Payan, who had been convicted of killing three Chihuahua university students in 1987, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Marcos Juror Says Panel Knew of News Coverage
DOC.TEXT: A member of the jury that cleared Imelda Marcos says jurors were influenced by supposedly off-limit news reports that the judge had expressed doubts about whether the case belonged in a U.S. court. ``Everybody knew about that,'' Alan Belofsky said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ``It was even quoted by one or two people.'' Asked if U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan's comments influenced jurors' thinking, he said, ``I'd assume so.'' On Monday, another juror, Thomas O'Rourke, said after the verdict, ``We are not big brothers to the people overseas. It was a totally silly case.'' The jury acquitted the former Philippines first lady and Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi of racketeering and fraud. Mrs. Marcos was accused of helping loot her homeland of $222 million and sinking the money into art and real estate. Belofsky, a 41-year-old letter carrier from the New York suburb of Bronxville, said nobody on the panel liked or trusted Mrs. Marcos' chief attorney, Gerry Spence. ``He lied to us. He lied to us an awful lot,'' Belofsky said. ``Spence should not think that he won the case. It was that the prosecution didn't give us enough evidence, the right evidence.'' Belofsky also said jurors were aware of Keenan's doubts about the case being tried in New York instead of in the Philippines. On June 20, Keenan wondered, out of the jury's presence, ``what this case is doing in an American court.'' His remarks were reported in news accounts where jurors, though admonished not to read about the trial, could see them. Belofsky said the panel found Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella's delivery bland and confusing. ``Just as we'd start to think about one subject, they'd jump to another one,'' he said. He said a ``consensus'' of jurors thought Mrs. Marcos knew about the huge thefts attributed to her husband, the late Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos. She ``probably was a little bit guilty, but there wasn't enough evidence. I'm not going to put somebody in jail on the basis of that,'' Belofsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Calvin Klein Thrown Off a Horse
DOC.TEXT: Designer Calvin Klein was reported in stable condition with broken ribs and cuts on his head today after being thrown from a horse. Klein, 47, was taken by helicopter to New York Hospital after the riding accident Tuesday in Bridgehampton, on Long Island, said hospital spokeswoman Mary Cialone. ``I'm sure he'll be here for the next few days,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: School Reform Doesn't Come Easy
With PM-Teachers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: School reform sounds great, but teacher union leaders from three cities in the forefront of change say they've learned the headaches may be as numerous as the gains. Turf wars with principals and other administrators, lack of training and planning, a shortage of money and even flak from fellow teachers are a few of the pitfalls reformers have been encountering. So said teacher union members Tuesday from Dade County, Fla., Rochester, N.Y., and Hammond, Ind., districts that have gotten high marks for their reform efforts. Addressing a workshop at the American Federation of Teachers annual convention meeting here this week, local union president Pat Tornillo of Dade County said an added problem is that the public expects a quick fix. For three years, teachers in Dade have gained authority over a wide range of issues in 155 of the 275 schools. ``Have we turned test scores around? Has there been some kind of miracle as a result of these reforms? No. It takes more than three years,'' Tornillo said. Adam Urbanski, president of the AFT local in Rochester that two years ago obtained a contract instituting numerous reforms and raising salaries for top teachers to over $70,0000, warned that ``in search of reform, you're likely to encounter shortages of ideas more often than shortages of money.'' He told teachers to expect ``tremendous turf wars. Administrators believe they have less leadership if they share it.'' In Rochester, Urbanski said, poor parents were sometimes mistrustful of reform. They wanted the kind of education rich kids get; they didn't want to be the guinea pigs for the latest reform fads, he said. In Hammond, a district with chronic money problems that 10 years ago was among the first to try school-based governance, AFT president Patrick O'Rourke said that perhaps one-third of the teachers have grown so cynical and powerless they resist change. ``Having said all that,'' Tornillo said, ``come on in, the water's fine. If we don't try reform, the public schools as we've known them won't survive.''

DOC.HEAD: Pilot of Rodeo-Bound Plane Couldn't See Mountain Before Crash
DOC.TEXT: A pilot radioed he couldn't see Mount Rainier minutes before his charter plane slammed into the cloud-shrouded peak, killing four champion calf-ropers en route to a rodeo in Canada, authorities say. The single-engine plane plowed into a glacier Monday at the 12,500-foot level of the 14,411-foot mountain. An Army helicopter brought the bodies of the five men down from the mountain on Tuesday. The cowboys had chartered the plane to go to a rodeo in Ponoka, Alberta. The Ponoka Stampede is the last big rodeo in Canada before the big Calgary Stampede, said Keith Hyland of the Canadian Professional Rodeo Association. The four were chasing the prizes of Cowboy Christmas, a 10-day stretch in which a competitor may hit a dozen shows and make 20 percent of his annual earnings. Minutes before the crash, pilot H.R Card had radioed to air traffic controllers that he couldn't see the mountain, said Bill Hamilton, assistant secretary of the state Department of Transportation's Aeronautics Division. Card was told to take evasive action. But moments later contact was lost, said Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Mitch Barker. Killed besides the pilot were Dave Smith, 31, of College Place; David Bowen, 28, of Yoakum, Texas; Randy Dierlam, 29, of Seadrift, Texas, and Mike Currin, 25, of Hermiston, Ore. Bowen was the sixth-ranked PRCA calf roper last year. Dierlam was No. 10 and Smith 18. Currin was PRCA Resistol rookie of the year in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Nazi to Try to Regain U.S. Citizenship
DOC.TEXT: A former supervisor at a Nazi rocket factory where thousands of slave laborers died has come to Canada in an attempt to win back his U.S. citizenship, his supporters say. Six years ago 83-year-old Arthur Rudolph renounced his U.S. citizenship and went to West Germany amid allegations he persecuted the laborers. He arrived in Canada on Sunday. Rudolph was to meet today in Niagara Falls, Ontario, with Congressman James Traficant, D-Ohio, who supports Rudolph's bid to return to the United States, where he helped develop the rocket that put Americans on the moon. The meeting's border setting and the date, Independence Day, were deliberately chosen to try to build support for Traficant's call for congressional hearings to review evidence against Rudolph. Traficant claims a 1947 Army investigation absolved Rudolph of war crimes. One of Rudolph's supporters said about 20 citizens would be in Niagara Falls for the meeting with Traficant. The supporter, Cindy Bendall, said Rudolph was considering walking across the bridge to the United States, which could lead to his arrest. Rudolph has been accused of persecuting workers, including concentration camp inmates, at the German Mittelwerk underground rocket factory between 1943 and 1945. The West German government, after reviewing the U.S. Justice Department's material and interviewing more than 50 witnesses, was unable to prove him guilty of war crimes. He was detained for 9{ hours by customs officials at Toronto's Pearson International Airport after he arrived from Hamburg, West Germany, on Sunday. A senior immigration official said the Justice Department had alerted the Royal Canadian Mounted Police about a month ago that Rudolph was headed for Canada. The tip came after Traficant announced that he would try to get Rudolph back into the U.S. through Canada, a Justice Department spokesman said. Traficant made the announcement at a May 12 dinner in Huntsville, Ala., Rudolph's former home, where 140 supporters paid $20 each to raise cash for a possible legal battle. The northern Alabama city is home to NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center, where Rudolph and other scientists who worked on Nazi rocket weapons developed rockets for U.S. moonshots. Rudolph is believed to be the first person facing deportation from Canada under a 1988 amendment to the Immigration Act barring war criminals, an Immigration Canada spokesman said. His immigration hearing is scheduled to start Friday, but it will likely be adjourned to another day, the spokesman said. Major Canadian Jewish groups called for the government to deport Rudolph. ``We think he should have been put on the next plane back to Hamburg,'' said Sol Littman, Canadian representative for the Nazi-hunter Simon Wiesenthal, who is based in Los Angeles. Rudolph agreed to leave the United States in 1984 after signing an agreement conceding his citizenship was illegally obtained. Rudolph now says the statement was coerced from him and that he was told his pension and the citizenship of his wife and daughter would be jeopardized ``if I do not do as they said.'' U.S. Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said Rudolph signed the declaration voluntarily after consulting a lawyer.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys 100-Year-Old Jail Section
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 400 inmates were evacuated under watch by SWAT team officers as a fire blamed on a workman's propane torch destroyed a 100-year-old section of the city jail. Two firefighters and a guard suffered minor injuries in the blaze Tuesday at a medium-security sector of the 1,000-inmate Bridgeport Correctional Center, authorities said. The fire broke out in the oldest of the jail's five buildings, a three-story, wood and brick structure. It was brought under control more than four hours later. Fire officials said the blaze apparently started on the roof, where workers were using propane torches. SWAT team officers were sent to oversee the evacuation, which was described as orderly. About 30 state troopers were put on standby. Anxious relatives of inmates gathered outside, awaiting word of loved ones. ``I'm counting on God,'' said Mildred Ramos of Bridgeport, whose son is an inmate. Most of the 375 inmates evacuated to a gymnasium will be transferred to other jails, said Correction Department spokesman Bob Wheeler. ``It will create a burden, but right now we have a luxury of extra beds being available,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Record-Breaking Heat Southwest to Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Hot and dry weather prevailed across most of the nation for today's Fourth of July holiday after a day of record-breaking heat. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered from the lower Mississippi Valley to Florida and Georgia early today. Showers and thunderstorms were also scattered from Arizona across Colorado, New Mexico, southwestern Texas and Wyoming. A few showers were over northern New England. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. The hot high-pressure dome that was over the Southwest a week ago and over the central Plains and Rockies the past few days shifted toward the upper Mississippi Valley. Record highs were reported Tuesday in 15 cities from Texas to Michigan. Temperatures reached the 100-degree mark in southern Minnesota and hit 90 degrees as far north as International Falls. Afternoon highs were in the 90s or above 100 across much of the area from the Plains to the southern Atlantic Coast. Readings in the 70s and 80s prevailed over the Great Lakes region, Northeast and the northern Plains. The high for the nation was 112 at Laughlin, Nev. Other reports at 3 a.m. EDT: _East: Albany, N.Y. 68 partly cloudy; Atlanta 71 fair; Boston 72 cloudy; Charleston, S.C. 76 partly cloudy; Chattanooga 66 fair; Cincinnati 69 fair; Cleveland 70 fair; Detroit 73 fair; Hatteras 63 fair; Jacksonville 71 foggy; Key West 79 partly cloudy; Knoxville 69 fair; Macon 69 foggy; Miami 73 fair; New York 72 cloudy; Philadelphia 72 fair; Pittsburgh 68 cloudy; Portland 71 cloudy; Richmond 66 fair; Tampa 75 fair; Washington, D.C. 71 partly cloudy. _Central: Birmingham 72 fair; Bismarck 59 o data; Denver 62 partly cloudy; Des Moines 80 fair; Indianapolis 70 fair; Kansas City 81 fair; Little Rock 79 hazy; Louisville 73 fair; Memphis 78 hazy; Nashville 75 fair; New Orleans 76 partly cloudy; North Platte 69 showers; Oklahoma City 77 fair; Omaha 77 fair; Rapid City 66 fair; St. Louis 84 fair; Minneapolis-St. Paul 78 partly cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 70 foggy; San Antonio 77 fair. _West: Albuquerque 69 cloudy; Anchorage 60 fair; Boise 55 fair; Casper 61 fair; Fairbanks 66 partly cloudy; Great Falls 48 fair; Honolulu 76 fair; Las Vegas 83 fair; Los Angeles 64 fair; Medford 61 partly cloudy; Pendleton 54 partly cloudy; Phoenix 91 fair; Portland, Ore. 63 cloudy; Reno 57 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 70 fair; San Diego 66 fair; San Francisco 59 partly cloudy; Seattle 61 cloudy; Spokane 55 partly cloudy. _International: Calgary 46 partly cloudy; Montreal 68 cloudy; Ottawa 70 partly cloudy; Regina 48 windy; Toronto 73 fair; Acapulco 77 cloudy.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Meeting Ends With Agreement On Presidential Elections
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Nationalist Party and its opposition ended a historic meeting today by agreeing that all Taiwanese should choose the next president instead of aging Nationalists from mainland China. The week-long National Affairs Conference ended with a joint statement in support of popular presidential elections and other democratic change. For four decades, the political system has guaranteed Nationalist rule. ``The democratic trend is irresistible,'' said Chang Chung-hung, secretary general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. ``We have just had a peaceful revolution to gain democracy.'' Less dramatic progress was made in discussions on relations with China. The conference urged more trade and cultural exchanges but cautioned against official talks on reunification before the Communist government in Beijing agrees to end its policy of isolating Taipei diplomatically. President Lee Teng-hui said he would support the recommendations reached by the 140 politicians and academics at the conference. ``This is the time to act,'' he told the delegates in a closing speech. Lee called the meeting after student demonstrations in March protesting his election to a six-year term by an electoral college dominated by aging Nationalist Party members. Most members of the electoral college last ran in elections on the Chinese mainland shortly before they fled to Taiwan in 1949, defeated by the Communists in civil war. They were subsequently frozen in office to support the Nationalist claim to still be the legitimate government of all China. The opposition has long argued that popular presidential elections are necessary to give full political power to the native Taiwanese, who account for 85 percent of the island's 20 million people. Many Nationalist delegates to the convention proposed direct presidential elections after Lee's term ends in 1996, but some supported an even earlier date. At a concluding session broadcast live on television, convention delegates also supported direct elections of the mayors of Taiwan's two largest cities, Taipei and Kaohsiung.The posts are now appointed by the Nationalist government. Delegates also supported an earlier Nationalist proposal to retire by 1991 all 800 elderly members from mainland China who sit in the lawmaking Legislative Yuan and electoral college. Officials said a task force of representatives from the major parties would be set up to settle remaining differences on the democratic reforms. One unresolved issue is whether the electoral college should be abolished, as proposed by the opposition, or should be transformed into a symbolic institution that would reflect the popular vote but still reserve a few seats for deputies purportedly representing mainland China. President Lee told the 140 politicians and academics attending the convention that he would back their proposals. Opposition delegate Hsu Hsin-liang said Lee would have to keep his word even with an expected backlash from the conservative Nationalist old guard. ``He has issued a check to all Taiwanese and cannot afford to have it bounce,'' said Hsu.

DOC.HEAD: Italians Tearful Over World Cup Defeat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Turin brawl. Picks up 8th pvs, `The streets ...' ^By TERRY LEONARD
DOC.TEXT: Italians were shocked and bewildered over their elimination in the World Cup soccer semifinal, reacting with tears, anger and defiant chants. Italy's dream of a fourth World Cup title was shattered Tuesday night when its team lost a penalty kick shootout to Argentina 4-3, breaking a 1-1 tie. Italians watched their TV screens in disbelief. ``In other countries soccer is only a game. Here in Italy soccer is something in the heart. I cannot describe how bad I feel,'' said Emiliano Mari of Rome. In Turin, police used tear gas early today to disperse about 1,000 Italians who broke down a gate and attacked English fans sleeping in a park, witnesses and officials said. The other semifinal, between West Germany and England, was to be played in Turin today. Forty-three Italians were arrested, said Turin police chief Antonio Beradino. Three Italians and a policeman were reported hospitalized. An undetermined number of English suffered minor injuries. The streets were eerily quiet in Rome, where thousands of people have noisely celebrated every Italian triumph with flag-waving, horn-honking processions. The ``Azzurri'', or Blues, last won the World Cup in 1982. Two young men on a motorscooter yelled ``forza Italia!'' (power to Italy), but their heart was clearly not in it and there was no response from the few pedestrians on the street. Three young joyously shouting ``Argentina, Argentina!'' on a street in the center of Rome got only insults from passing Italians. Many bars and restaurants closed early _ without the crowds of celebrating fans there was no reason to remain open. Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, who watched the game from the VIP seats at San Paolo Stadium in Naples, tried to put the best face on the defeat in a tournament his government has spent unspecified billions of dollars to host. ``There is sadness but a third or fourth place at the World Cup cannot be dismissed,'' said Andreotti. Even before the defeat there had been some grumbling in Italy about the World Cup, about the problems caused by tournament-related construction, about the money spent by the government to host the tournament. Merchants, hotel operators and restaurant owners all over Italy have complained that the tournament has not produced the promised surge in tourism and in fact that both tourism and profits had declined. ``It's true that the Italian dream is finished. But it's only a ball game. Now we can get on to more important things,'' said one Roman, gesturing to the dog he was walking in a park.

DOC.HEAD: Party Congress Calls on Miners Not to Strike, Asks Gorbachev to Talk to Them
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party congress passed a resolution today appealing to disgruntled coal miners to halt plans for a strike next week to press demands for more far-reaching reforms and better living conditions. The 28th Communist congress, in a stormy session over the party's future, said the threatened strike by up to 1 million miners ``could lead to the break-up of the country's economy,'' Soviet television reported. The miners have said the show of force will last less than one day. The party's appeal, passed by a margin of 3,514 to 354 on the congress' third day, also urged President and party leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to open talks with the miners. A national miners' congress last month voted to strike unless Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and his Cabinet resign. They blame Ryzhkov for an unpopular economic reform plan that calls for drastic price increases but only minor moves toward a market economy. A crippling coal miners' strike last summer ended after the government promised reform, but miners say the changes have been slow in coming. The resolution also criticized the miners for their mass exodus from the party _ which claims to be the vanguard of the workers _ and for locking party organizations out of the mines, Soviet television reported. The miners' congress in June had condemned the Communist Party for hindering the development of a more democratic Soviet society, saying an exodus from a party of diminishing credibility was understandable. ``We are workers, but we do not consider the Communist Party in its present form to be our party,'' the miners' declaration said. Progressives in the party say it is fast becoming irrelevant in the face of burgeoning democratic movements in many of the 15 Soviet republics and victories at the polls that have given reformers control of the governments of major cities including Moscow and Leningrad. Speakers at the conservative-dominated Communist Congress heaped more stinging criticism on Gorbachev on Tuesday. Hard-line Politburo colleagues charged that his five years of reforms haved been scarred by ``limitless radicalism.'' Yet the 59-year-old Soviet president, who has been gradually shifting political power to government bodies from the long-dominant party, appeared unperturbed. Gorbachev won election Tuesday as chairman of the party rules committee, and he joked and laughed at times. Across Moscow on Tuesday night, reformers rallied to declare the Communists irrelevant and demand that they move aside. More than 4,000 demonstrators gathered and cheered speakers including Moscow City Council member Valery Fadeyev, who shouted: ``Down with the bandits who captured power in 1917!'' The crowd cheered lustily at any mention of Boris Yeltsin, the radical president of the Russian republic, who was not present. It whistled derisively at references to the KGB secret police and conservative leaders. Reformers want the party to remove its cells from the police and military. Despite the attacks from hard-liners and threats of a split from progressives, the delegates' stampede toward the center continued today. A poll found most delegates believe all supporters of socialism should rally around the Communist Party, rather than split off as some reformers are threatening, the official Tass news agency reported. The survey also found most delegates alarmed ``by an absence of clear theoretical goals and the leadership's slowness in taking decisions,'' Tass said.
