Leningrad hard-liner Boris Gidaspov told the delegates that ``time is needed'' to implement the party's decision to transfer some of its power to elected officials. He said local governments should have strong executives comparable to the the presidency that gave Gorbachev enhanced powers in March. Delegates murmured impolitely at Gidaspov's speech. Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak, a well-known reformer, told reporters in the marble lobby of the Palace of Congresses, ``There must be a platform of consolidation'' at the party congress. He said he was leaning toward electing Gorbachev to continue as party leader even though he generally opposed the idea of the same person leading both the party and the state.

DOC.HEAD: Tattoos on Patient's Chest Tip Daughter to Long-Lost Father
DOC.TEXT: Medical assistant Allison Forciea had given her father up for dead _ until she saw her birth name tattooed across a patient's chest. Forciea was born Edith Josephine 30 years ago but got a new name when her father gave her up for adoption when she was 2. She was shocked when she saw ``Edie Jo'' tattooed on George Jensen Sr.'s chest. ``When I realized who this person might be, I kind of had to leave the room,'' Forciea said. Forciea said she was afraid about how her father would react. Her anxiety turned to happiness when he turned to her and said, ``If you wouldn't mind, I'd like to get to know you better.'' Jensen, who was seeing an orthopedist for a minor ailment, also had had no word of his Edie Jo until their chance encounter June 5. ``There's got to be a higher being that's pushed us together,'' Jensen said Monday. ``This just doesn't happen by accident.'' The newly found father, who left the appointment with tears in his eyes, said he couldn't believe his luck at finding the daughter he had wondered about for nearly three decades. ``I was ready to go buy a lottery ticket that day,'' said Jensen, who lives with his third wife in Vallejo, about 70 miles northeast of San Francisco. Forciea found her biological mother, Lois Payne, in 1985, and has been in touch with her since. ``I always knew I would find them, since I was 10,'' Forciea said. Now, she can't stop talking to her dad. ``Twenty or 30 times a day, I want to pick up the phone and talk to him,'' Forciea said Monday. ``And it's not like I have anything super important to say. I just want to hear his voice.'' Forciea had been told her father was dead and believed he was until she saw the names ``George Jr.'' and ``Edie Jo'' tattooed across his upper chest. Forciea's older brother was 4 when he and his sister, then 2, were given up for adoption. George Jensen Jr. will be coming from San Diego for a family reunion at a park there. The elder Jensen and his first wife were a struggling young couple with a failing marriage when they decided to give up their children rather than attempt to raise them without financial means, Jensen said. ``We were just unable to take care of them, so we found a family that could,'' Jensen said. ``I talked and thought about them many times. I thought about finding them.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Send Reinforcements To Showdown in Monrovia; Doe Said Ready To Quit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with reports of gunfire. Pickup 2nd, `Political sources...' The following is based on a pool report filed by journalists in Monrovia, including Associated Press reporter Michelle Faul.
DOC.TEXT: Rebels say they are moving reinforcements and heavy artillery to the capital, where fighting has intensified amid reports President Samuel Doe has agreed in principle to resign. Sporadic firing was heard early today in several areas on the city's edge, said the Christian missionary radio station, ELWA, monitored in neighboring Abidjan, Ivory Coast. The radio said some gunfire was heard near its facilities several miles outside the city, but no information was available from government officials. Political sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday that Doe agreed to step down if his safety and that of his minority Krahn tribe are guaranteed. But they said rebel leader Charles Taylor, a former Doe aide, would likely have trouble restraining his people's desire to take revenge after a bitter 6-month-old civil war in this West African nation. A rebel source in neighboring Ivory Coast said 800 insurgents were involved in attacks on Monrovia on Monday and several thousand more were advancing, bringing heavy artillery with them. For Monrovia residents, who have been without water for a week and without electricity since Friday, life got more difficult. Shops remained shuttered and barred. People went out briefly to search for food and water before retreating to the safety of their homes. Four U.S. warships carrying 2,000 Marines are off the Liberian coast, and the United States has offered to evacuate Doe if he asks. Doe's adminstration has asked the United States to intervene on several occasions, but Washington has declined. U.S. officials in Washington said Tuesday they believe Doe's government could collapse within days. The officials, who asked not to be identified, said there had been a number of desertions from the elite unit of about 500 fighters that protects Doe. A rebel leader in the United States, Tom Woewiyu, said the insurgents would not oppose a U.S. evacuation of Doe, who has ruled Liberia since taking over in a bloody coup a decade ago. ``If they can help him, God bless him. If they can't, we'll get him,'' Woewiyu said. ``If they can send a hook from the heavens to pull him up and take him out, fine, we wouldn't mind that. We can try him later.'' There were no reports of fighting Tuesday in Monrovia itself, where Doe was holed up in his heavily fortified executive mansion. But the fighting continued two miles north of Monrovia's port, and further west on the road to Sierra Leone near the Hotel Africa _ the city's biggest hotel complex. Sounds of those battles could be heard in the city center. There also was fighting in Paynesville suburb, within eight miles of Doe's fortified Israeli-built executive mansion. The mansion overlooks the Atlantic ocean. Western military sources said rebels who surrounded the city's landward sides Monday had not advanced. It was unclear whether the rebels were regrouping, or if they were awaiting reinforcements. Soldiers sent to put down the rebellion have turned on civilians from the Gio and Mano tribes _ to which many rebels belong _ pillaging homes, killing and raping. Rebels have retaliated by killing Krahns and those of the wealthier tribe of Mandingos, accused of supporting Doe. Diplomats said that at the country's Coca Cola factory on the outskirts of the Paynesville suburb, rebels who advanced past the bottling plant Tuesday were hunting for Mandingos and Krahns. The same thing happened at the U.S. government's Omega tracking station _ one of only seven of its kind in the world _ just north of Paynesville. Diplomats said rebels demanded that staff at the station hand over Mandingos and Krahns, but went away when they refused. A statement from the diplomatic corps demanded that the government halt further abuses of human rights, cease the murder of innocent civilians, and end army harassment of refugees at the centers. Unruly troops, many drunken or drugged, looted several shops Monday night under cover of a dusk-to-dawn curfew, shopkeepers said. On Tuesday, they terrorized the city, shooting from commandeered cars and extorting money from passers-by. In 1980, Doe led a coup that toppled elitist descendants of the freed American slaves who established an independent Liberia in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Rifle in Assassination Reported Traced to Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 6th, `Israeli Embassy ...' to include more background on Israeli position.
DOC.TEXT: An assault rifle seized in the arrest of four suspected assassins of a Colombian presidential candidate has been traced by U.S. authorities to an Israeli arms shipment, New York Newsday reported today. The Galil rifle is not believed to be the actual murder weapon in the Aug. 18 assassination, allegedly by drug traffickers, of Luis Carlos Galan, the newspaper said. Newsday said the weapon was one of several firearms and explosives discovered by Colombian authorities in two Bogota safehouses when they arrested the suspected assassins Sept. 21. The newspaper quoted Jack Killorin, a spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, as saying the rifle had been part of an Israeli arms shipment purportedly destined for the defense force of the island of Antigua. Published reports have said Galan was believed to have been killed by a machine pistol but that rifles were fired as a diversion, Newsday said. Israeli Embassy press attache Ruth Yaron in Washington did not return repeated phone calls from Newsday. Israeli officials have repeatedly said the weapons shipment to Antigua was completely proper and that they had no idea of plans to divert the guns to other countries. Israel has maintained it does not know how the weapons from the shipment of 500 Galil rifles and Uzi machine pistols ended up in the hands of the late Colombian drug boss Jose Rodriguez Gacha. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., chairman of a Senate narcotics subcommittee, said the new disclosure was disturbing, and he called for an investigation. The Galan assassination prompted a government crackdown on Colombia's drug barons and set off a wave of terrorism. Colombia has previously claimed that a group of Israeli reserve officers led by Lt. Col. Yair Klein trained and armed Gacha's forces. Colombia said Gacha's forces then launched a campaign of terror against the government.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Allies Giving Good Reception to His Proposals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Bush comments on aid to the Soviet Union; picks up 2nd graf pvs, bgng: While on ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he would look more favorably on western economic aid to the Soviet Union if Moscow would devote less money to defense spending. ``I hope that given the changes in the world they'll be able to curtail that defense spending some,'' Bush said hours before he was to leave for a meeting in London with NATO allies. ``If they do, I think it will be much easier for the west to give them certain kinds of economic assistance. It will be a very good thing,'' the president told reporters. Bush was asked about comments by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze that Moscow was devoting too much of its national spending to defense. Some European nations have indicated they want to send a western aid package to help the Soviets' struggling economy. Bush said he doesn't mind if other nations want to do that, but he is not interested in contributing until the Soviets show evidence of economic reform and stop aiding Marxist Cuba. While on a six-day vacation at his seaside home, Bush has been talking by telephone with world leaders and consulting with top advisers in advance of the Thursday-Friday summit. He spoke with the prime ministers of Denmark, Belgium and the Netherlands on Tuesday before capping his day by viewing early Fourth of July fireworks from the deck of the Coast Guard training barque Eagle. The president is taking to London a series of proposals dealing with how to restructure the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the face of the declining threat from the Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies. In a letter to NATO members, Bush proposed abandoning a flexible-use strategy for the alliance's nuclear defense in light of expected Soviet troop withdrawals from the traditional border front lines of confrontation, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft said. Officials have said Bush is proposing use of nuclear weapons only as a last resort, contrary to NATO's basic doctrine since 1967 holding that nuclear weapons use would not be ruled out if the allies were confronted with an invasion by superior conventional forces. Bush did not directly confirm that, but he told reporters, ``The general approach that we're proposing seems to be getting wide acceptance.'' Scowcroft said the proposals are not ``bombshells, but they are significant because this is a significant time.'' He said the United States already has gotten favorable reactions from five or six of the 15 other NATO allies. The national security adviser told a news briefing that the summit will focus on adapting the Western alliance to ``the changing security environment in Europe,'' including ``the collapse ... of the Warsaw Pact, the changes in Eastern Europe (and) the turmoil that's going on in the Soviet Union.'' ``No longer will there be ... armies facing each other directly across a boundary,'' Scowcroft said. ``It's a very different matter to attack a few hundred yards across a border than it is to move forces up several hundred miles into Eastern Europe to be prepared for an attack.'' ``One has to look at the issues of forward defense, flexible response, all the kinds of strategies that NATO pursues now to see how they might be modified to fit those new circumstances,'' Scowcroft said. The administration is anxious to assure the Soviet Union that NATO, particularly with a unified Germany as a member, will not be a threat. In addition to agreeing to use nuclear weapons only as a last resort, administration officials say Bush is suggesting that NATO eventually scrap the 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells now based mostly in West Germany, reduce or eliminate an arsenal of 1,560 U.S. nuclear bombs deployed in seven NATO countries and pull back troops from forward deployment. Today, the president ventured out on a rainy morning to get in a round of golf and show off the self-inflicted wound he got on Monday while cleaning fish. For curious reporters, the president peeled back the bandage on his right hand so they could see the cut. He said he caught 10 fish. Bush wraps up his seaside holiday tonight and heads directly to London. At the end of the week he will fly to Houston for the economic summit of seven industrialized nations. There, he said, trade and agriculture issues will be high on the agenda.

DOC.HEAD: Holy Mako!: 710-Pounder Caught Off Long Island
DOC.TEXT: A fisherman plans to make steaks with the 710-pound mako shark he caught off Long Island, a marina spokeswoman said. Ray Benza of Yorktown Heights caught the shark Tuesday afternoon with a rod-and-reel on a charter boat in the Atlantic, 30 miles south of Montauk. It was the largest of its kind seen in years in the area. Rusty Botta, a Montauk Marine Basin spokeswoman, said biologists plan to study the female shark before it is eaten. The mako is a dangerous shark that looks similar to the great white shark in the movie ``Jaws,'' said Mike Leech, a spokesman for the International Game Fish Association in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. A mako has sharper, more pointed teeth. Botta said it took two hours to bring fish to the boat, and four hours to secure it. ``A shark is like a rattler,'' she said. ``You may think it's dead, but they don't die easily, so all precuations are taken.'' Leech said that the rod-and-reel record for a mako shark is 1,080 pounds caught off Montauk on Aug. 26, 1979. Botta said a great white shark weighing more than 2,000 pounds was caught off Long Island a few years ago. In a Montauk shark contest two weeks ago, the largest mako caught weighed 155 pounds and the winner made $15,000.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0637 (or leads a0659, a0712), AM-Racial Attack, sent July 3 under a New York dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously Tuesday that John Vento, a defendant in the Bensonhurst killing of Yusuf Hawkins, had been acquitted of five counts of discrimination. Vento was charged with only four counts of discrimination and was acquitted on all four.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Archivist Changes Mind on Retirement
DOC.TEXT: The city archivist has retired after 27 years but won't leave because she hasn't been told who will replace her. Gladys Hansen's last official day was Saturday, but the 65-year-old plans to stay on by returning her first retirement check. ``I won't retire if I feel this is all in jeopardy,'' she said Tuesday, gesturing to the collections she has helped amass over the years. ``Unless I know who is going to take over and what is going to happen to the collection and the staff, I won't retire. City Librarian Kenneth Dowlin, who has been Hansen's boss for three years, said, ``Gladys seems to be holding us hostage until we do things her way.'' City law requires Dowlin, 49, to wait until Hansen's vacation time and sick leave are expended before advertising for a new archivist _ about six months from now. He said he plans to lovingly care for the collection after Hansen is off the job, but probably will modernize, automate and expand the archives. ``She has been working for decades on that collection and feels very possessive about it, but she should be reminded it is not hers; it belongs to the city,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Flood, Typhoon Kills At Least 31 in Two Provinces
DOC.TEXT: Torential rains and a typhoon in two provinces have left at least 31 people dead in recent days, according to news reports Wednesday. In Hunan, 22 people died in several days of rains and flooding, the official People's Daily said. The rainstorms, which ended Monday, also brought down 4,430 buildings and flooded 271,700 acres of farmland, the paper said. In Fujian, the second typhoon in a week left nine people dead and about 100 injured. More than 6,650 buildings collapsed, 107,086 acres of cropland was flooded and fishing boats, roads and communications facilities were damaged. The typhoon hit Fujian last Friday, just days after Typhoon Ofelia, which left at least 10 people dead.

DOC.HEAD: Queen's Favorite Horse Dies
DOC.TEXT: Burmese, familiar to millions as Queen Elizabeth II's favorite ceremonial horse, died after suffering a stroke, Buckingham Palace said Wednesday. The horse was 28. The jet black mare, ridden by the monarch in 18 Trooping the Color ceremonies, died Tuesday at Windsor Palace, 22 miles west of London, and will be buried in adjacent Windsor Home Park, the palace said. Burmese was given to the queen by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in 1969, and was featured in a postcard with the queen riding side-saddle in a scarlet Guards uniform. The horse was retired from ceremonial duties in 1986, and the queen switched to a horse-drawn carriage for Trooping the Color, the annual military pageant marking her birthday. When the mare was retired, trainer Sylvia Stanier said the queen had a rapport with Burmese and was ``hesitant to start on another horse.'' Burmese worked for the police until 1988 when she was put out to pasture in Windsor Home Park.

DOC.HEAD: Heroic Underground Driver Awarded Damages
DOC.TEXT: The High Court on Wednesday awarded a London Underground train conductor $15,500 for psychological stress suffered during the 1987 King's Cross subway station fire. Arthur Barrett was commended for bravery after he disobeyed orders not to stop his train at the burning station. Thirty-one people were killed and 80 injured in the Nov. 18, 1987, fire at London's busiest subway station. The 41-year-old motorman stopped his train and picked up between 150 and 200 passengers stranded on the platform. High Court Justice Nicholas Phillips said Barrett had acted with ``great clear-headedness and courage'' by evacuating passengers during the height of the fire. Barrett said he suffered terrible nightmares about the blaze. He said he was still anxious and obsessed with safety and feared a possible recurrence of the disaster. Andrew Dismore, Barrett's lawyer, said his client would continue with his job. Of the 100 claims arising from the disaster, Dismore said there were still ``many dozens'' outstanding.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Passenger Train Accident
DOC.TEXT: A steel beam carried by a freight train slashed through a car of a passenger train traveling in the opposite direction, killing six people and injuring eight, a state railway spokesman said Wednesday. The beam sliced through the car ``like a knife through butter,'' said Jose Luis Sanchez, the spokesman. The accident late Tuesday east of Madrid occurred as the two trains passed on close rails. The beam, destined for a construction site, killed two rail company employees and four Spanish passengers on the inter-city express train bound for Madrid from northern Zaragoza, he said. The freight train was traveling from Madrid to northeastern Granollers. There were 30 passengers in the passenger car, Sanchez said. Six of the injured were treated at a hospital and released. One woman was hospitalized with a fractured skull, and a man, with serious chest injuries, Sanchez said. It was not immediately clear what caused the steel beam to break loose.

DOC.HEAD: Ordinance Restricting Chlorofluorocarbons Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: Businesses that use ozone-destroying chemicals in this city known for its high-tech industries could face fines of up to $500 a day and six-month jail terms for their officers under a new law. But many companies in this city of 90,000 people about 40 miles south of Los Angeles may avoid the restrictions. ``I'm expecting a fair number of exemptions, at least in this first year,'' Michael Brown, the city's environmental coordinator, said Tuesday. City officials hailed the measure as a local solution to a global problem when the City Council approved it last summer. The law went into effect Sunday. It prohibits companies from using or selling chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, and other chemicals that destroy ozone gas in the stratosphere about 30 to 50 miles above the Earth's surface. Ozone filters out ultraviolet radiation, which can damage the human immune system, cause skin cancer and cataracts, harm crops and disrupt sea life. Scientists say restoring the ozone layer will require worldwide controls, and 56 nations last week signed an agreement to ban some chemicals and set up a $240 million international fund through which industrialized nations can help developing countries adopt environmentally safer technology. In the United States, some states and localities have been in the forefront on ozone protection. The Connecticut General Assembly last year banned the sale of freon in small containers to individuals for recharging refrigerators and car and home air conditioners. But licensed repair people still can buy them. Similar legislation is pending in Massachusetts. More than a dozen counties and cities, including Irvine, have enacted ordinances curtailing polystyrene in such uses as fast-food coffee cups and hamburger boxes. Since industry has modified its plastics-making process to use a much less ozone-depleting form of CFCs, the primary benefit of these laws now is to keep landfills from overflowing. Irvine officials have yet to determine which companies are using CFCs and related chemicals that commonly serve as refrigerants and industrial solvents and are used in the manufacture of insulation, foam and plastic food containers. ``Our best guess was that 200 to 300 were using CFCs,'' Brown said. He estimated that as many as 100 will be granted exemptions because they have no alternative. Some, such as Hughes Corp.'s Industrial Electronics Group division, are legally bound to use solvents specified by contracts with the government. Companies that use solvents to make medical devices are similarly bound by U.S. Food and Drug Administration rules that certify a specific manufacturing process. Even if companies are granted an exemption, Brown said he has told them, ```We want you to reduce your use and emissions as much as you can.''' Some businesses, such as Calsonic Climate Control Inc., have installed equipment that recovers and recycles coolants for manufacturing automobile air conditioners, Brown said. ``They've done a lot to reduce their use,'' Brown said.
Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

June 28 The Greenville (S.C.) News on the savings and loan collapse: With great fanfare President Bush last week made public a series of steps his administration will take to get tougher with criminals behind the financial collapse of hundreds of savings and loans institutions. Federal prosecutors will get more money, manpower and legal authority to investigate and prosecute suspected cases of fraud, the president said, and ``We will not rest until the cheats and chiselers and charlatans have spent a large chunk of their lives behind the bars of a federal prison.'' To a large degree Bush was responding to the politics of the crisis. Democrats in Congress have become strident in their criticism of his anti-fraud efforts, and he has traded shots with them. Against this backdrop, the new initiative and the ``we will not rest'' rhetoric ought to play well with a public that indeed is suspicious of the overall thrift industry rescue program. Now, most should be mollified as long as no one expects too much. Estimates of the cost of restructuring the thrift industry range as high as $500 billion, and most of that money is going to come from taxpayers. ... Investigators no doubt need more resources. FBI field offices last year asked for 425 new agents; they got 202. The U.S. attorney in Oklahoma has only five lawyers assigned to 40 investigations in Oklahoma City. Bush's proposal to boost spending on fraud investigations to $100 million annually is in order. But no one should expect an early or less costly rescue.
July 2

The Jersey Journal of Jersey City, N.J., on U.S. Supreme Court ruling against political patronage: Whatever its merits as constitutional law, the Supreme Court decision undercutting the validity of hiring and firing based on political patronage has the potential to perform a valuable service. Patronage has had as damaging an impact in Hudson County as anywhere in America. Hiring rank-and-file workers on the basis of political support or political activity severs the link between the individual's success in remaining employed, getting promoted and getting favorable assignments and his or her performance on the job. Too many politicians have a vested interest in creating the jobs people want, rather than the jobs people need. The public, especially in Hudson County, will be well served if reducing patronage produces more emphasis on doing the job well and less on serving the political ambitions of politicians and their partisan supporters.

June 29 The News-Review (Roseburg, Ore.) on math code: The fact that a team of mathematicians has succeeded in splitting a 155-digit number into its three prime factors is hardly the sort of news that has most people gripping the edges of their chairs. Nevertheless, in the cryptologist's arcane world of espionage and secret messages, it is a major triumph. Only a year ago the feat seemed utterly impossible. But researchers Hendrik Lenstra of the University of California at Berkeley, and John Pollard of Reading, England, have come close to confirming Edgar Allen Poe's famous dictum that human ingenuity cannot concoct a cipher which human ingenuity cannot resolve. But what practical effect does this mathematical discovery have on the man in the street? Perhaps more than he realizes. Bankers use these large code numbers to move funds electronically. Phone companies use them to ensure privacy. The Defense Department relies on them for security. And governments use them to transmit secret intelligence. Breaking other nations' codes produces more and better information than all the world's spies put together. ... No matter how good we become at solving codes, military and diplomatic intelligence will always need to be backed up by another form of intelligence. As the latest team of mathematicians has just shown, there simply is no replacement for human ingenuity.

June 28 Corpus Christi (Texas) Caller-Times on President Bush and taxes: That runaway federal deficit is finally going to get the serious attention it deserves. President Bush is abandoning his ``read my lips, no new taxes'' pledge that figured so prominently in his election and has been the capstone of his administration's budget policies. But too much should not be made of Bush's turnaround. It may sound cynical, but politics is one thing (the ``read my lips'' was pure politics) and responsible governing is another. It certainly is in this case. Since he made so much of saying never, never, never, it took a considerable amount of courage for Bush to change his position. ... But the deficit is soaring ... All this makes it an urgent priority to consider tax-raising options, promises or no. Bush's statement outlined the following package: entitlement and mandatory program reform, tax-revenue increases, growth incentives, orderly reductions in defense expenditures and budget-process reform. This package of proposals by President Bush will bring the budget summiteers back to the negotiating table. And if Bush's change of heart leads to a sensible plan to reduce the federal deficit, it can hardly be called dumb. It shows that Bush, after two years of posturing on the issue, is finally taking a straightforward approach. Neither the Democrats nor the hard-liners in his own party should try to exploit this politically.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: this politically.''
DOC.TEXT: June 27 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on censorship: Broward County does it again. After arresting the band members of 2 Live Crew for obscenity, the ignorant people of this southern Florida county managed to find the devil in a geography lesson. ... It seems that two of these churchgoers named Kevin and Renee Bryan got hold of the script of a play their daughter Tiffany was in at school called ``In Quest of the Banjo Man.'' The play is really about brotherhood, global understanding of ethnic differences and a healthy dose of geography. What these paranoid little Bryans saw was devil worship. ... That they could convince the Wilton Manors school administration that they were right and to put pressure on the principal, one Linda Marable, to scrap the play is a tragic breakdown in human relations and a disgusting commentary on personal integrity. ... The cowardice and foolishness of the school administration allowed the ignorance of one pair of wackos to reign supreme over a beautiful project.

July 2 Milwaukee Sentinel on NASA's Hubble trouble: A lot of travelers have known the disappointment of going on vacation only to find their camera is on the fritz. But just imagine how the people who put up the Hubble telescope must feel. A problem with the light-gathering mirrors has partially distorted the $1.5 billion eye in the sky, virtually eliminating its ability to single out dim and distant objects in space. Spokesmen for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration say other functions of the Hubble that are operating properly still justify the scientific mission of the venture. But a probe of the problem should focus on how in the world the craft got off the ground with equipment that was not in tip-top shape. Perhaps an investigation will show that there was no way of catching the defect. One person connected with the project already has said that the kind of testing necessary to spot it would have cost hundreds of millions of dollars. But the project was 12 years in the making and experienced several delays. And it is not enough to say that lack of money was the reason for the malfunction of a camera that was supposed to perform 40 percent of the craft's scientific work. One report is that one of two precisely ground mirrors was not made to specification and the suggestion is that the problem was with the manufacturer. But the public _ whose support for the project was sustained, in part, by the promise of pictures of never-before-seen stars _ deserves a thorough explanation. The hope, of course, is that some of the lost capability of the Hubble will be recaptured when a space shuttle team goes up to service the craft in April 1993, or, given the new problem, maybe sooner. Before they take off, a double check should be made to make sure they have all the right tools along. The history of the Hubble is such that nothing can be taken for granted.

June 30 El Paso (Texas) Herald-Post on drunken driving checkpoints: The key word in the Bill of Rights' protection against government harassment of individuals is ``unreasonable.'' We suspect most Americans agree with the Supreme Court's recent ruling that police checkpoints are a reasonable means of combating drunken driving. Interestingly, our notion of what is unreasonable is sometimes irrational. No Fourth Amendment challenge to electronic security checks at airports has reached the high court, yet attacks on planes take infinitely fewer lives than drunken driving. And airport security often involves more waiting than sobriety checkpoints along the road. The effectiveness of checkpoints resides largely in deterrence. The number of people who refrain from driving under the influence because of a checkpoint cannot be known. Organizations such as Mothers Against Drunk Driving have worked hard to raise the awareness of the routine cost of driving under the influence. If they keep it up, maybe 23,000 deaths in a year will come to be seen as the scandal it is and more communities will crack down. Sobriety checkpoints should be among a community's options.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: community's options.
DOC.TEXT: June 28 Jeune Afrique, Paris, on press freedom: What is the African country where the press is the most free? No, it's not Senegal. It's South Africa. Shame on us. What is the Middle Eastern country where the press is the most free. This time you've guessed it. Yes, it's Israel. Shame on us. Oh, I know very well that South Africa is ruled by a minority based on color, that Israel is based on religion, and that freedom of the press in these two countries benefits foremost the ruling class. But, believe me, in each of these countries, the oppressed also benefit from the free circulation of information and ideas. Meanwhile, in our countries, the non-freedom of the press doesn't serve anybody. Not even the true interests of those who govern and find it convenient to hide behind the veil of secrecy.

June 28 The Straits Times, Singapore, on developments in Poland: If Poland is the first wave of democracy to reach East Europe's shores, then Mr. Lech Walesa is the triumphant leader riding on its crest. For bringing about that transformation, history has already reserved a page for the Solidarity leader. ... Mr. Walesa's underdog, anti-establishment and street-fighter style may have been just the thing to unseat the communists. But to continue with the same style now may serve his country no good. Having won the right to dissent, Poland, ironically, now needs a unity of purpose rather than a babble of voices to face an uncertain future. ... But perhaps it is unrealistic to expect Solidarity to remain in solidarity for long. The union is, in truth, a protest movement, an anti-communist platform of diverse parts. With the disappearance of the common enemy, the true colors of the intellectual, worker, peasant and other components of the movement are showing through. The mass defection of the intellectuals from Solidarity's fold is a sign that Mr. Walesa is increasingly speaking more for a section within it than the whole movement. ...

June 29 Helsingin Sanomat, Helsinki, Finland, on recent Soviet hijackings to Scandinavia: The lawyer of one Soviet hijacker (being held by Finnish police) said it was unprecedented that (Finland's) Prime Minister Harri Holkeri described the hijacking as a heinous crime and a serious violation against Finland before the court case began. Holkeri's statement was a necessary political assurance that Finland will ... act in accordance with international agreements. One such agreement is between Finland and the Soviet Union on the return of hijackers to their country of origin. The statement also was undoubtedly meant as a signal and a warning to potential future hijackers in the Soviet Union.

July 2 The Times, London, on Berlin as the German capital: The military governments of the Four Powers in Berlin will soon be packing their bags. West German capitalists, civil servants and politicians are poised to take their place. ... Berlin was not exclusively the odious stronghold of Prussian militarism, overweening imperial ambition and Nazi fanaticism depicted by Allied propaganda. On the contrary: it was once no less the cosmopolitan home of high culture and high finance, of plebian humor and ethnic diversity. Germany's division cannot be healed only by the spending of wealth ... Berlin has a vital role to play as the place in which the severed parts first coalesced. It will doubtless be the popular choice as capital. But the functions of government are not indivisible. Bonn could well be allowed to retain some of its present institutions, even if the Bundestag and other organs of state were moved to Berlin.

July 2 The Berlingske Tidende, Copenhagen, Denmark, on opening of Communist Party congress in Moscow: President Gorbachev once had the ability to turn defeat into victory and end up on top in difficult situations. There are strong indications that his old winning streak is about to end. The Russian people have become impatient waiting for better results from perestroika, and opposition forces on the right and the left in the party have weakened his position as general secretary before he has had time to consolidate his new power as state president.

June 27 Dagens Nyheter, Stockholm, Sweden on Western assistance to Iran: There is no reason why foreign interests should exploit the rift in the structure of Iranian society caused by the earthquake by kindling internal confrontation. The risk is then a return to old ways. The wish by states which are providing assistance to score quick political points should be sacrificed for the inevitable process that surely will change Iran in a more sweeping way. The Iranian leaders are being forced to have what they had feared and tried to prevent -- cooperation and contacts with other countries.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Jilted Student Sues, Wins Case Against Date
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager whose date to the prom stood her up got a date in court instead and was awarded $79.50 to cover her costs. ``In the future, I will only ask someone who I can trust,'' Dana Jurist said Tuesday. Miss Jurist, who attends Downingtown Senior High School outside Philadelphia, said Shawn Norbeck agreed to accompany her to the junior prom in May after she mentioned she didn't have a date. She said she had known Norbeck about five months through their jobs at a supermarket. He had graduated from high school four years earlier. Miss Jurist said Norbeck's mother told him he had a virus on prom day, but a friend of his said he actually was going to a rock concert by the group Rush. Norbeck's family said he would have no comment. In his June 28 decision, District Justice Harry J. Martini refused to award Miss Jurist compensation for a $235 dress she bought because she got to wear it to the senior prom a week later.

DOC.HEAD: Pilgrims Wind Up Rituals, Iran Accuses Saudis of Incompetence
With AM-Mecca-Reconstruct, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims wound up their rituals at Islam's holiest sites Wednesday while the Moslem world mourned the deaths of 1,426 people in the worst pilgrimage tragedy in modern history. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said the tragedy proved the Saudi royal family is incompetent to administer Islam's holiest shrines. Rafsanjani's harsh remarks ended hopes that relations might improve after the generous relief supplies Saudi Arabia sent to Iranian earthquake victims. Most pilgrims were leaving the plains of Mina by sunset Wednesday and heading for Mecca to make a farewell circle of the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine to which Moslems turn five times in daily prayer. Part of the day's rituals also included the ``stoning of the devil'' for a third time at Gamarat Aqabah, the site where the pilgrims were headed when the tragic stampede occurred Monday. Saudi authorities were setting up a large area at the holy sites for graves for those victims whose families wanted them to be buried at Mecca. In the Islamic faith, to die and be buried in Mecca is a blessing. Saudi officials said the tragedy in the Mo'essem tunnel began when a railing on a pedestrian bridge over the tunnel bent, sending seven pilgrims tumbling to their deaths on top of people coming out of the tunnel. The bodies crashing into the throng touched off panic. Only those at the entrance to the tunnel knew what had happened. Behind them, pilgrims continued to move inside. The 1,000-capacity tunnel filled with an estimated 50,000 pushing, shoving pilgrims. Many died in the frantic stampede. Others died when the ventilation system in the 600-yard-long, 35-foot-wide tunnel stopped, inexplicably. The accident, which happened on the first day of the Eid al-Adha or Feast of Sacrifice, was described by King Fahd as ``the will of God.'' Hospital sources in Jiddah said the victims included Arabs, Indonesians, Malaysians, Turks, Pakistanis and Indians as well as Saudis. ``It was fate,'' Fahd said. ``Had they not died there, they would have died elsewhere and at the same predestined moment.'' ``Throughout the world accidents suddenly happen _ planes crash, buildings collapse, trains collide,'' he said. He referred to the recent earthquake in Iran, where at least 40,000 died. ``The earthquake in the Moslem state of Iran: Could anyone stop that? Can anyone stop death? It is God's will above all.'' Fahd's comments on state-run television came as Saudi Arabia, which has spent billions of dollars to maintain and upgrade the holy sites, faced criticism from the Islamic world _ most of all from its arch-rivals in Iran. Rafsanjani, in an interview with the official Islamic Republic News Agency and Tehran Radio, said it was ``unacceptable'' to liken the events in Mecca to the earthquake that struck Iran last month. ``Those officials responsible for administering the holy sanctuaries and the Saudi rulers should be answerable to the Islamic world,'' he said. ``From such incidents it is clear that the level of the security of the pilgrims in Saudi Arabia should be increased.'' Three Iranian newspapers also blamed the Saudi ruling family. Saudi Arabia severed relations with Tehran in April 1988, after accusing the Iranian leadership of terrorism and subversion. Islamic leaders, from those in neighboring Persian Gulf countries to leading Moslem nations such as Pakistan, were quickly closing ranks with the Saudi monarch, sending messages of condolence saying the tragedy was an act of God. The tunnel was built as part of a $15-billion development project launched by the government at the holy sites two years ago. With these renovation schemes, Saudi Arabia secured Moslem world backing in 1988 to limit the numbers of pilgrims to 1,000 per million in each country because of the ongoing work. The Iranians, who considered the limit directed against them, have boycotted the annual pilgrimage season for the three years since. Iranian activists or pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems have spread terrorism at the annual hajj since 1986, when security men found large quantities of explosives during the pilgrimage. The following year, Saudi riot police clashed with pilgrims, who defied a government ban on political rallies during the religious event. More than 400 people, mostly Iranians, were killed. Last year, one pilgrim was killed and 16 were wounded in two bombs explosions. Sixteen people, tried and convicted of the attacks, were beheaded by the Saudi government.

DOC.HEAD: Hydroelectric Generator Heading to Michigan Museum
DOC.TEXT: Walls of a hydroelectric powerhouse are being knocked out this week so a turn-of-the century turbine and generator can be removed for display at the Henry Ford Museum. It will join a ``Made in America'' exhibit opening in fall 1992 at the museum in Dearborn, Mich. Curator John Bowditch said an advertisement for the machinery in this spring's newsletter of the Society for Industrial Archaeology caught his eye. Earlier this week, he was in Spokane to examine the turbine and generator. ``I am very happy to be able the save them because equipment of this nature almost inevitably ends up in a scrap heap,'' Bowditch said. Washington Water Power Co. is donating the machines to the museum as a result of a $26 million upgrade. The generator was installed in 1903 below the city's most prominent waterfall on the Spokane River.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Battle Army's Example of How Not to Fight A War
DOC.TEXT: The Army's Task Force Smith peered through a steady rainfall on the morning of July 5, 1950, and saw 33 oncoming Soviet-made tanks and thousands of North Korean infantrymen. The unit had just six artillery shells powerful enough to penetrate heavy tank armor. Their bloody, seven-hour rout is held up by the Army 40 years later as an example of how not to fight a war. Task Force Smith's defeat is an object lesson for the 1990s, declares Gen. Carl E. Vuono, the Army chief of staff. He says the army of 1950 was fractured by the rapid demobilization and meager budgets that followed the World War II. Vuono says he fears that could repeat itself as the Cold War recedes and political and budget pressures build to rapidly cut military spending. The survivors of the ill-equipped Task Force Smith units are convening for a reunion in nearby Alexandria, Va., Thursday, proud of their fight, but resentful of the government-created obstacles they faced. ``The lesson from Task Force Smith is that there is a need for a trained and ready army in times of peace, especially when the army is small,'' Gen. Vuono said. Named for its commander, Lt.Col. Charles Bradford Smith, Task Force Smith was hastily stitched together from infantry and artillery units after North Korea struck across the 38th parallel on June 25. On the morning of July 5, with North Korean troops already in the South Korean capital of Seoul, Task Force Smith was dug in on a ridge commanding a highway and railway line about 22 miles south of Seoul. The first U.S. combat unit to go into action in Korea, Task Force Smith had problems: Weapons that didn't work, inoperable radios, no air support, no resupply and no maps to lead troops to safety once the situation fell apart. ``We found out we didn't have any weapons that could penetrate the armor on the tanks,'' says William Wyrick, 65, a retired Army colonel who was then a young first lieutenant leading a platoon. The unit's high-explosive, antitank or HEAT rounds, represented one third of the armor piercing ammunition available in depots in Japan. Those six rounds ``killed two tanks,'' Wyrick said, in an telephone interview from his home in Columbia, S.C. But less powerful artillery shells simply bounced off the armor or didn't explode at all. ``All we could do was scratch the tanks and annoy the gunners,'' said Carl Bernard, another retired Army colonel who was a platoon leader with Task Force Smith. ``If we had been able to stop the tanks, we would have been in a totally different world,'' Bernard said. ``The vast majority of the weapons we carried into that fight had been declared combat unserviceable,'' Wyrick said. ``Our vehicles were worn out. Our radios didn't work because the batteries were corroded.'' The North Korean tanks sliced through Task Force Smith during the first hour of fighting and continued their drive south. Elements of the North Korean infantry, crowded into a column of trucks that some accounts say formed a six-mile-long line, attacked the U.S. positions. They were twice driven back, Wyrick said. ``But by 2:30 in the afternoon we were running out of ammunition,'' he said. ``They were enveloping our flank and Col. Smith gave the order to withdraw.'' Bernard never got the word and learned of the move only after a runner found the command post abandoned. ``The withdrawal immediately became ragged and chaotic,'' says author T.R. Fehrenbach in his 1989 account of the Korean War, ``This Kind of War, A Study in Unpreparedness.'' ``At close range, automatic weapons chewed the retreating Americans, breaking them up into small, disorganized units,'' Fehrenbach wrote. ``They left their dead where they lay, and abandoned the 30 or so wounded who were too hurt to walk.'' Of the more than 400 men who went into action with Task Force Smith, some 150 did not return. ``We had no medical evacuation, no resupply of food or ammunition,'' Wyrick said. ``It was especially difficult because no one had a map. The officers had only a general idea of where we were.'' The two former lieutenants say their men lacked little in the way of fighting spirit but simply didn't have the resources to do the job. ``I don't object to the way we fought; I object to the result,'' Bernard said. ``We didn't get anything like what we should have gotten.''

DOC.HEAD: Panama Orders Cuba to Reduce Embassy Staff
DOC.TEXT: The government that was installed in Panama during the U.S. invasion today accused Cuba of ``hostile conduct'' and gave the Cuban Embassy 10 days to reduce its staff to four members. A Foreign Ministry communique said all personnel other than the charge d'affaires, the commercial and economic attaches and the consul must leave the country. The statement did not give the current size of the embassy staff. The embassy has been a strong critic of President Guillermo Endara since he was installed during the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that deposed Manuel Antonio Noriega and brought him to the United States to face federal drug charges. Noriega's wife and daughters and some other Noriega associates took refuge at the embassy after the invasion. Some of them later traveled to Cuba, but former Noriega legislator Luis Gomez remains in the embassy. The communique mentioned two instances in which the Cuban government questioned the legitimacy of the Panamanian government or its leaders. The statement also referred to a series of unspecified incidents in which the Cuban government exhibited ``hostile conduct'' toward the Panamanian government.

DOC.HEAD: Relationship Between U.S., Laos Improving, Officials Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0520 to fix category code
DOC.TEXT: The United States is quietly improving relations with Laos as that nation's communist government shifts from state control of the economy and works to attract foreign private investment, officials say. The two nations are expanding joint efforts to combat drug smuggling and discussing the possibility of sending Peace Corps volunteers to the Southeast Asian nation, officials say. Laos, along with Vietnam and Cambodia, came under communist rule in 1975. It was the only one of the three countries with which the U.S. maintained diplomatic ties and with which there appears to be tangible progress toward friendly relations. Two decades ago, U.S. warplanes bombed Laos for years in a failed effort to wipe out a communist insurgency. But the rebels seized power within weeks after communist triumphs in Vietnam and Cambodia. Talks on sending Peace Corps volunteers are still in the preliminary stage, U.S. officials say, with the focus on the type of experts the agency could send to Laos. The Peace Corps has never sent volunteers to a communist country although discussions had been held with China before Sino-American relations soured last year. Last fall, the United States and Laos agreed on a development aid project, the first anywhere in Indochina in 15 years. The $8.7 million effort is aimed at persuading farmers in northeast Laos to cultivate crops other than opium. Linked to that project was an agreement signed last January in which Laos promised a ``maximum effort'' to halt the cultivation and trafficking of opium. Laos also has been more cooperative in helping the U.S. government obtain an accounting for American servicemen killed there during the Vietnam war. The collaboration has included inspections in remote areas by teams of Laotians and Americans and visits to sites where U.S. war planes crashed. In addition, Laos has lifted restrictions on travel by U.S. diplomats in its capital of Vientiane and on the number of Americans authorized to serve there. The two countries have not exchanged ambassadors since the communist victory, but discussions on a possible exchange have begun, U.S. officials said. ``The whole dialogue has improved,'' said one U.S. official, who insisted that he not be identified. The conciliation effort has been made easier by a substantial reduction in the number of Vietnamese troops stationed in Laos, which had long been seen as the junior partner in its alliance with Vietnam. U.S. officials estimate there were once as many as 40,000 to 50,000 Vietnamese troops in Laos. Only a handful, at most, remain, they say. Beyond that, Laos has set free virtually all of the several thousand political prisoners confined to labor camps after the communist victory, the officials said. Perhaps the most significant change relates to Laos's effort to revitalize its moribund economy, the officials said. Laos has been selling off state enterprises and moving toward a private economy with a heavy reliance on foreign investment. The shifts began after Laos appeared to be falling increasingly behind the dynamic economies elsewhere in the region, including neighboring Thailand.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Lithuanian Officials Find New Careers as Diplomats to Third World
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former Communist officials of Lithuania who were ousted during the republic's two-year quest for independence have wound up as Soviet diplomats in Africa and Mongolia, a news agency reported Wednesday. Former Lithuanian Prime Minister Vitotas Sokolauskas, who was defeated in the republic's first multicandidate elections for the Soviet parliament last year, is being trained to be a counselor in the Soviet embassy to Mozambique, said the independent news agency Postfactum. The ambassador there is former Lithuanian Communist Party second secretary Nikolai Dibenko, it said. Victor Baltrunas, former ideology chief of the Lithuanian Communist Party, is awaiting appointment as the ambassador to Ivory Coast, while former Lithuanian Foreign Minister Victor Mikuchyauskas is to become ambassador to Sierra Leone, the agency said. Former party ideology official Cheslovas Slizhyus will represent the Soviet Union in Mongolia. Postfactum added that Kazimieras Plekhavicius, the former Minister of Services for the republic, has gone into the business of building horse-drawn carriages.

DOC.HEAD: First Conviction Under Gang Law in Los Angeles County
DOC.TEXT: A man was convicted of first-degree murder and of gang membership in what prosecutors said was the first Los Angeles County conviction under a 2-year-old state law. The anti-gang-membership law can add three years to a prison sentence stemming from a separate felony conviction. Jurors on Tuesday convicted 23-year-old Manuel Madrigal in the slaying of Jimmie Torrez, 16. Sentencing was scheduled for July 23. Prosecutors said only Orange and Riverside counties had won convictions under the law. Past attempts to gain such convictions in Los Angeles County have failed, the District Attorney's office said. Because first-degree murder generally carries a life sentence, the gang law should not affect Madrigal's prison term, said Deputy District Attorney Ed Nison. But the conviction ``gives a strong message that if you're associated with a gang member, you're going to have a stiffer penalty,'' Nison said. Madrigal's attorney, Mel Brown, said he would appeal the conviction. He also insisted his client was not a gang member.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Cast In Middle-Man Role With Kohl and Thatcher
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to delete extraneous `might'
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: As NATO leaders ponder the alliance's future, President Bush is cast somewhere between Margaret Thatcher's cautious approach and Helmut Kohl's pursuit of conciliation with Moscow. The arrangement gives Bush tremendous power to influence the outcome of the two-day strategic review in London. As it is, U.S. presidents, by virtue of America's historic might, tend to dominate such sessions anyhow. Even before the 16 NATO nations assembled in London word leaked out that Bush was willing to consider scrapping 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells and 1,560 U.S. tactical nuclear bombs in light of a diminished Soviet threat and a disintegrating Warsaw Pact. Also, the strategic doctrine that has guided NATO's policies for over four decades was due for an overhaul. Because a blitzkrieg by the Red Army is less likely than ever, the allies are ready to make the use of nuclear weapons an option of last resort. This flips the existing first-use theory upside down to reflect new military realities in Europe. And yet, even though Bush sent letters to the other leaders before the summit, outlining his proposals, there was a lot of room left for debate and for decision in London. ``This is not a pre-cooked summit meeting,'' a U.S. official said. ``That wouldn't bring about the best results.'' When the debate breaks out _ circumspectly behind closed doors _ it is quite likely that Mrs. Thatcher, Britain's prime minister, will make the argument for keeping NATO's guard up. It is equally likely that Kohl, the chancellor of West Germany, will emphasize that the East-West relationship must be sharply changed to reflect the ending of the Cold War. ``Communism has crumbled. It has lost all credibility, even among nominal believers,'' Mrs. Thatcher told the NATO foreign ministers at a pre-summit session June 7 in Turnberry, Scotland. And yet, she said, Europe's future is bound to be turbulent and uncertain. ``We must keep our capacity effectively to deter and to defend ourselves,'' she said. ``You don't cancel your home insurance policy just because there have been fewer burglaries in your street in the last 12 months.'' Of the other NATO leaders, President Francois Mitterrand of France is perhaps most inclined to support Mrs. Thatcher's cautious approach. On the other end of the spectrum is Kohl, backed by a foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who has taken the lead in trying to allay Soviet and Polish concerns about the impending West German absorption of East Germany. These assurances include a pledge not to develop German nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, permitting the Red Army to remain for a transitional period on what is now East German territory and keeping NATO forces out of that region in the meantime. The Bush administration has endorsed this approach, but steered clear _ so far _ of West Germany's economic inducements to Moscow, including an aid package that might be put together with other West European governments. Bush did say Wednesday, however, he would look more favorably upon western economic aid to Moscow if the Kremlin slashed spending on defense. ``I hope that given the changes in the world they'll be able to curtail that defense spending some,'' he told reporters in Kennebunkport, Maine, his summer vacation retreat, just hours before leaving for London. Gesncher, speaking at a May 27 University of Maryland-European branch commencement, proclaimed that a united Germany will remain in NATO. However, he also said that ``the development of a stability-oriented partnership with the Soviet Union and other European countries is the right perspective for the Atlantic Alliance.'' Genscher is for broadening the role of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE), which deals with military security, economic cooperation and human rights. ``The CSCE process must be intensified and given permanent institutional foundations,'' he said. A new relationship between NATO and the Warsaw Pact must be developed, ``to open up new possibilities for the development of relations with the Soviet Union,'' Genscher said. On the nuclear issue, meanwhile, Kohl and Genscher tend to reflect the anxieties of a German populace faced with the largest concentration of nuclear weapons in the world. This has contributed to West Germany's conciliatory approach perhaps as much as Bonn's eagerness for unification. All these conflicting views and national pressures will be close to the surface at the NATO summit as the alliance begins to change its focus from a military to a political forum. On the one side there is Mrs. Thatcher, adamant that NATO's future role is to remain a defense alliance bolstered with nuclear weapons and U.S. troops. To reinforce this stand, Britain is replacing its aging nuclear weapons with U.S. Trident missiles. ``Sufficient forces and weapons keep us secure, not fine words,'' she said in Turnberry. Chancellor Kohl, meanwhile, agrees that U.S. troops should remain in West Germany. But his government was the principal force within NATO for delaying the deployment of new U.S. short-range nuclear missiles. And in May, Bush scrapped the program for installing new Lances. Which side will Bush come down on in London? Administration officials prefer casting the question differently. ``The United States,'' an official said, ``is trying to provide a pole of consensus around which the alliance can rally.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is the chief diplomatic writer for The Associated Press and will be covering the NATO summit in London.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at the Rapid Movement on Lithuania
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at events in Lithuania since the republic's declaration of independence from Moscow:

March 11 _ The Lithuanian legislature elects the first non-Communist president of a Soviet republic, Vytautas Landsbergis, changes the republic's name and declares independence from Moscow. March 13 _ Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declares Lithuania's move illegal.
March 15 _ Gorbachev, elected the Soviet Union's first executive president, is given authority by the Soviet congress to deal with the dispute with Lithuania.
March 16 _ Gorbachev gives Lithuania three days to begin returning to the Soviet fold. Lithuania rejects his authority. March 21 _ Gorbachev gives Lithuanians seven days to turn in firearms. March 22 _ Soviet armor rumbles through Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, in a show of force. April 18 _ Gorbachev stops shipments of all oil, most natural gas and other raw materials to Lithuania to pressure the republic into rescinding pro- independence laws. April 21 _ Lithuania closes most factories to save fuel and raw materials. May 12 _ The presidents of the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia meet to forge a united front against Moscow to re-establish their independence. May 17 _ Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene meets with Gorbachev, who says Lithuania must suspend its declaration of independence, softening his demand that it be revoked. June 2 _ Lithuania is discussed by Gorbachev and President Bush at their Washington summit. The United States presses for an easing of the Moscow stance. June 12 _ Gorbachev meets with the presidents of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia after weeks of refusing to negotiate with them unless they agreed to abide by the Soviet Constitution. June 13 _ Prunskiene says the Soviet government agrees to restore some fuel and raw materials to Lithuania, easing the embargo. Lithuania had said it was willing to negotiate on rolling back its independence laws. June 16 _ The Lithuanian government proposes that the republic's parliament strike a compromise with the Kremlin and impose a moratorium on its declaration of independence. Soviet authorities begin pumping natural gas to the Azotas fertilizer plant in the city of Jonova. June 26 _ Prunskiene tells parliament that Gorbachev agreed that in return for a moratorium, he would end the economic embargo and begin negotiations that ``will discuss a different status for Lithuania, including as an independent state.'' Gorbachev meets in Moscow with Landsbergis. June 27 _ Landsbergis and Prunskiene meet with Gorbachev in Moscow to ``search for common points of contact,'' a Lithuanian spokesman says. June 29 _ The Lithuanian parliament agrees, on a vote of 69-35, to trade a 100-day moratorium on its independence declaration for an end to the economic blockade and negotiations. June 30 _ Oil begins flowing to Lithuania's sole refinery as the Kremlin makes good on its promise to lift the blockade. July 3 _ Natural gas begins flowing back into the republic, according to Arune Kontaugaite of the Lithuanian parliament's information bureau. The Kremlin tells Lithuania it is lifting a 10-week ban on rail deliveries of key foodstuffs, the last remaining economic sanction.

DOC.HEAD: Nationalist Party And Opposition Agree on Presidential Election
DOC.TEXT: The government and opposition defused a constitutional crisis Wednesday and agreed on democratic reforms, including a popular vote for president to end four decades of one-party rule. An opposition leader called the decision a ``peaceful revolution.'' A historic weeklong National Affairs Conference that concluded Wednesday agreed to give more power to native Taiwanese, dominated by the ruling Nationalist Party that retreated to this island from mainland China in 1949. President Lee Teng-hui called the meeting after student protests in March demanded the scrapping of the system that has preserved the Nationalists' lock on power. Opposition politicians had warned there would be violent demonstrations if no reforms were implemented. Lee told the delegates in a closing speech that he would support the recommendations by the 140 delegates, including 80 members of the ruling party and 16 representatives from the Democratic Progressive Party. Independent academics and politicians accounted for the remaining seats. ``This is the time to act,'' Lee said. Many delegates proposed popular presidential elections when Lee's term ends in 1996, but some supported an earlier vote. ``We have just had a peaceful revolution to gain democracy,'' said Chang Chung-hung, secretary-general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. ``We can now organize a new government governed by law rather than by a few people.'' Convention delegates also supported direct election of the mayors of Taiwan's two largest cities, Taipei and Kaohsiung. Currently, those mayors are appointed by the Nationalist government. And delegates ratified an earlier Nationalist proposal to retire by 1991 all 800 elderly members of the lawmaking Legislative Yuan and electoral college from mainland China. A task force of representatives from the major parties will settle remaining differences on the democratic reforms, officials said on condition of anonymity. One unresolved issue is whether the electoral college should be abolished, as the opposition proposes, or transformed into a symbolic institution that would reflect the popular vote but still reserve seats for deputies purportedly representing mainland China. No dramatic progress was made, however, in discussions on relations with the rival Communist government in Beijing. The conference urged more trade and cultural exchanges but cautioned against talks on reunification before Beijing agrees to end its policy of isolating Taipei diplomatically. The debate focused on what to do with the 1947 constitution, enacted in China by the Nationalist government two years before it lost a civil war to the Communists and retreated to the offshore island, now home to 20 million people. The Nationalists have since used the constitution as the legal basis for their political power. Claiming to still be the legitimate government of all China, the Nationalists have not allowed native Taiwanese to vote for a majority of seats in the Legislature and electoral college. Instead, the party froze in lawmakers elected on the Chinese mainland more than four decades ago. The Nationalists have acknowledged the need for change as the aging lawmakers from the mainland die off and the increasingly affluent native Taiwanese _ 85 percent of the island population _ demand more political power.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Greets Mandela Three Years After Denouncing ANC
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher welcomed Nelson Mandela today, just three years after she denounced his African National Congress as a terrorist organization and said she would have nothing to do with it. Mrs. Thatcher and Mandela called their first meeting a success despite disagreement on sanctions and the ANC's commitment to armed struggle against the white minority government in South Africa. ``They had a very good exchange. They agreed to keep in touch,'' said a spokesman for Mrs. Thatcher, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The objective of establishing a personal relationship and rapport was fully achieved.'' Mandela described Mrs. Thatcher as ``warm and gentle'' and told a news conference he was ``very encouraged'' by their three-hour meeting. ``There were a number of points on which we did not see eye to eye completely like the question of sanctions, the use of violence as a method of political action,'' he said. ``Our views on economic questions were not altogether identical but we made progress and I went away with the distinct impression that the prime minister was willing to exchange views with us on the problems that are confronting us in South Africa,'' he said. Mrs. Thatcher greeted Mandela as he arrived in drizzling rain at her 10 Downing Street residence just before noon. Some 300 anti-apartheid demonstrators who back sanctions demonstrated at the end of Downing Street and chanted as Mandela's limousine went through the gates blocking off the street. Earlier today, Mandela urged British businessman to support sanctions for up to two years during final negotiations to end apartheid. Mrs. Thatcher and British business oppose sanctions and want those imposed by the European Community relaxed as a reward for South African President F.W. de Klerk's reform program. Mandela told more than 250 senior British business executives that both the South African government and the ANC want an end to sanctions and there is now ``an element of urgency'' on both sides to negotiate quickly so they can be lifted. ``We are aware of the damage which has been done to our economy by sanctions and we do not want our economy to be reduced to ashes by the maintenance of sanctions,'' he said. ``All that we are saying to the international community is that give us a few months, if not a year or two to resolve this question amongst ourselves,'' Mandela said. Mandela stressed that economic progress is crucial to the success of any political settlement because of the disparity in living standards of blacks and whites. ``It will be critical that the economy grows rapidly and at rates that supercede population growth. This cannot happen without large inflows of foreign capital, including British capital,'' he said. British investment forms 50 percent of the total foreign investment in South Africa and two-way trade in 1989 was worth just over $3.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's President-Elect Makes Pilgrimage to Ancestral Home
DOC.TEXT: Peruvian President-elect Alberto Fujimori knelt before his family's Buddhist altar Wednesday during a pilgrimage to his ancestral home that has brought promises of aid for his debt-ridden country. Residents of the small seaside town of Kawachi waited for hours under blazing sun to greet Fujimori. It was his first visit in 18 years to the home his parents left for Peru in 1934. In addition to his red-carpet welcome, Fujimori received promises of private aid from the region and pledges of medical and technical assistance from the local government. They were Fujimori's first firm promises of aid since his arrival in Japan on Sunday. Fujimori, an agronomist, was a political unknown before he defeated celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa in Peru's June 10 presidential runoff. He played up his Japanese heritage during the campaign, even posing dressed as a samurai warrior for news photographers. ``It was a very emotional visit for me,'' Fujimori said. ``I was surprised at the reaction. I felt the people received me with the same simple and frank hospitality as the Peruvians.'' Fujimori, the first person of Japanese descent to win such a leadership outside Japan, appears to have charmed the Japanese with his frank admiration for this nation's culture and economic power. Schoolgirls treated Fujimori as if he were a movie star. Banners proclaiming ``Bienvenido Presidente,'' greeted the Peruvian in this hilly, tangerine-growing town on the southern island of Kyushu. Elderly residents, who remember the days when poverty drove many, including the Fujimoris, from the village, said they were thrilled. Kawachi demonstrated its enthusiasm by awarding Fujimori the town's first honorary citizenship. Fujimori shook hands with people in the crowd, paid his respects to his ancestors at the household altar and posed for photos with relatives still living in the town of 8,500 people. Fujimori's talks earlier in the week with top Japanese leaders failed to draw any concrete promises of aid for his nation's ailing economy. But the governor of Kumamoto, the state where Kawachi is located, said local groups were considering the best way to provide private aid to Peru. ``Mr. Fujimori says there is a shortage of everything, from medicine to soccer balls,'' said Gov. Morihiro Hosokawa. ``We want to help meet those needs.'' Hosokawa also said his government planned to invite medical and technical trainees from Peru to local research institutes. Japanese officials have denied Peru would receive special treatment because of Fujimori's family ties. Fujimori, who assumes office July 28, has sought to emphasize those ties throughout his visit. ``I am proud to have my roots in both countries,'' he said. ``I plan to use the strong blood of the people of this area, who left 60 to 70 years ago, for the sake of my country.'' Fujimori was to leave Japan Thursday after a five-day visit. His 12-day foreign tour began in Washington and will also take him to South Korea. He told reporters he planned emergency economic measures to cope with Peru's 2,000 percent annual inflation and isolation from the international financial community. Peru, considered virtually bankrupt, has not made payments on its $22 billion foreign debt since the mid-1980s and is ineligible for money from international lending institutions. Fujimori is seeking medium- and long-term loans from Japan and a $1.8 billion bridge loan from the International Mometary Fund to help stabilize the economy. He said he planned a new currency to replace the severely devalued indica, utility price increases and a temporary, hefty tax on wealth. ``The economy of Peru needs order, it needs to recover equilibrium in its prices,'' he said. Japanese leaders have said Japan might aid Peru if Fujimori works with the IMF and other multilateral organizations to address its economic problems. Peru owes Japan about $1 billion in government and private credits.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-President Carter Accepts $100,000 Liberty Medal
With AM-July Fourth Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former President Carter was awarded the $100,000 Philadelphia Liberty Medal in a sun-baked Fourth of July ceremony at Independence Hall. He pledged to use the prize money for peace and humanitarian activities everywhere in the world. ``This award is given not to me but for the work we are doing at the Carter Center in Georgia,'' he told a crowd of thousands gathered in the mall between two historic shrines _ the hall where the Declaration of Independence was written and the Liberty Bell Pavilion. The ceremony kicked off the city's ``Freedom Festival,'' to celebrate the nation's 214th birthday. The first medal, which honors the pursuit of liberty and freedom from oppression and ignorance, went to Poland's Lech Walesa last year. A group called ``We The People'' set up the medal and obtained funding for the first three years from the Bell Atlantic Co. It plans to raise money to fund the awards beyond next year. Carter said in a statement that even as Americans celebrate the holiday ``we should remember that liberty is a privilege that many in the world don't enjoy.'' The Atlanta-based Carter Center focuses its work on promoting democracy, preserving human rights, and fighting hunger. Carter came to Philadelphia on Tuesday, where he was the guest of honor at a gala pageant and dinner. Mayor W. Wilson Goode called Carter ``an absolute inspiration to all who love freedom and love people,'' and hoped he would inspire leaders in urban communities, including Philadelphia, to rescue children from drugs and poverty. After accepting the medal, Carter was to join Goode in cutting ``America's Birthday Cake,'' which is big enough to serve 25,000 people. The cake was to be sliced up and then served, with ice cream, to the crowd assembled on a plaza across the street from the Liberty Bell.

DOC.HEAD: Man Extradited from Mexico to Face Drug-Trafficking Charges
DOC.TEXT: A rancher accused of running a drug smuggling empire is back in the U.S. after 20 years as a fugitive, the last three fighting extradition. Daniel James Fowlie faces a U.S. District Court hearing July 10 on 26 counts of narcotics trafficking and illegal-currency transactions. If convicted, Fowlie could be sentenced to life in prison. An indictment alleges Fowlie, 56, supervised shipments of nearly 27 tons of marijuana from 1982 to 1986 and transferred more than $1 million in cash abroad without reporting it to the government. Fowlie's operation bought marijuana in Mexico and smuggled it to Orange County in quantities between 50 pounds to 30,000 pounds, according to the indictment. He was extradited from Mexico and arrived at John Wayne Airport on Monday, flanked by U.S. agents who escorted him from a La Paz jail where he had been imprisoned for three years on a U.S. government warrant. Fowlie had fought extradition, saying it would violate the Mexican Constitution, but a court in Mazatlan on June 22 upheld the transfer. Authorities allege that Fowlie engineered a massive marijuana-and cocaine-smuggling ring from Rancho del Rio, his 213-acre ranch near San Juan Capistrano. Six of his alleged helpers _ including sons Daniel and Gus _ have been convicted. In 1985, county sheriff's investigators seized his ranch and last summer, President Bush used the property as a backdrop for a nationally televised address on drug abuse. In an interview earlier this year, Fowlie denied the charges, saying he was railroaded by former associates-turned-government snitches. Various law enforcement agencies tracked Fowlie for more than 20 years, traveling to Europe and Central America in pursuit of him. In the late 1960s, he was linked to drug guru Timothy Leary and a smuggling ring known as the Brotherhood of Love. Fowlie later started an import-export business in Laguna Beach and lived an extravagant lifestyle, purchasing airplanes, exotic cars and estates in Orange County, Baja California and Costa Rica.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors: `Racial' Attack Was Case of Mistaken Identity
DOC.TEXT: A black youth who was killed in an attack by a white gang in Bensonhurst was a victim of mistaken identity, not racial bias, according to jurors who cleared one mob member of intentional murder and discrimination. The jury Tuesday failed to resolve a second murder charge against John Vento, 21, in what has been routinely described as the racially motivated attack on Yusuf Hawkins.
