Jurors interviewed after the verdict said prosecutors and journalists had overemphasized the role of race in the slaying, which occurred last August in a predominantly white, lower middle class section of Brooklyn and inflamed racial tensions throughout the city. ``We all felt this was really more about mistaken identity,'' said juror Lee Levin. If Hawkins and three other blacks ``had gone to the same section of Bensonhurst on any other night ... these people would not have been involved in an incident,'' she added. ``Race was used for identification only,'' agreed juror Judith Schwartz, a teacher. ``If they had heard a bunch of Norwegians were coming to the neighborhood looking for trouble, they would have acted the same way.'' ``If the only reason they attacked (Hawkins) was because he was black _ that would have been discrimination,'' she said. According to testimony at the trials of Vento and two other young men, the whites believed that a group of blacks and Hispanics was coming to start a fight over a woman who had been involved with one of the whites. Instead, the whites set upon the 16-year-old Hawkins when he came to the Brooklyn neighborhood to look at a used car that was for sale. The jury's four black members agreed that race did not motivate Vento and most of his companions. ``All they had to go on was some blacks and Puerto Ricans were coming to the neighborhood,'' said one, Kenneth Spears, a transit worker. Spears said some members of the mob may have been racists, but added, ``We can't get into their minds, so we don't know.'' Vento's lawyer, Gerald DiChiara, said that prosecutors created a racial issue for political purposes. DiChiara seemed to have defused the racial issue during the trial by calling as witnesses four black men who knew Vento and said he was not a bigot. Ms. Schwartz said the news media also tried to make the incident seem purely racial in origin. ``I went in thinking he was probably guilty,'' she said. ``But then I heard the evidence and the law.'' She said she was so convinced of Vento's innocence that she would contribute $500 to a defense fund for his September retrial on charges of riot and murder with depraved indifference. Vento, who allegedly helped organize the gang, was convicted of two counts of unlawful imprisonment and four counts of menacing. Jurors said the votes on the unresolved charges were 10-2 for acquittal on murder by depraved indifference and 8-4 for conviction on riot. On the murder by depraved indifference count, ``There was agreement that he organized people. There was agreement that he was there,'' said Levin, one of the two holdouts for a murder conviction. ``All the physical stuff was there, but there wasn't agreement on whether he was mentally culpable.'' Juror Irwin Ziegler said the deliberations were ``not very nice. ... It was very tense, very emotional, a lot of yelling and screaming.'' Vento faces one and one-third to four years in prison on the unlawful imprisonment counts and 90 days on each menacing count. Sentencing is Aug. 14. He was the third member of the mob to go on trial; Keith Mondello and Joseph Fama both were convicted of discrimination. Fama, who allegedly fired the shot that killed Hawkins, was convicted of murder, but Mondello was acquitted of the most serious charges. Five other youths still face trial.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Photographer Latest Star in Art vs. Censorship Battle
DOC.TEXT: A photographer whose black-and-white prints have been shown internationally became an advocate in the debate over arts censorship after much of his life's work was seized in an obscenity investigation. Jock Sturges hasn't been arrested or charged, but the San Francisco-based photographer has been the subject of a federal grand jury investigation for nine weeks. The 43-year-old Sturges said he finds himself ``cast in a role that I'm unprepared for,'' in being accused of child pornography. About half of his photographs are of nude men and women and their children. Sturges says the subjects are ``naturists'' who provide written permission for the photos to be published or displayed. Federal agents confiscated all types of works by Sturges, who also photographs fashion models and classical dancers. His most lucrative local account, the Marin Ballet, canceled his contract after the investigation began. ``I'm under assault,'' Sturges told several hundred people who gathered Monday night in a San Francisco theater to hear his story. ``But I'm getting lots of support from the arts community. ``It's time to say enough is enough. ... I was shocked at first, depressed, when my life's work was carried away. Now I'm beginning to get angry.'' Sturges shared a podium with Dennis Barrie, a Cincinnati gallery director under indictment for exhibiting explicit photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. ``This is not an aberration, what happened in Cincinnati,'' Barrie told the audience, warning that unless he wins his case pro-censorship forces will grow bolder. ``If we lose all arts museums are vulnerable.'' Sturges reminded Barrie that ``this is not Cincinnati.'' Indeed, Mayor Art Agnos declared Monday Dennis Barrie Day in San Francisco. A resolution protesting the case against Sturges was approved Tuesday by the Board of Supervisors' City Services Committee. ``There is a dangerous state of hysteria and repression over freedom of expression of artists in the United States,'' said the resolution, which goes before the full board next week. Sturges says some of his artworks have been ruined since police and FBI raids on his apartment and the shop of his film processor, Joseph Semien, who was arrested for investigation of possessing child pornography. The FBI and the San Francisco district attorney's office have refused to comment on the cases. FBI spokesman Duke Diedrich would only say, ``We're very careful when we handle evidence.'' In a similar investigation, federal prosecutors in Portland, Maine, have gone to court to get permission to destroy a photograph of a nude father and son that was seized by customs agents at the Canadian border. The self-portrait by nationally known photographer Walter Chappell dates to the early 1960s and has appeared in a picture book of American nude photography published by Harper & Row. The federal government's sudden interest in bringing an obscenity case against the Chappell photograph comes at a time of national debate on freedom of expression in such diverse issues as flag burning and the lyrics of the rap group 2 Live Crew. The investigation of Sturges began after Newell Colour, a photo lab, notified authorities of negatives of nude girls ages 9-11. Semien, 26, was arrested April 25 after picking up some of Sturges' photos from the lab. A state law intended to fight child abuse requires all film-processing companies to report any material showing a child under 14 engaged in ``sexual conduct.'' Sexual conduct is defined as ``exhibition of the genitals ... for the purpose of sexual stimulation of the viewer.'' Sturges' lawyer contends the law is unconstitutional because it's vague. ``It's a sense of taste,'' said attorney Michael H. Metzger. ``There are certainly some people who may find it to be tasteless. But nothing Sturges ever did in any way exploits or is harmful to children.'' ``I think he's a talented, serious photographer. The idea that his work is somehow obscene or pornographic is ludicrous,'' said Peter Galassi, curator of photography at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. The museum has a Sturges photograph in its collection, and his work has been displayed in the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris. ``I'm an artist,'' Sturges said. ``I am to no extent a pornographer.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Israeli Weapon Seized in Colombian Assassination
DOC.TEXT: Four arrests in the assassination of a Colombian presidential candidate turned up an assault rifle that U.S. authorities say came from a shipment of Israeli arms, a newspaper reported Wednesday. New York Newsday quoted Jack Killorin, a spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, as saying the rifle was part of an arms shipment Israel says was intended for the defense force of the island of Antigua. Israel has maintained it does not know how weapons from the shipment of 500 Galil rifles and Uzi machine pistols were diverted, with some reaching the late Colombian drug boss Jose Rodriguez Gacha. In the Aug. 18 assassination of Luis Carlos Galan, drug traffickers allegedly fired rifles as a diversion before killing the presidential candidate with a machine pistol. The assassination prompted a government crackdown on Colombia's drug barons and a wave of terrorism. Colombia has blamed the terror on Gacha's forces, which it claimed were trained by Israeli reserve officers led by Lt. Col. Yair Klein. Newsday said that Colombian authorities discovered the Israeli Galil rifle among weapons in two Bogota safehouses raided when they arrested the suspected assassins Sept. 21. Israeli Embassy press attache Ruth Yaron in Washington did not return repeated phone calls, Newsday reported. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., chairman of a Senate narcotics subcommittee, said the new disclosure was disturbing, and he urged an investigation.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0534 to fix cycle designation
DOC.HEAD: Tribe Accepts Direct Control of Federal Funds
DOC.TEXT: Cherokee Nation Chief Wilma Mankiller has signed an unprecedented agreement in which the Bureau of Indian Affairs will give the tribe direct control over millions of dollars in federal funding. ``Through self-governance, we can better determine the services needed by tribal members and fulfill those needs without the bureaucratic delays of the past,'' Ms. Mankiller said in a statement from Boston, where she is recuperating from a kidney transplant. Three-year agreements announced Tuesday also cover four smaller Indian tribes. They are the Quinalt Indian Nation, of Taholah, Wash.; the Lummi Indian Nation, of Bellingham, Wash.; the Jamestown Klallam Indian Tribe, of Sequim, Wash.; and the Hoopa Valley Indian Tribe, of Hoopa, Calif. ``This is a major step toward giving tribal governments full authority and responsibility for governing their reservations,'' Eddie F. Brown, assistant Interior secretary, said in Washington, D.C. ``These agreements are historic for these tribes and for the BIA,'' he said. The agreements and Brown's comments were reported Wednesday from Washington by The Daily Oklahoman and the Tulsa World. John Ketcher, deputy principal chief of the Tahlequah, Okla.-based Cherokee Nation, said tribal leaders were looking forward to having more flexibility in using federal funds. ``The problem with the BIA in the past has been that once they get locked into something, it's difficult for them to change direction,'' Ketcher said. The agreements go into effect Oct. 1, the beginning of the next fiscal year. Of the five tribes, the Cherokee Nation has the largest amount of funds to be administered, $6.1 million next year. Brown said the agreements are expected to eliminate 20 to 30 full-time BIA positions. Former BIA head Ross Swimmer of Oklahoma, Mankiller's predecessor as Cherokee chief, was one of the first to gain support for self-governance, said agency spokesman Carl Shaw. A 1988 law allows 20 tribes to participate in agreements to control their own funds with minimal federal interference. The law also requires the Interior secretary to maintain its ``trust responsibility'' in Indian affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Testify About Finding Female Jogger
DOC.TEXT: Police were sitting in a car about 40 yards from where a naked and bloodied female jogger lay moaning and nearly dead in Central Park last April, two men testified. Vinicio Moore, 38, testified Tuesday that he was walking through the park with a friend when they heard a faint moan coming from a muddy spot in a gully. ``I heard somebody go, `Uuuhhh! Uuuuhhhh! Uuhh!''' Moore said. ``I didn't know if it was a man or a woman, but I knew it was a body.'' Neither Moore nor his companion saw or heard anyone leaving the area. Moore's companion, Carlos Colon, who also testified Tuesday, said they didn't get too close because they feared attack. Moore said he could see a body covered with mud. ``The night was clear,'' he said. ``There was moonlight. It was warm.'' Moore said he thought it was about 12:30 a.m., April 20, 1989. ``Carlos said, `Look! Look! Look! Look, Vinny, look!'' Moore said, ``Carlos was the first one who saw her.'' ``We ran up the hill and there was a police car,'' Moore said. ``We talked to the police. We got into the car and drove down the hill and we showed them there was a body there.'' From spots Moore pointed out on a map and pictures of the park, it seems the police were parked only 30 to 40 yards from where the woman was found thrashing in the mud and gagging on a bloodied T-shirt stuffed in her mouth. Colon, 24, testified he was walking about 5 feet ahead of his friend. ``I heard moaning, so I looked back,'' Colon said. ``I saw a body moving. I didn't know if the person who did it was still around, and I didn't want to stay there and find out. ... ``When they turned the body over we saw it was a woman,'' he said. ``She had two holes in her head. Her face was bruised. Her hands were like this.'' The witness closed his hands into fists, put them together with palms facing, and pulled them up to his face. ``She had a gag in her mouth,'' Colon continued. ``I asked the police to take the gag out of her mouth because she looked like she couldn't breathe. He had trouble taking it out, so I helped him.'' The men were testifying in Manhattan's state Supreme Court at the trial of Antron McCray, 15, Raymond Santana, 16, and Yusef Salaam, 16, charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in the attack on the woman and two male joggers. The female jogger, an investment banker who was then 28, was gang-raped, savagely beaten, and left naked and near death. She survived, but suffered brain damage and has no recollection of what happened to her that night, Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer said. The prosecutor has refused to say whether the woman will testify. McCray, Santana and Salaam are on trial in an adult court, but if convicted they will be sentenced as juvenile offenders to up to 10 years in prison. Three other youngsters charged in the attacks, Steven Lopez, 15, Kevin Richardson, 15, and Kharey Wise, 17, are to stand trial on the same charges later this year.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Members Wary of Meddling with Their Successful Alliance
With AM-NATO, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Major members of NATO go to London this week reluctant to change the alliance that has prevented conflict during the Cold War and the advent of nuclear weaponry. After 41 years of an alliance pitted against the Warsaw Pact, the 16 nations that make up the North Atlantic Treaty Organization must rethink how they will keep the peace. The Communist governments of Eastern Europe that supported the Warsaw Pact have been swept away in the last year by popular revolutions. The new governments, for the most part, have insisted that Soviet forces be withdrawn from their soil and that the East-West armed confrontation be ended. NATO leaders on Thursday and Friday must decide how the Western world will ensure its safety and what future role the alliance might play. Members will wrestle with proposals to change NATO's focus _ from a military alliance to a political forum; its strategy, from containing communism to regional peacekeeping; and even its membership, with the suggested admission of East Germany. Here are some views about the alliance's future: _ West Germany wants NATO membership extended to both halves of a united Germany, and to develop the Atlantic alliance into ``a stability-oriented partnership with the Soviet Union and other European countries ...,'' Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has said. Genscher also wants a broader role of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE), which deals with military security, economic cooperation and human rights. _ Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said last week: ``There exists a clear consciousness that the Atlantic Alliance is not replaceable and that the trans-Atlantic link (with the United States and Canada) should be maintained.'' ``That someone might propose the elimination of NATO would seem to me an attempt to ignore the history of the 20th century, ignore that there was a World War (II),'' he said. _ British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, traditionally the most hawkish of the Western leaders, is adamant that NATO should remain as a defense alliance complete with nuclear weapons and U.S. troops deployed in Western Europe. ``You do not cancel your home insurance policy just because there have been fewer burglaries in your street in the last 12 months,'' the Conservative Party prime minister told NATO foreign ministers last month. Britain is replacing its aging nuclear weapons with a $9-billion U.S. Trident missile system. British officials also say there will likely be a reduction in the 66,700 British troops based in West Germany. _ Norwegian Defense Minister Per Ditlev-Simonsen is in general agreement. Norway has seen little effect from military changes in the East Bloc. In fact, the Soviet Union is modernizing and has moved forces from Central Europe to its Kola Pennisula bases, near its arctic border with Norway, Ditlev-Simonsen said. Backfire bombers are now stationed at Kola, and Flogger fighter-bombers withdrawn from Hungary went to the north flank, he added. His spokesman, Erik Senstad, said: ``We want NATO to stay the way it is, with Germany as a member.'' _ French officials are staying out of public debate on details of NATO's future. They continue to insist they will remain outside its military wing. Asked about pleas that France rejoin the unified miltary structure that it left in 1966, President Francois Mitterrand's spokesman, Hubert Vedrine said: ``The answer is no.'' Vedrine also indicated France has backed away from its earlier suggestions that the CSCE be developed into a continent-wide security body that would supercede NATO and the Warsaw Pact. ``NATO is an alliance for defense,'' Vedrine said. ``The CSCE is not an alliance ... We cannot push it as a substitute.'' _ U.S. officials have remained vague about the role NATO should take overseeing Europe, although the administration of President Bush believes the alliance should gradually evolve from a military to a more political union, in which a unified Germany will be anchored. ``NATO has been the most successful defensive alliance in history. It is and it must remain a coherent force for peace,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said last Thursday. With some promptings from U.S. allies, Baker has gradually shifted his view to say that the CSCE should be bolstered to provide a new security arrangement for Europe. But he and other officials see the forum more as a tool to help spread democracy in Europe and help the transition from government-controlled to market economies. _ Belgium, on the other hand, seeks a greater profile for the CSCE. It wants a permanent CSCE secretariat as ``an embryonic form of a greater Pan-European security structure,'' said Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said in a recent position paper.

President Bush declared parts of Nebraska a major disaster area Wednesday from the severe storms, tornadoes and flooding that struck the state last month. The declaration, issued at the president's vacation home here, makes federal funds available for the recovery effort in a 14-county area. The counties are: Buffalo, Colfax, Dodge, Douglas, Gage, Hitchcock, Madison, Platte, Red Willow, Sharpy, Sherman, Stanton, Thurston and Washington. The federal aid includes temporary housing, grants, low-cost loans and other help for both individuals and business owners. The government also normally pays up to 75 percent of the costs of repairing or replacing damaged public facilities. The severe weather struck the state beginning June 10. The Federal Emergency Management Agency is still surveying other areas of the state to determine whether the disaster declaration should be extended to other counties. Edward A. Thomas of FEMA's Boston regional office was named to coordinate federal recovery operations.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Designer Calvin Klein was in a Manhattan hospital Wednesday with a concussion, two broken ribs and other injuries suffered after being thrown from a horse at a Long Island riding stable. Klein, 47, was in stable condition at New York Hospital, where he was flown by helicopter Tuesday night, said Mary Cialone, a hospital spokeswoman. He also had a bruised lung and cuts on his head, she said. He would probably remain hospitalized for about a week. ``The doctors expect a quick and complete recovery,'' said Paul Wilmot, a spokesman for Klein. He said the fashion designer was riding his horse at a stable in Bridgehampton when ``something spooked the horse.'' He described Klein, who has a home in nearby East Hampton, as a good rider. Wilmot, reached at his home in Rhode Island, said he spoke Wednesday morning with Klein by telephone. Asked if Klein mentioned riding again, Wilmot said, ``I don't think you'd want to ask him that today.''

Princess Diana gave Spanish tenor Jose Carreras an honorary membership in the Royal Academy of Music on Wednesday. Carreras, who resumed his singing career two years ago after bone marrow surgery for leukemia, traveled here for the school's graduation ceremony. ``It is a great honor because this is one of the most prestigious institutions for music in the world and it is a very special moment for me,'' the 44-year-old star said. Carreras is scheduled to perform in Rome this weekend with opera stars Luciano Pavarotti and Placido Domingo as part of the World Cup soccer tournament finale. German-born conductor Klaus Tennstedt, the conductor laureate of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, and international violinists Erich Gruenberg and Gyorgy Pauk, also were made honorary members of the academy.

His friends include Marcello Mastroianni and Vanessa Redgrave. The Mayor of Rome gave him ``Most Likable Person'' of the year prize. From Milan to Naples to Florence, people stop him in the streets for autographs. Not bad for a 10-year-old. ``I get letters saying to maintain my naturalness,'' said Salvatore ``Toto'' Cascio, the projectionist's invaluable assistant in ``Cinema Paradiso,'' which won the Academy Award for best foreign film. ``Everyone wants to have my picture.'' ``Cinema Paradiso'' was Salvatore's film debut. In fact, he had never seen a movie since there was no theater in his hometown of Palermo, Sicily. ``They made the selection among 300 children,'' he explained Tuesday through an interpreter during an interview at a Manhattan hotel. ``After this selection, myself and another boy were chosen. They then had another rehearsal and I was ultimately picked. ``I wasn't nervous. I slept very well.'' Now, Salvatore is almost everywhere. He's completed five more films, appearing with Mastroianni, Redgrave and Peter Ustinov among others, and says he's seen ``Cinema Paradiso'' 16 times. ``Maybe I'll do another picture this summer,'' he said. ``Then I will go on vacation.''

Thousands of women may consider talk-show host Phil Donahue to be the ideal husband, but the one who married him says he's far from perfect. ``Phil is the greatest husband in the world, and he's nothing to brag about,'' Marlo Thomas told the General Federation of Women's Clubs convention Tuesday. She says her husband shares a trait common among married men _ always asking their wives where their shoes, keys and other belongings are. ``And the thing that kills me is, we know where those things are!'' Thomas also told the group at a Times Square hotel that women get a bum rap in the business world. ``A man has to be Joe McCarthy to be called ruthless,'' she said. ``All a woman has to do is put you on hold.''

DOC.HEAD: Robber Commits Suicide After Asking Sheriff's Deputies to Shoot Him
DOC.TEXT: A man robbed a convenience store, then shot himself to death in front of horrified onlookers after asking sheriff's deputies to shoot him, authorities said. The man was identified Wednesday as Darcy Willey, 24, of Tacoma. After the man robbed the suburban Lakewood store Tuesday, he was cornered in a parking lot, authorities said. ``We asked him to put the weapon down. He refused,'' said Curt Benson of the Pierce County sheriff's office. ``He kept putting it in his mouth and at his temple. We tried to encourage him to surrender. At one point he said, `Will you shoot me?''' When deputies refused, the man pulled the trigger, Benson said. The suicide was seen by 10 to 20 people, said Benson. A sheriff's chaplain was summoned to counsel them as well as the deputies, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Marion Hart Dies at 98; Made Seven Solo Flights Across Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Marion Rice Hart, an adventurer who sailed around the world and made seven solo flights across the Atlantic, has died of pneumonia. She was 98. Hart, who died Monday, first learned to fly at age 54 and earned worldwide acclaim for her feats. ``I wanted to see the world. I don't want to just sit around the house,'' the then-81-year-old Hart told a reporter in 1972 before she climbed into her single-engine aircraft in Katmandu, Nepal. ``The feminist movement didn't mean much to her because she did whatever she wanted before feminism came in,'' said her niece, Dorothy Rice. Hart was born Oct. 2, 1891, in London. She married a mining engineer and the couple lived in Arizona and California before divorcing. After learning to fly, Hart piloted her single-engine plane non-stop across the Atlantic at age 61. She later flew all over the United States, Europe, Asia, Africa and South America, and made at least six more solo flights across the Atlantic, the last at age 83. ``She always wanted to get into Russia,'' said Dorothy Rice. ``She wrote to Mrs. Khrushchev, but they would only permit it if she had a Soviet guide and she never wanted that. She refused.'' Hart received the Harmon International Trophy from Vice President Walter Mondale in 1976. The award recognized her feats operating a ``small aircraft on a global scale.'' Hart, whose parents left her a comfortable trust fund, was the first woman to graduate in chemical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In 1936, Hart cast off for what became a three-year voyage sailing around the world on her 72-foot ketch. Hart took to flying after working as a radio operator for the Army Air Corps during World War II. She stopped flying at age 87 after she overshot the runway at the Tucson, Ariz., airport on a trip back from Mexico. The plane is in the Tucson Pima Air Museum. Hart is survived by one nephew and four nieces. At her request, no funeral service will be held.

DOC.HEAD: Anonymous Pamphlet Urges Jewish Settlers To Shoot Arabs
DOC.TEXT: A pamphlet distributed among Jewish settlers urged them to shoot Palestinians and gave detailed instructions on how to obtain guns and avoid capture, according to media reports Wednesday. The anonymous pamphlet, quoted by the Hebrew daily Yediot Ahronot and state radio, advises settlers to gather explosives from the army, masquerade as soldiers during attacks and leave behind misleading evidence. It says the settlers in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip should respond to stoning attacks on their cars with gunfire and should try to ``hit and cause much damage.'' The pamphlet also urges retribution against Palestinians. ``You must react to every Arab stone with secret revenge acts,'' the leaflet was quoted as saying. ``Cause damage to Arab property.'' The reports come at a time of rising tension between settlers and Palestinians, who have carried out an uprising against Israeli occupation for more than 30 months. In the uprising, at least 721 Palestinians have been slain by Israeli gunfire and 45 Israelis have died. The daily Haaretz quoted security sources as saying stalled peace efforts could push Palestinian extremists to attack Jewish settlements. Liberal politicians have accused the right-wing government of encouraging radicals among the settlers. Yediot said the pamphlets were put into settlers' mailboxes, but it was unclear how many were distributed or in which settlements. The pamphlet was not signed and news reports gave no evidence of who printed it. More than 130 Jewish settlements have been built in the West Bank and Gaza since the territories were captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. About 75,000 Jews live there among 1.7 million Palestinians. Israel Harel, a settler leader, said he checked eight settlements and found no sign of the pamphlets. ``This pamphlet is simply not known in the settlements,'' he said. Zvi Katzover, head of the Kiryat Arba settlement in the West Bank, said the pamphlet was probably done by a ``fringe group.'' He said, however, the advice ``should not be ignored ... to try and catch stone throwers at almost any price.'' Politicians on both left and right expressed fears the pamphlet could be evidence that a new Jewish underground was forming, similar to one that targeted and killed several Palestinian leaders in the early 1980s. Parliament member Ran Cohen of the liberal Citizens' Rights Movement said the pamphlet ``not only calls for the murder of innocent Arabs ... but also the impersonation of army soldiers.'' Cohen said he sent copies of the pamphlet to authorities. Lawmaker Geula Cohen of the right-wing Tehiya Party said the pamphlet was ``madness.'' ``This is really an underground, not against the Arabs but against the state of Israel,'' she told Yediot. According to the radio, the pamphlet outlines a scenario in which two settlers are in a car nearing an area where Palestinian youths often stone settlers' cars. The pamphlet says: ``Your friend moves into the back seat, handgun in hand. ... In front of you a stone is thrown. Your friend opens a window and empties his magazine. He tries to hit and cause much damage.'' The pamphlet goes on to to say that to mislead investigators, the settlers should then sprinkle on the roadside empty cartridges not from their own weapons. Among the instructions quoted from the pamphlet were: _ ``Collect explosives, fuses, delaying fuses, detonators. The primary source: the army. _ ``Arm yourself with an M-16 assault rifle. Take the weapon from your settlement's armory or from your army unit.... _ ``When you go on an operation, wear army fatigues and a stocking cap. _ ``How not to be caught: If you use your weapon, do not report to a civilian control center or the military. ... Wipe fingerprints from the weapon.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-KGB Agent: Soviet Defectors Destroying Intelligence Networks
DOC.TEXT: A former KGB counterintelligence chief says about 20 agents who have defected to the West in the past decade have caused the ``total collapse'' of many Soviet spy rings. Oleg D. Kalugin, who worked as an operative in the United States from 1958 to 1970 but has since been dismissed from the KGB and stripped of his rank as major general, made his latest revelation about the agency in Tuesday's editions of the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda. At an anti-Communist rally Tuesday evening, Kalugin blamed KGB chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov for what he called ``criminal negligence and incompetence, which led to the mass desertion of KGB agents and demoralized intelligence.'' In recent weeks, Kalugin has been waging a public relations campaign against the KGB, through interviews with Western reporters and in articles in reformist Soviet newspapers. He has said the KGB still taps telephones, infiltrates Soviet life, including the Russian Orthodox church and labor organizations, and engages in dirty tricks. Kalugin has embraced the reform policies of the radical Democratic Platform, alleging his superiors drummed him out of the agency because of his politics. After his Tuesday speech, which at times evoked populist themes that a candidate for office would use, many in the crowd chanted ``Well done!'' and a few urged him to run for the Soviet parliament. In the newspaper article, he denied allegations by his former superiors that he himself was responsible for leaks of information. ``Since 1960 until 1980, three KGB agents defected to the West,'' Kalugin wrote. ``And since 1980, about 20 have already betrayed the motherland. ``Thus we can boldly speak not of an information leak but about a majority of Soviet intelligence's secrets sold to the West, about the total collapse of a great number of intelligence networks,'' he added. ``But all this is being thoroughly concealed from the public.'' A separate letter by Soviet lawmakers printed in Komsomolskaya Pravda urged an investigation of Kalugin's allegations by the Supreme Soviet legislature. At the rally Tuesday evening, he said his ex-bosses claimed he had been living in the United States too long. Kalugin said he had not been affected by America's ``material benefits,'' but rather by the civil rights movement led by the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., and students protesting the Vietnam War. He also delivered a stinging attack on the KGB's hard-line chiefs, to the delight of a crowd of more than 4,000 people who earlier had been shouting ``Shame on the KGB!'' ``The people who are now in the leadership of the KGB are mainly those who bear full responsibility for the injustice and crimes committed against the Soviet people and our society,'' Kalugin said. The men in leadership positions of the KGB for the past 15 to 20 years were ``chips off Stalin's and Brezhnev's empire,'' Kalugin said, referring to former Soviet leaders Josef Stalin and Leonid Brezhnev. He also blamed the KGB for recent unrest in the Soviet Union's Caucasian and Central Asian republics. ``I'll say that the KGB did not fulfill its basic role when it failed to prevent ethnic conflicts and failed to provide stability for society,'' he said. Years of lawlessness by the agency was responsible for ``millions of lost lives, millions of broken lives,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Grape Farmer, Plumber Unlikely Promoters for `Mr. Bojangles' Singer
DOC.TEXT: The grape farmer was in the front row, and the plumber and vacuum-cleaner salesman were close by. That was the payoff for cajoling country-rock star Jerry Jeff Walker to give a concert in the picture-postcard village of North East on the shore of Lake Erie. Walker acknowledged the plumber-turned-promoter by sporting an ``Ollinger's Plumbing, Heating and Air Conditioning'' T-shirt under his black jacket. He traded his beige felt cowboy hat for a maroon North East baseball cap. ``I like a man who knows what he wants and goes and gets it,'' Walker hollered to the screams and shouts of 250 fans who packed a barn-turned-restaurant for Walker's concert Tuesday night. ``And they said it couldn't be done.'' Chuck Ollinger got the idea of a Walker concert so Ollinger and his buddies could have front-row seats to hear one of their favorite singers. Ollinger called Walker's agent and struck a deal that Ollinger would put half the money up front. ``It was a spur-of-the-moment kind of thing,'' said Ollinger, 36. ``We had no idea what we were doing.'' ``It was either going to fly or else it was going to be a real expensive Fourth of July,'' said Bill Neil, 36, a grape farmer who put up some of the advance money. The amount was not disclosed. Walker catapulted to fame in 1968 when he recorded the now-classic ``Mr. Bojangles.'' Other hits include ``L.A. Freeway'' and ``Up Against the Wall, Redneck.'' ``These guys wanted me here, and they paid my money,'' Walker, 48, said before taking to the makeshift stage at the Delhurst Country Inn. ``I do the solo thing this way ... for economic reasons. When guys are carrying six, seven, eight people around, they keep themselves out of the market. I did that longer and longer with less and less money to show for it.'' Ollinger wanted to bring Walker to North East after he saw him perform at a small club in Pittsburgh, about 150 miles to the south. He called Walker's agent and struck a deal that required Ollinger put half the money up front before a contract could be signed. To Walker, it was a good arrangement because he was headed to his 30th high school reunion in Oneonta this Saturday. Ollinger tapped four friends to help _ Neil; Rich Timer, a computer salesman; Brad Wallace, a vacuum cleaner salesman; and Randy Cunningham, a car dealer. They signed the contract at the end of May. With the help of a local radio station and word-of-mouth advertising, the $18 tickets were sold out in four days. ``We could have sold at least 500 tickets with the limited advertising we did _ more if we spent money on advertising,'' said Timer, 36.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from the Communist Party Congress
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Among speakers at Wednesday's session of the Communist Party congress was Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin, considered one of the main architects of the Kremlin's current plan for a transition to a market economy. His remarks were translated by The Associated Press:
The fate of socialism and the socialist ideal should not be tied to just one of its models. Now it has become clear that there are more than one _ and quite varied _ models of forming socialism. And the failure of one of these models does not mean the crash of the idea of the socialist choice itself. Among these models can be those that correspond to general models of social progress, and those that represent a blind alley of social development. The model based on full state ownership of property, on liquidation of various forms of enterprise, and the negation of the market is not capable of maintaining high social and economic results. We often say we built the wrong socialism, now we'll build another, humane and democratic. I think we should be clear that we did not build socialism and have not lived in the conditions of a socialist society. Otherwise we'll have to admit that a society in which the problems of food supply, feeding the people, solving the housing problem, a society without the institutions of a democratic government are absent, can be called socialist. If we want a more effective economy, oriented toward technical progress; if we want stores full of varied products of high quality; if we want to be done with the shame of lines, speculation and closed stores; if we want to create a strong enough stimulus for labor, we have no other choice but the transition to a market economy. A lot hinders us in this, including what I mentioned before, dogma and myth. There are general laws of social progress. They can't be canceled. ... Any party or social organization that tries to hinder this process, try to go against the logic of social progress, will inevitably be pushed aside from the historical battle and meet defeat. I think our congress has enough wisdom, calm and confidence in the achievements of contemporary science to make the right decision.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Gives Himself Two Years To Improve Soviet Union
LaserPhotos MOSB1,2,6
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday gave himself and the Soviet leadership two years to improve citizens' lives or resign. ``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership must go,'' Gorbachev told a TV interviewer as he entered the Kremlin Palace of Congresses on the third day of the Communist Party's 28th congress. It was the first time that the Soviet president and party leader, who is facing bitter criticism from both radical reformers and party traditionalists, has given himself and the leadership a deadline for turning around the country's political, economic and social problems. A Western journalist who was on the scene said Gorbachev had been asked what should happen if there are no improvements in the Soviet Union in two years. Speaking confidently in a videotaped segment shown on the nightly TV news program ``Vremya,'' he denied that the Kremlin leadership would do anything to hold onto political power. ``No!'' he said. ``I will tell you, before perestroika we had more power. I don't know who had more power than the general secretary of the Central Committee.'' The leadership has made mistakes, he said. But he praised its courage in starting his reform program. He did not specify who should be covered by his self-imposed deadline, but it seemed likely that it was meant for both party and government leaders. Most important Soviet officials still hold important posts in both the Communist Party and the Soviet government. Earlier Wednesday, Gorbachev heard more bitter criticism of his program inside the congress hall from regional party officials, who accused the leadership of cowardice and indecision in an ideological battle against growing anti-Communist sentiments. Underscoring the mood, more than 4,600 delegates to the Communist Party's 28th Congress sat sullenly as Deputy Prime Minister Leonid A. Abalkin warned that resisting reform would lead the party to disaster. ``Our position today reminds of an army that is retreating in haste without a plan,'' said Nursultan Nazarbaev, party chief in the Kazakhstan republic, as he pleaded for clearer direction from the Kremlin. But despite the criticism, speakers displayed no new ideas and no alternative to re-electing Gorbachev. The congress made a special appeal to one of most anti-Communist elements of society _ disgruntled coal miners _ not to strike. In a resolution, it said that a repetition of last year's walkout could ``lead to a breakup of the country's economy.'' Regional leaders blamed their bosses in the Kremlin for ecological disasters surrounding the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, Central Asia's shrinking Aral Sea and its overdependence on cotton production, and poor social and economic conditions that are causing an increasing number of Soviets to blame the party as the source of their problems. Gorbachev listened quietly to the criticism, which came mainly from party leaders of some of the 15 Soviet republics, large cities, and ministers in charge of important sectors of the economy. He heard much of the same criticism the previous day from fellow members of the party's ruling Politburo, but he appeared to remain in firm control of the congress. The regional party leaders, echoing a poll of delegates released by the state news agency Tass, demanded that the national leadership give them clearer direction. They heaped criticism on party ideology chief Vadim A. Medvedev, who was jeered as he spoke on Monday, the first day of the congress. Nazarbaev, the party chief in Kazakhstan, was warmly applauded when he complained that the party's opponents ``heap buckets of mud on Lenin and Leninsim, and the cowardly activities of our ideologists led by Medvedev demoralized our forces.'' Vitaly Perov, representing a region near Moscow, accused Medvedev and Gorbachev adviser Alexander N. Yakovlev of ``hiding in the trenches'' while radicals from the Democratic Platform reform group seize the initiative. Anatoly Poruchikov, director of a central Russian state farm, said in a speech that farmers are not impressed with the government's reforms. ``We are like a big cow for you, you milk us non-stop,'' he complained. ``What will happen to you if we all stop?'' ``We're all sick of your extreme pluralism and democracy,'' he declared. Stanislav I. Gurenko, newly elected head of the Ukrainian party, said: ``We should rebuff mud-slinging slander, we should not retreat from our positions, we should stop committing suicide, we should stop this self-flagellation.'' ``We underestimated the danger of anti-communism,'' Gurenko said. As party chief in the Soviet Union's second-largest republic, he faces an anti-Communist challenge not only in the Don River coal mining basin in the eastern Ukraine, but in the troublesome western region near Lvov. Miners' representatives meeting in Donetsk last month condemned the Communist Party for hindering reforms. They announced plans for a short political strike on July 11 if Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, also a leading Communist official, does not quit. Despite the criticism, speaker after speaker said there was no alternative to giving Gorbachev another five-year term as party chief. ``Gorbachev started perestroika and party members support him,'' said Yefrem Sokolov, a traditionalist republican party leader from Byelorussia.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Orders Recall of Newest Jet Engines
DOC.TEXT: Pratt & Whitney has recalled more than three dozen of its newest, largest jet engines in response to a compressor problem that, if left unchecked, could have prompted an in-flight engine shutdown. The problem was discovered in one PW4000 engine compressor, Pratt spokesman Mark Sullivan said Tuesday. He said none of the recalled engines was in use by an airline. The problem stemmed from a tightening of the blade-tip clearance in the engine's high-pressure compressor, a ``performance improvement'' Pratt introduced in February. Sullivan said the reduced clearance meant rotating compressor blades were rubbing a bit harder against rub strips inside the engine casing. Although there were no problems in ground testing for the first 38 improved-performance engines, the 39th engine had excessive rub, causing the compressor to stall. Sullivan said East Hartford-based Pratt & Whitney, a division of Hartfort-based United Technologies Corp., is satisfied that the problem has been corrected. He said the problem caused a ``very minimal disruption to our customers and their delivery schedules.'' Pratt has been marketing the PW4000 engine for the many jumbo jets expected to enter service in the 1990s. The first 38 engines had been shipped to aircraft builders Boeing Co. in Seattle, McDonnell Douglas Corp. in Long Beach, Calif., and Airbus Industrie in Toulouse, France, Sullivan said. To replace the recalled engines, Pratt delivered new PW4000s with the original blade-tip clearance, Sullivan said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders Attorneys to Testify Who Paid Fees in Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors hope testimony from five Oklahoma and Texas lawyers about the source of their legal fees will help in the drug conspiracy case against a Dallas businessman. The attorneys say the testimony comes under duress. ``I just think it's a shame,'' Tulsa lawyer John Echols said Tuesday. ``It's another example of what the war on drugs is doing to liberty in America.'' The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver ruled Monday the five must testify who paid their fees in the case that led to the 1987 federal drug conviction of four operators of a lab that made methamphetamine, or ``speed.'' ``You're going to wake up some day and wish you could talk to an attorney in confidence,'' Echols said. ``It may be that in any one case it doesn't threaten liberty, but if you transfer that to all cases, it does.'' Stanley Monroe, the other Tulsa attorney affected by the ruling, called the court's decision ``a sad day for the U.S. Constitution.'' ``Of course, I'm disappointed,'' said Monroe, who declined to comment further until he was able to review the 33-page ruling. The court order caps months of legal maneuvers that at one point sent the attorneys to prison on a contempt citation for refusal to testify before a grand jury. The appeals court stayed the contempt charge hours later, and ordered the attorneys freed. But Monday's ruling upheld U.S. District Judge James O. Ellison's decision to jail the five in Tulsa. U.S. Attorney Tony Graham said Tuesday he would not seek to have the attorneys jailed again. ``I don't intend to be vindictive,'' he said. ``If I were, I could ask they be put in jail now. But I don't intend to let this case linger.'' Federal prosecutors contend Dallas businessman James Coltharp may have paid the attorneys' fees. Graham said that information could be used to prove Coltharp operated a continuing criminal enterprise. Coltharp's federal trial on drug conspiracy and possession charges is scheduled to begin in August. His indictment was unsealed March 7 in Tulsa. Graham said if prosecutors were able to prove the attorneys' fees came from illegal drug transactions, ``then that money was the government's money from the moment the crook came in possession of it.'' Echols, Monroe and the other lawyers _ Scott Anderson, James Walker and Tex McConathy of Dallas _ argued fee information is a privileged communication between attorney and client. But the appeals court said there was no evidence that testifying to the grand jury would create a conflict between the attorneys and their clients. That test is one of several used in such cases. In its ruling, the three-judge panel said the attorneys must tell the grand jury the source of their legal fees, the amount of the fees and the names of anyone at least partly responsible for paying them. The attorneys also must provide all documents related to paying or accepting those fees, including checks, deposit slips, wire transfers and certain tax forms. The court refused to order the attorneys to provide copies of any fee contracts and passed the issue to the district court for a decision.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Further Consolidating Hold on Power
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In their public statements, delegates to the Communist Party congress are critical of many of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms. But in their hearts, most seem to believe the party would be lost without him. Despite hard-line attacks on Gorbachev's policy of perestroika, many delegates to the 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party say they expect to re-elect him as party general secretary, a post he has held since 1985. Five speakers from across the party spectrum endorsed Gorbachev from the podium on Wednesday, prompting several delegates to pass notes forward asking for a ban on the practice. ``Mikhail Sergeyevich (Gorbachev), please appeal to the delegates not to praise you and make an icon of you, because it creates the opposite reaction in the hall and the country,'' said one request, read by the acting chairman, Islam A. Karimov, first secretary of the Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan. The party, which seemed on the point of rupture in the weeks before the congress, was gathering in Gorbachev's banner _ for the time being. Members of the hard-line majority, who two weeks ago urged Gorbachev to relinquish his party job and keep the national presidency, had dropped that demand by the time the congress opened Monday. And members of the reformist Democratic Platform, consisting of about 100 of the nearly 4,700 delegates, were faltering in their earlier decision to quit the party. Andrei Godunov, a Democratic Platform delegate from Leningrad, said it was better to work for change within the party, and advocated a ``centrist'' and ``pragmatic'' course. Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak, a prominent reformer, told reporters in the lobby of the Palace of Congresses that ``there must be a platform of consolidation'' at the party meeting. He said he was leaning toward re-electing Gorbachev, although he opposed the idea of the same person heading both the party and the state. At the other end of the political spectrum, Leningrad hard-liner Boris Gidaspov delivered a surprisingly mild speech endorsing Gorbachev's effort to shift power from the party to government bodies and elected legislatures. Gorbachev's leading hard-line critic, Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, said on national television two weeks ago that Gorbachev should not continue to be the national president and head of the Communist Party. But on Tuesday, in a blistering critique of Gorbachev's reforms, Ligachev carefully avoided a personal attack on him, and did not repeat his demand to elect someone who could devote full time to party work. KGB chairman Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, who followed Ligachev's lead in attacking the reform movement, nevertheless told reporters he would back Gorbachev for general secretary. A reformer from the Ukraine, newspaper editor Vitaly G. Karpenko, joined conservatives in criticizing Gorbachev for ``combining the posts of president and party leader.'' But, he said: ``If we have to vote, I shall vote for Gorbachev, simply because there is no other alternative. ... It is Gorbachev who will be able to consolidate the country.'' Alexander Frolov, first secretary of the Surovsky region near the central Russian city of Tula, said: ``We have no other leader with more potential than Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev.'' Pressed to explain the mixed attitude to Gorbachev, Frolov fell back on an old Russian proverb: ``He who works is scolded.''

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Suspends Plans To Kill Seals In Response To Criticism
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday temporarily suspended plans to kill 30,000 seals in response to mounting criticism from local and foreign animal rights groups. Environment Minister Gert Kotze acknowledged that public outrage was behind his decision to reconsider plans to kill 25,000 Cape fur seal cubs and 5,000 adult male seals on the northwest coast later this month. ``This is not backtracking at all, but it is fair towards the public and conservationists to consider their objections, and I want time to do that,'' Kotze told the state-run South African Broadcasting Corp. The government has granted a five-year permit to kill seals to a Taiwanese business group, Jiuh Weh Industries. The company killed more than 3,000 seals last year, but the culling was not publicized and there were no protests. The seal bodies would be used for pet food while the males' genitals are prized as aphrodisiacs in the Far East. The government was to receive about 8 cents for each seal killed. The Earthlife Africa group said it welcomed the minister's decision to temporarily suspend the culling. But it added, ``we would be far happier if there was a permanent suspension _ until then we are carrying on with the battle.'' Many countries have outlawed the killing of seals, and animal rights groups say the practice should be banned in South Africa because of its cruelty. The seals are clubbed on the head, then stabbed in the heart so they bleed to death. South Africa has permitted the commerical culling of seals for more than 70 years. Kotze said plans for the culling may proceed later. ``The culling of wild animals is always unpleasant, but, unfortunately, cannot always be avoided,'' he told the South African Broadcasting Corp. The Department of Environmental Affairs had been defending its plans since local newspapers first reported the matter last week, igniting the protests. The department said the culling would not endanger the country's huge 1.2 million Cape Fur seal population. It said there was evidence the growing seal population had contributed to a decline in the number of jackass penguins and other sea animals as they competed for resources. The seals could damage the South African fishing industry, it said. The seals ``must therefore be seen as competitors with the (fishing) industry, and maintaining high population levels of seals could be costing this country both jobs and income,'' the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Game Show Host Bill Cullen Critically Ill With Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Former game show host Bill Cullen, whose many credits include ``The Price is Right'' and ``To Tell The Truth,'' is critically ill with cancer, his manager said Wednesday. ``He has known for several months,'' manager George Spota said. He said Cullen's family has requested the type of cancer not be revealed, and declined to give any specifics about the illness. Cullen, 69, is receiving round-the-clock medical care at his Los Angeles home, and has not been hospitalized for his disease, Spota said. ``All things being equal, it's always best to be at home in a situation like this,'' Spota said. The manager said Cullen's family this week decided to disclose the illness because rumors about the former game show host's sickness had begun to circulate. Cullen was the original host of ``The Price is Right,'' from 1957 to 1964, and has appeared in more than 35 network shows, including ``I've Got a Secret,'' ``To Tell the Truth,'' ``Eye Guess,'' and ``$25,000 Pyramid.'' Spota called Cullen ``the dean of American game shows.'' Cullen was working in a garage in Pittsburgh in 1939 when he got his first job in broadcasting, as an unpaid assistant disc jockey. He later became a regular announcer, earning $25 a week. In 1943, Cullen moved to New York and became a staff announcer with the CBS Radio Network. A year later, he became announcer for the ``Winner Take All'' game show.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Official in Moscow Reportedly Defects To Miami
DOC.TEXT: A senior Cuban economic official has defected through Spain and now is under U.S. protection in Miami, a Spanish newspaper reported today. The conservative daily ABC quoted Ramon Gonzalez Vergara as saying he could ``not endure to live in Havana, where there is no liberty.'' A Cuban-American leader in Miami said Gonzalez Vergara would be one of the highest civilian officials to defect from Cuba since Fidel Castro took power in 1959. There was no immediate U.S. comment on the report. Gonzalez Vergara, 46, left Madrid Tuesday for Miami under the care of U.S. agents, after first seeking political asylum in Spain, the newspaper said. The paper said Gonzalez Vergara had been under police protection in Spain since arriving June 25 by car from Moscow with his wife, two children and mother-in-law. In an interview before he left for Miami, Gonzalez Vergara told the paper that President Castro had named him to the post of deputy secretary of the Council on Mutual Economic Assistance, or Comecon, earlier this year. The Moscow-based Comecon coordinates economic policies of current and former Communist nations, including the Soviet Union, Eastern European countries, Cuba, Mongolia and Vietnam. Gonzalez Vergara told the paper he also had served as chief negotiator in Moscow for Soviet aid. The newspaper quoted Vergara as saying a new aid agreement with the Soviet Union is currently under discussion. U.S. officials estimate Soviet aid to Cuba is $4.3 billion a year, but have speculated that Kremlin budget-cutting and its ideological differences with the hard-line Havana government would lead to significant reductions. Gonzalez Vergara appeared to confirm some of this speculation. ``There will be aid on the part of the Soviet Union, but it will be distinct (from past amounts), given the complicated economic situation in the U.S.S.R.,'' he was quoted as saying. He characterized the Cuban economy as in ``a continued process of decline. ... I don't see, in the short term, any exit to the situation in Cuba. In Miami, Roberto Hernandez, vice president of the anti-Castro Cuban American National Foundation, said he had heard the defection report. If true, he said Gonzalez Vergara would be one of Cuba's higher-ranking civilian defectors. ``We receive any defectors with open arms,'' Hernandez said. ``As long as they behave and with dignity, they will have our support.'' The foundation, which is planning for a Cuba after Castro's rule, anticipates many defectors in coming months because of deterioration in the Cuban economy, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pigs Employed to Get Rid of Gulls
LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: A passel of pigs has been pressed into service where poison and cannon have failed _ to get rid of sea gulls that pose a nuisance and a health threat. In a one-month experiment, the Porker Patrol roams the half-mile breakwall along Lake Huron at Michigan Limestone Operations Ltd.'s Calcite plant. The swine are encouraged to eat gull eggs and chase the birds who for years have nested messily on the wall. The gull droppings combine with soil to make an ideal medium for growing histoplasma capsulatum, a fungus that can cause a lung disease when inhaled. In 1980, 138 workers became ill after a pulley stored on the breakwall was brought into the plant, prompting officials to launch bird-ridding efforts. Roosting areas were layered with clay to suffocate the fungus, permits were obtained letting workers break eggs and poison a few gulls, and noisemakers ranging up to a cannon were employed. All failed. Then Steve Truran, a plant manager, heard pigs had been used to control gulls on an island on the Upper Peninsula. Enter Harold Claus, an employee who raises Yorkshires and loaned the plant six, weighing about 100 pounds each. They're checked daily to be sure they're happy as, well, pigs in slop.

DOC.HEAD: 24 Nations Widen Aid to Eastern Europe
With AM-NATO Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two dozen wealthy nations on Wednesday extended their aid program for Poland and Hungary to four other East European nations that shed their communist ways and switched to market economies. Agreement to grant financial and other aid to Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and East Germany came at a meeting of foreign ministers of 24 nations, including those of the European Community, the United States, Japan, Canada and Australia. Romania was excluded because of doubts about its commitment to democratic reforms. Aid to the Soviet Union was discussed but no decision was taken. West Germany wants quick action on such aid. The United States and Japan, among others, do not. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said he wants to see more reforms in the Soviet Union. ``We take note of the fact that the Soviet Union is spending somewhere between 18 and 25 percent of its gross domestic product on military expenditures,'' he told reporters. Baker said the United States has problems the Soviet expenditure of between $9 billion and $15 billion a year ``to support regimes around the world that in the past at least have been hostile to the views and interests and principles of the United States.'' The Soviet Union, unlike the four countries added to the Western aid program Wednesday, has not asked for Western aid. The 24 nations also disagreed over creating a special fund, of possibly $10 billion to $12 billion, as a financial safety net for East European nations. Frans Andriessen, the meeting chairman and EC external relations commissioner, advanced the plan, but the ministers said this was mostly a question for existing institutions such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Wednesday's meeting fixed no specific aid figures. These will emerge as each donor makes pledges in food, money, credits, loan guarantees and other assistance. ``It was a conference designed to take stock, see whether we should and could decided to add countries'' to the aid package, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain told reporters. Aid to the new East European beneficiaries is bound to run into billions of dollars in the long term. The 24 nations already have pledged more than $12.4 billion in aid to Poland and Hungary since they began coordinating their aid program last summer. The aid effort is coordinated by the European Community's executive Commission. In a communique, the ministers said the four additional beneficiaries of aid merited help in view of the reforms they have begun ``based on the rule of law, the respect of human rights, the introduction of multiparty systems, the holding of free and fair elections and the establishment of market economies.'' Of Romania, where authorities relied on miners last month to suppress anti-government protests, they said: ``Recent events in Romania have not created the conditions in which the implementation of coordinated assistance should be extended to that country under present circumstances.'' Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany told reporters regarding aid to Moscow, ``We cannot expect the Soviet Union to resolve problems regarding the transition to a market economy on their own. ``They urgently need help, not only financial but in the form of advice. It is in the common Western interest to give this support.'' Officials from Poland, Hungary and the four new beneficiary countries attended the meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Germany to Send One Team to Olympics in 1992
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Germany will send a single team to the 1992 Olympics, the presidents of the two national Olympic committees announced Wednesday. It will be the first time since the 1964 Olympic games in Tokyo that Germany will compete with a unified team, and the merger is expected to make the already strong German teams a powerhouse single unit. Willi Daume, president of the West German Olympic Committee, and Joachim Weiskopf, president of the counterpart East German organization, said the two national Olympic committees will merge in December to oversee the formation of a single team. The merger will follow the political unification of the two German states, expected in early December. A united German team may be competing in international athletics as early as March 1991, authorities in East Berlin said. The two Olympic committee presidents said there was ``complete agreement'' between the two organisations about the decision. ``We had no dissenting opinions whatsoever,'' Daum said at a news conference in East Berlin. ``The unification will be completed by the two Olympic committees in an orderly fashion. We will be working intensively together in the coming weeks,'' Daume said. ``We're moving ahead quickly for the sake of the athletes. A fast merger is important in order to remove any uncertainty about who will make the team,'' said Weiskopf. ``As the two Germanys grow together there has been great concern over whether the athletes would feel shorted out of the competition for fewer places. Still we find great support among our sportsmen for forming one team from one country,'' he said. Weiskopf said it was not yet clear how the team would be selected and funded. He also said the international sport governing bodies would need to decide how a single German team would be represented in qualifying competitions for world and Olympic events. Separate teams representing both the National Olympic Committees have already participated in qualifying events in some sports. These events determine the rank and seeding for teams in major competitions such as the World Championships in individual sports and the Olympic Games. Both Olympic Committee presidents also said they support the choice of Berlin as site of the Olympics in 2000. ``The city of Berlin should be accepted by the International Olympic Committee for athletic and humanitarian reasons,'' said Daume. The groups, with active participation by athletes, will develop plans for the formation of a team for the 1992 Olympic Games in Albertville, France and Barcelona, Spain. East Germany won 127 medals at the Olympic games in 1988, and West Germany won 48. Together, a united German team would have won 175, 14 medals more than first-place Soviet Union. In the Tokyo Games in 1964, the single German team competed under the Olympic flag, with the Olympic anthem. ``It is the place for sports to lead in this direction. It is a great step towards peace,'' Weiskopf said.

DOC.HEAD: Documents Said To Show Spying on Poland's Non-Communist Government
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Ministry began a review Wednesday of documents that purportedly show its secret police spied on Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's government as it took power from the Communists. The documents were presented by the conservative, anti-Soviet political party Confederation for an Independent Poland, known by its Polish initials KPN. The papers are said to describe activity by the security services under Interior Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak, who remained in the new government as a Communist holdover. Dated from August and September 1989 _ Mazowiecki was elected on Aug. 24 and the East bloc's first non-communist government was seated on Sept. 12 _ the reports analyze the activities of Lech Walesa, potential splits in Solidarity, and debates by former Communist-linked parties that joined the new coalition. Krzysztof Krol, a KPN leader, on Tuesday made public some of the documents he said were passed to him by an unidentified informer. He said the originals were in his possession and would be handed over to the Justice Ministry. Spokesman Wojciech Garstka of the Interior Ministry went to KPN offices Wednesday and took notes on the documents. He expressed skepticism about their authenticity but reserved further comment. Krol said the papers ``prove that the security service under Gen. Kiszczak, at least with the knowledge of President Jaruzelski, spied on the government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki.'' Kiszczak was one of four Communists who remained in Mazowiecki's government. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party first secretary who imposed martial law in 1981, was given the presidency in July largely to smooth relations with the Soviet Union. The transitional concessions to the Communists resulted from historic negotiations that ended the party's 45-year grip on power. At the time, Poland was the only country that had gone so far. But as reform swept Eastern Europe, the continued presence of former Communists in the government became a source of controversy. Walesa, leader of the Solidarity union, and many Poles have agitated for their removal. The documents are addressed to Jaruzelski, Kiszczak and a senior Interior Ministry deputy, according to the Gazeta Wyborcza daily. Mazowiecki will go before parliament Friday to unveil a shakeup in his government, struggling to surmount an avalanche of criticism from farmers and Walesa. This was disclosed Wednesday by Solidarity parliamentary leader Bronislaw Geremek at a meeting of his caucus. Government spokesmen declined information on what changes were under consideration. The shock economic reform program embarked on by Mazowiecki and his deputy prime minister, Leszek Balcerowicz, has prompted harsh protests from various hard-hit sectors. Among those protesting the loudest are Poland's 2.5 million private farmers. Roman Bartoszcze, leader of the Polish Peasant Party which competes with other groups to represent rural interests, suggested Tuesday that his party's four ministers quit the government. Walesa wants Mazowiecki to replace holdover Communists in the government, hold early parliamentary and presidential elections and speed privatization of state enterprises. The government also is grappling with a major rail strike. Walesa is widely believed to be gearing up to run for president to replace Jaruzelski.

DOC.HEAD: A Hot Fourth in the East and the Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Record temperatures in the 90s and 100s made it a hot Fourth of July in sections of the Midwest and the East. Showers and thunderstorms fell over much of the country Wednesday. Hot weather has baked the central part of the country this week. By afternoon, the heat index combining temperature and humidity was 110 to 120 degrees across Missouri, 105 to 115 in Tennessee and 105 to 110 in Illinois and Wisconsin. Temperatures were 100 degrees or higher from northeast Oklahoma to southeast Nebraska and northwest Missouri. Readings were in the mid- to upper 90s across much of Indiana, the 90s across southern New England, central New York and Lower Michigan. It was also hot _ and often humid _ in much of Iowa, Kansas, Arkansas and northern Texas. The mercury hit 97 degrees in Erie, Pa., breaking the record for the date of 93 set in 1911. Records were broken in Syracuse, N.Y. (95 degrees, 94, 1955), and Alpena, Mich. (93, 88, 1988). Record-tying readings were reported in Baltimore (100 degrees, 1966); Cleveland (98, 1949); Detroit (97, 1949); Lambert Field at St. Louis (101, 1936); South Bend, Ind. (96, 1946). There were showers and thunderstorms in northeast New York, northern Vermont and northern New Hampshire, and from the upper Texas coast to northwest Florida and the Georgia coast. Thunderstorms and showers also fell in Lower Michigan, central and southwest Minnesota, southern South Dakota, northwest Iowa and northern Nebraska. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over southern New Mexico, southeast Arizona, Colorado and northwest Wyoming. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 31 degrees in West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 61 degrees at Great Falls, Mont., to 107 degrees in Wichita, Kan.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher, Mandela Agree to Disagree on Sanctions, Armed Struggle
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Nelson Mandela agreed they can do business together, even though their first meeting Wednesday failed to resolve differences over sanctions and the use of violence. Mrs. Thatcher welcomed the black South African leader, just three years after she denounced his African National Congress as a terrorist organization and said she would have nothing to do with it. ``They had a very good exchange. They agreed to keep in touch,'' said a spokesman for Mrs. Thatcher, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. ``The objective of establishing a personal relationship and rapport was fully achieved.'' Mandela, in an unusual description of the British leader whose toughness has earned her the reputation of ``the iron lady,'' called Mrs. Thatcher ``warm and gentle.'' The ANC's deputy president said he came away ``full of hope and strength'' from their three-hour meeting at the prime minister's residence at No. 10 Downing Street. Picking up on Mrs. Thatcher's well-known phrase that she could ``do business'' with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a reporter asked Mandela if he felt he could do business with her. ``Oh yes, I'm doing business with her now,'' he replied. ``We made progress ... We will keep in close contact.'' Unlike the other leaders on Mandela's world tour, Mrs. Thatcher openly opposes sanctions and wants those imposed by the European Community relaxed as a reward for South African President F.W. de Klerk's reform program. Like President Bush, Mrs. Thatcher also wants the ANC to renounce its armed struggle against the white minority government. Mandela has insisted that the sanctions remain in place for now to keep pressure on the South African government to dismantle the apartheid system. He also has said the ANC cannot renounce the armed struggle until blacks are guaranteed their political rights. Mandela had earlier expressed hope that his meeting with Mrs. Thatcher would narrow their differences on these two issues. But in the end they apparently agreed to disagree without debating the issues extensively. Asked about the ANC's armed struggle, Mandela said, ``We don't believe in force as a means of solving problems. If we resorted to force it's because we had no other option except to use force to defend our people.'' Mandela said the ANC is ``now mobilizing the country around peace,'' but could not rule out resorting to violence if existing conditions in South Africa do not change. Mrs. Thatcher's spokesman said the prime minister and Mandela agreed on the main issue of getting rid of apartheid and focused on ``the broader issue of the way ahead ... including the changes in apartheid laws, the economy and the importance of flexibility.'' Before the midday meeting, 300 anti-apartheid demonstrators rallied at the end of Downing Street and chanted as Mandela's limousine went through the gates blocking off the street. Mandela's two-day visit to Britain ended the European and North American legs of his 14-nation world tour. Before flying to Zambia, he said his meetings had surpassed expectations. ``Our message for the maintenance of sanctions has succeeded beyond our wildest dreams,'' he said. ``Our appeal for resources has been equally successful, in some respects again beyond our expectations.'' At his Wednesday morning meeting with leaders of the Confederation of British Industry, Mandela said he viewed nationalization as the method for redistributing South Africa's wealth to reduce the disparity in living standards between blacks and whites. But he added he was open to other options. On the economic issues, Mandela said his views and Mrs. Thatcher's ``were not altogether identical.'' The prime minister's spokesman said she opposed nationalization. British investment accounts for 50 percent of the total foreign investment in South Africa and two-way trade in 1989 was worth just over $3.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Rail Blockade, Last Soviet Sanction on Lithuania, Ending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7 grafs for final six grafs, 12-17, `Ms. Kontaugaite...' to UPDATE with quotes on crisis at party congress.
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin has lifted its 10-week ban on rail deliveries of key foodstuffs to Lithuania, the last remaining economic sanction imposed to stop the republic's independence drive, Lithuanian officials said Wednesday. The shipments should resume within two or three days, depending on the availability of rail cars, said Gintaras Yatkonis of the Lithuanian Council of Ministers' information center. On Tuesday, natural gas flowed back into the Baltic republic, according to Arune Kontaugaite of the parliament's information bureau. Oil shipments resumed Saturday, one day after the Lithuanian parliament agreed to freeze its March 11 declaration of independence. Its lawmakers agreed to the 100-day freeze so that negotiations on independence with Moscow can begin. The freeze will start once talks begin. Yatkonis said a telegram from the Soviet Transport Ministry addressed to Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene arrived late Tuesday, advising that the ban on railroad deliveries had been lifted. The ban was imposed to prevent Lithuanians from making private arrangements to receive sugar, coffee, fish, tea and citrus fruit from other parts of the Soviet Union and abroad. Yatkonis said the Council of Ministers has ordered that cargo be unloaded as quickly as possible so that the trains can return for new loads. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cut off all shipments of oil, most supplies of natural gas and other key items to Lithuania on April 18 after the republic refused to rescind its pro-independence laws. Lithuania's 3.8 million residents depend on the Soviet Union for their energy supplies. About 50,000 of Lithuania's estimated 1.1 million workers lost their jobs because of the shortages. Lithuania now is receiving 15 million cubic meters of gas a day, somewhat less than the normal level of 18.5 million cubic meters, Ms. Kontaugaite said. Lithuania's sole oil refinery was also working at less than full capacity. The government newspaper Izvestia said 7.6 million gallons of diesel fuel, 1.7 million gallons of gasoline and 44 million gallons of lubricating oil were being sent by rail and pipeline to Lithuania from the Russian and Byelorussian republics. The Lithuanian crisis came up at the Communist Party Congress in Moscow when Lithuanian party leaders still loyal to the Kremlin addressed the delegates to thunderous applause Wednesday. One Lithuanian party leader, Vladislav Shved, cautioned that what happened in Lithuania _ including the party split _ could easily happen elsewhere. ``Who's next?'' he asked, wondering aloud if this would be the last national Communist Party congress. ``We can't allow adventurists and neo-Stalinists to lord it over people,'' he said, referring to Lithuanian election victories by the pro-independence grass-roots movement Sajudis. He also partly blamed the party leadership in Moscow for allowing the situation in Lithuania to get out of hand. Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 after being independent since World War I.
