The official Soviet news agency Tass quoted Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis as telling Lithuanian Radio on Tuesday that ``long talks about talks'' will be needed before negotiations with the Kremlin begin. Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzkhov said the talks should be held at the prime-ministerial level.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Sets Dec. 2 as Date for All-German Elections
DOC.TEXT: The Germanys took another step toward full unification Wednesday when East Germany's cabinet voted to set Dec. 2 as the date for elections to an all-German parliament. Government spokesman Matthias Gehler made the announcement late Wednesday afternoon at a news conference in East Berlin. The East German Parliament is expected to approve the date and West Germany's governing coalition has also said it was prepared for all-German elections on Dec. 2. The announcement came as East German workers, concerned that unification would lead to high unemployment, held a series of warning strikes and West Germany's economics minister cautioned labor unions against unreasonable demands. An unspecified number of workers held strikes at at least four metalwork plants in northern East Germany, the state-run ADN news agency reported. Government sources in East Berlin said Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere will insist on separate elections in East Germany and West Germany. That coincides with West German proposals to have German elections on the same day, but separate balloting in the East and West. The issue has become important because under West German law parties must receive 5 percent of the vote to have representation in Parliament. There is no such cut-off in East Germany, and parties fear their chances would be reduced if they had to compete throughout East Germany and West Germany. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said if the 5 percent rule applied but East Germany and West Germany held separate elections, a party in West Germany would need 2 million votes for representation while an East German party would need only 575,000 votes. There are about 40 million eligible voters in West Germany, and approximately 12 million eligible voters in East Germany. He said separate elections would most likely be held and immediately after the polls closed East Germany would declare itself unified with West Germany under the West German constitution. Schaeuble, in a Wednesday interview with Deutschlandfunk radio, said any other arrangement would mean East German parties that have merged with their West German counterparts would not have a fair chance at gaining seats in an all-German parliament. On Friday, Schaeuble and East German Parliament State Secretary Guenther Krause are scheduled to begin talks in East Berlin on a second state treaty on the constitutional and legal aspects of unification. The two countries merged their economies and social systems on Sunday in the first major step toward unification. About 30,000 workers held brief warning strikes Monday, the first day East Germany went to work under a capitalistic system after 40 years of rigid socialism. Experts have predicted up to one-third of East Germany's 8,000 businesses could fold and as many as half its 8 million workers could lose their jobs under pressure from West Germany competition. East Germany's industrial base is antiquated and labor-intensive. Foreign capital has been slow in arriving.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Educator: `We Need Education for Democracy'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 14, bgng `Shanker said ...,' to restore first reference to Shanker. Pickup 15th graf, `But it...'
DOC.TEXT: Teacher unionists from Czechoslovakia and South Africa greeted U.S. teachers on the Fourth of July with a plea for help in planting the seeds of democratic education in their countries. Czechoslovakia is ``an atomized society whose traditional social ties are destroyed, a society believing in no values, a society that does not trust its teachers, politicians or priests,'' said Jan Urban, a former philosophy teacher driven from his post in 1977 for human rights activities but eventually rising to a leadership role in Czechoslovakia's revolution. Addressing the American Federation of Teachers annual convention being held here this week, Urban added: ``We need education for democracy.'' ``We have to face the hardships of a market economy that we know nothing of. What we need most is teacher training,'' Urban later told reporters. Several hours of the AFT general session Wednesday was dedicated to the spread of freedom in Eastern Europe and elsewhere in the last several years. The union detailed its activities in those nations in helping budding teacher unions and lending technical assistance to educators. Curtis Nkondo, a South African union leader and former teacher repeatedly jailed for anti-apartheid activities, raised a clenched right fist and told 3,200 cheering AFT delegates: ``Education in our country is so that blacks should remain hewers of wood and carriers of water forever.'' Some 60 foreign teacher delegates attended the AFT convention, marking the 744,000-member union's 75th anniversary. At a separate workshop on the AFT's international activities on Tuesday, representatives from half a dozen East bloc countries called on U.S. educators to come to their classrooms and help them understand and teach democratic values. They also asked delegates to send any old texts, printing machines or other supplies they could spare. ``We all have nothing. Everything you can send will be used,'' said Jaroslav Kalous, chairman of the School Committee of Civic Forum, one of the groups instrumental in bringing about free elections in Czechoslovakia last year. The challenge educators in Czechoslovakia and other fledgling democracies face in rebuilding trust in schools and other social institutions is as daunting as the revolutions themselves, Urban said. ``Teachers, once the pride of my country ... assumed the role of pitiful, if not hated servants of a hated ideology, which was incorporated into any subject they taught,'' he said. ``Before last year, much of the education in those countries was controlled politically through the communist states. Educators now find themselves with the daunting task of transforming those schools, the curricula, the way democracy is taught,'' said Eric Chenoweth, an official of AFT's Education for Democracy-International project, which has been sending technical aid to those schools. AFT President Albert Shanker said in an interview earlier this week: ``I think the whole celebration of the end of the cold war is especially important to the AFT. A lot of educational organizations over the years took the view that, well, democracy is just one form of government, and we would be ethnocentric to tout our system as the best. We did not take that view.'' But ``it is not the intention of our union to go over there and say, this is the American model, and that's it, no ifs or buts,'' insisted Chenoweth. The AFT has already helped support free teacher unions in Poland and Hungary. It is developing special texts and curricula explaining the concept of democracy. One is now being written by Diane Ravitch, an educational historian at Columbia Teachers College. The union also is trying to get its members to arrange classroom-to-classroom and school-to-school exchanges so that Eastern Europeans can learn U.S. educational concepts, and American kids can learn about the political upheavals in those countries. Such classroom-to-classroom projects already have led to letter exchanges between students in Poland and Anchorage, Alaska, McLean, Va., and Albuquerque, N.M., AFT officials said. Many teachers in formerly communist countries have grown to mistrust unions, said Zoltan Pokorni, of the new Hungarian Democratic Teachers Union. ``We need to learn how to get new members, how to organize collective bargaining, how to set up a democratic union structure,'' he said. Pokorni added, however, that East Bloc nations have no desire to simply copy U.S. labor and education customs with no regard to their countries' histories and traditions.

DOC.HEAD: Rostock Revokes Honorary Citizen Title Awarded Hitler
DOC.TEXT: City officials said Wednesday they had revoked an honorary citizen title awarded to Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler in 1933, the East German news agency ADN reported. A city committee also canceled the honorary citizen title of Friedrich Hildebrandt, Rostock's former Nazi Gauleiter, the district administrative chief of Mecklenburg in northern East Germany, ADN said. A city council member, Christoph Krummacher, told ADN, ``It is grotesque and shameful that it took 45 years after the war to strike the honorary titles of Nazi representatives.'' Also revoked were the honorary titles of former ousted Communist Party bureaucrats, ADN said. It said that following the city's first democratic elections in May, the new city council appointed a committee to investigate Rostock's list of honorary citizens ``in the spirit of law and order.'' The honor first went to Prussian Field Marshal Gebhard Leberecht von Bluecher, for his role in defeating Napoleon's main army near the Rhine River in early 1814 and eventually conquering Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian President Says Iran, Iraq Moving Closer To Peace
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said Wednesday Iran and Iraq have moved closer to peace following direct talks between their foreign ministers aimed at a formal ending to almost 10 years of hostilities. Speaking in an interview with the official Islamic Republic News Agency and state-run Tehran Radio, Rafsanjani said: ``What is clear to me is that we are now closer to peace compared to two months ago.'' ``The confidence of the two countries in the fact that the other side desires peace has become relatively greater,'' Rafsanjani added without elaboration. U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar mediated the Tuesday meeting in Geneva between the foreign ministers of Iran and Iraq, Ali Akbar Velayati and Tariq Aziz. It was the first face-to-face encounter between Velayati and Aziz since peace negotiations were launched in August 1988, a few days after a U.N.-mediated cease-fire halted the eight-year Persian Gulf War. Although Velayati and Aziz were present in the four rounds of peace talks held since 1988, the two men did not speak directly to each other, instead relaying their comments through Perez de Cuellar. The earlier negotiations stalled almost immediately over the question of priorities. Iran insisted on an Iraqi withdrawal from territories occupied in the last weeks of the war. Iraq insisted that Iran agree first to the dredging of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway of war debris. The waterway marks the southern border of the two nations. The common border ran down the middle of the channel before the war but Iraq has demanded full sovereignty over the Shatt-al-Arab, its main outlet to the gulf. Before leaving Geneva Wednesday, Velayati told reporters he was optimstic that the talks would move ahead. ``During the meeting we found out that Iraq and Iran, both of them, now are more flexible than in the past,'' he said without elaborating. Perez de Cuellar, who in previous talks relayed statements between the two ministers, said Tuesday's meeting was a ``psychological breakthrough'' though nothing substantive was discussed.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Cut Two Paintings, One a Renoir, From Their Frames
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 4th pvs, `Officials noted...' to ADD both museums run by government agency.
DOC.TEXT: In bold, daytime operations, thieves cut two paintings from their frames at two Paris museums on Wednesday, one a Renoir stolen from the Louvre, officials said. Both paintings, Renoir's ``Portrait of a Seated Woman'' and Hebert's ``Portrait of Monaluccia,'' were small format paintings. Such paintings are often chosen by thieves because they can be easily concealed. The theft of the Renoir, which had been hanging in the Louvre's third-floor Pavillon de Flore gallery, was discovered about 2:15 p.m., officials said. The Hebert was discovered missing from the Ernest Hebert Museum, across the Seine River on the Left Bank, about an hour later. Officials said both paintings were stolen during the day, presumably after the museums had opened. Officials noted that in both cases the paintings had been cut from their frames, but could not immediately say whether the thefts were related. Both museums are run by the Directory of French Museums, a government agency. ``Portrait of a Seated Woman,'' painted between 1916-1918, measures 13.5 by 10.5 inches. Hebert's work, painted around 1870, measures 14} by 12} inches. A catalogue of stolen paintings, recently published by the Interior Ministry, shows that small format paintings are the most common targets. The catalogue also shows that 58 percent of the paintings stolen from French museums between 1979 and 1989 were taken from the stocks. About 40 percent of the stolen paintings had been on display. The last Paris museum theft that occurred during the day was Oct. 27, 1985, when a gang of armed thieves held up the Marmottan Museum, stealing a number of impressionist works, including Claude Monet's ``Impression Sunrise,'' which inspired the name for the impressionist movement. The painting has not been recovered.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Learn Where the Beef Is
DOC.TEXT: First came the West German mark, then the Whopper. The first Burger King fast food restaurant in East Germany opened its doors Wednesday, treating East Germans to ``original hamburgers, American apple-pastries and the world-famous `Whopper,''' according to the East German news agency ADN. The fast food outlet, near the main Dresden train station, is co-run by the East German company, Mitropa, ADN said. Burger King and Mitropa plan to open restaurants throughout East Germany, especially at train stations and on the autobahns, Burger King European vice-president John M. Rollo said, according to ADN. ADN described the Whopper sandwich, cornerstone of the fast food restaurant, as a ``grilled beaf steak, originally garnished, served in a sesame roll.'' East Germans paid for their meals with the new mark, which since Sunday has circulated in both Germanys as part of the economic unification of the two countries. The news agency carried no other details.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, 200 Arrested in World Cup Celebration
DOC.TEXT: Two people were killed and nearly 200 arrested after street celebrations turned violent following Argentina's 4-3 victory over Italy in World Cup soccer, police said Wednesday. A gang of young men beat a 54-year-old man to death after he refused to hand over an Argentine flag he was waving, police said. The incident occurred in Florencio Varela, 18 miles south of Buenos Aires. In a western suburb of Buenos Aires, a 22-year-old man was fatally struck by what appeared to be a stray bullet as he celebrated the victory. In Buenos Aires, thousands of fans took to the streets Tuesday night to celebrate the defending champion's advance to the World Cup finals. The celebrating turned chaotic when several hundred youths began looting shops. Police fired tear gas at the rioters, who responded with stones and bottles. Police said nearly 200 youths were arrested, and 165 remained in jail Wednesday facing charges of robbery, resisting arrest and disturbing the peace. Business returned to usual Wednesday morning. Argentina faces West Germany in the World Cup final Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Authorities Agree to Meet Foreign Diplomat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6 grafs for grafs 8-12, `The unrest ...' to UPDATE with higher refugee figure, relief plane turned back. Pickup 13th pvs, `In Warsaw...' Minor editing to conform, trim
DOC.TEXT: Albanian authorities agreed to meet Wednesday with a representative of foreign embassies sheltering more than 200 asylum-seekers who have issued one of the biggest rebuffs to 45 years of orthodox Communist rule. In Vienna, an Albanian diplomat said on condition of anonymity that all foreign embassies in Tirana, the Albaninan capital, were assured anyone wishing to leave would receive a passport. He indicated there would be no reprisals. Last week, a few Albanians hoping to leave their impoverished, isolated country of 3.2 million sought political asylum at embassies. Word of their success apparently spread by word of mouth, and on Monday, their numbers swelled. Truckloads crashed through embassy gates or clambered over walls. Some Albanians were injured in their desperate attempt to gain entry. At least three were shot and wounded by agents of the feared secret police, diplomats said on condition of anonymity. In Bonn, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said the West German Embassy in Tirana had received ``reports that the Albanian guards carried away bodies which didn't move. We don't know if they were dead or not.'' The spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the reports, which came from people who said they witnessed the scene, could not be confirmed by the embassy. The Albanian government, led by Ramiz Alia, also said people were wounded, but gave no figures. It described the asylum-seekers as either criminals or deluded adolescents, in a dispatch from ATA, the Albanian state agency. Tanjug, the official Yugoslav news agency, said 214 Albanians who want to leave the country have taken refuge in about a dozen foreign diplomatic missions in Tirana. In a telephone interview Wednesday with The Associated Press in Ankara, the Turkish ambassador in Tirana, Teoman Surenkok, gave the total number of refuge-seekers as 243. The unrest is the latest sign that the people are frustrated by Albania's refusal to follow other Eastern European countries in adopting democratic reforms. Albanian officials arranged to meet with Yugoslav Ambassador Novak Pribicevic, who was empowered to represent all foreign missions harboring Albanians, according to Austria's APA news agency. In addition, Tanjug cited unidentified Albanian sources as saying the Communist Party Central Committee planned an emergency meeting shortly. Foreign ambassadors accredited to Tirana agreed to jointly seek a solution to the plight of Albanians in their embassies. Hanns Schumacher, a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Bonn, said Albanian authorities refused on Wednesday to grant landing permission for a cargo plane carrying relief goods for the West German Embassy, where 86 Albanians sought refuge. He said Bonn would pursue the matter Thursday. In Warsaw, a Foreign Ministry official said 41 Albanians sought refuge in the Polish Embassy. Andrzej Barzyk said Poland ``under no circumstances'' would hand the refugees back to Albanian authorities ``if there are no guarantees their rights are to be respected.'' Other embassies echoed those sentiments. Cuba reportedly ejected some Albanians, and in an apparent protest, a bomb was thrown at the Cuban Embassy late Tuesday, causing damage but no injuries. The Hungarian Foreign Ministry said Albanian authorities pledged to issue passports to the four men holed up in Budapest's embassy. But a ministry spokesman said the four refused to leave the embassy. The East German news agency ADN said similar guarantees had been given to other embassies where Albanians sought refuge. Most of the 30 Albanians in Tirana's Turkish Embassy left the mission after being promised exit papers, diplomats said. The Albanian refugee flight recalled a similar situation last year when East Germans seeking safe passage to the West filled embassies in other East European states. The move helped fuel the peaceful revolution that toppled Communist rule in East Germany. The situation in Albania indicated authorities may have done too little too late to ease restrictions. Under reforms begun in May, starting Tuesday, Albanians who previously were not allowed to travel freely are entitled to passports; a ban on religion has been lifted, as has the death penalty for defectors; and modest economic retooling has been promised. The country has also expressed interest in broadening ties with other nations. But the Communist monopoly on power continues. The leadership has firmly rejected the political plurality now practiced in all former Soviet satellite nations. Foreign governments have protested that shots were fired at their missions' doorsteps, and European Community officials discussed the Albanian situation in Brussels, Belgium. Italy's foreign minister asked the United Nations to act on what he said was Albania's violations of international law and human rights. Bulgaria expressed ``astonishment'' over the arrest of one would-be asylum seeker within its embassy compound. West Germany protested the ``brutal behavior'' of Albanian guards who fired on people trying to enter the embassies. Turkey's Surenkok said large crowds gathered briefly outside the embassy to applaud asylum-seekers. He said asylum-seekers complained about lack of political freedom and the rigid economy.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to Quit in Two Years if Reforms Fail
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The following is a comment that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made to a reporter from Britain's Channel 4 TV during the Communist Party's 28th Congress in Moscow. The comment, translated by the television network from Russian, followed attacks on Gorbachev and pro-reform delegates by conservative Communists.

``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership has to go of its own accord _ the same way it is showing courage now. ``I said this to our delegates and I want to say it to you, when people want to cast a shadow on us and call into question our plans and intentions. Some people say they grabbed power and are holding onto it. No, we're not.''

DOC.HEAD: Police To Begin Crackdown on Civic Center Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Art Agnos has ordered police to break up a sprawling encampment of homeless people just outside City Hall, substituting a resettlement program critics call insufficient. Agnos' order, which takes effect Friday, directs police to begin enforcing laws against sleeping in public places. The mayor, an unabashed liberal Democrat, tolerated the encampment of as many as 350 people for two years because he said there was no workable alternative. This week, the city took over operation of two shelters intended to provide comprehensive services such as alcohol detoxification and job counseling to the homeless. City officials say the plan is a new approach of offering a ``port of re-entry'' to society. Advocates for the homeless charge that the two service shelters are insufficient and understaffed, and won't solve the city's housing problem. They say the Agnos program will reshuffle the homeless by forcing out 215 people staying in a private shelter taken over by the city. They said the new policy will break up couples and force many people into jails, doorways or alleys. ``What's going to happen Friday night is San Francisco will start criminalizing homelessness,'' said Josh Brandon of the Coalition on Homelessness. ``The city tells you there are 329 beds in our (new) system. What they neglect to tell you is 215 are already full,'' Brandon said. Only men will receive beds in the new multiservice shelters during the first few weeks of the program. Women will continue to be placed in existing housing programs until beds are added to the new shelters by mid- to late summer. Some women say they shun the existing programs because they involve placement in seedy, unsafe hotels or have too many restrictions. Cristina Jaskula, who has been living outside City Hall since February, says she and her husband would rather remain ``free'' than be separated in order to have shelter. ``A shelter is like being in prison,'' said Jaskula, 42. ``There's no freedom of movement.'' In the past two years, the number of homeless people in the tree-shaded Civic Center park has grown into the hundreds. It has been dubbed ``Camp Agnos'' by some of its residents and critics, including city employees who used to have lunch in the park but have been driven away by the shabbiness and human waste. Most campers have packed up their tents, blankets and other belongings since the eviction order, which told them to report to an intake office on Polk Street. Prior to the holiday Wednesday, 82 people had reported, and 64 men were sent to a new shelter nine blocks from the Civic Center. One shelter, which opened Monday night, accommodates 110 men and will add 90 beds for women by August, officials said. The 215 men at the shelter the city took over will be ``transitioned'' out to make way for new occupants, including women, said Judy Schutzman, the city's co-director of the centers. Ten beds are to be added next month, she said. City officials say the transition means finding housing for the men. Advocates for the homeless are doubtful. Food Not Bombs, a group that feeds the homeless, plans to stage an all-night protest outside Agnos' home Friday night _ bringing homeless people to the mayor's doorstep.

DOC.HEAD: Romania, Lukanov Move To Resolve Ecological Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Romania and Bulgaria on Wednesday moved to resolve an ecological dispute that has long soured relations between them. Prime ministers Petre Roman of Romania and Andrei Lukanov of Bulgaria agreed at a meeting to set up a joint commission that will work toward ``diminishing and stopping the pollution caused by the Giurgiu Chemical Plant and the Bulgarian nuclear facility near the border.'' The two sides undertook to provide each other with exact data on the disputed facilities within 20 days and to complete a convention for protecting the environment along their border before August. They said world experts will be asked ``to assess the degree of pollution at the frontier and the measures necessary for removing the pollution.'' The agreement was announced in a communique released after the meeting. Thousands of Bulgarians demonstrated along the frontier last month demanding closure of the Giurgiu plant. Romanians in turn accused the Bulgarians of having insufficient safety standards at their nearby nuclear plant. About 500 Bulgarians kept up a protest on their side of the border for the third day Wednesday, and at 6 p.m. blocked Romania-bound traffic for two hours. Romania's House of Deputies meanwhile approved Roman's liberal program of ``radical reform'' on Wednesday with only 12 of its 296 members opposed. President Ion Iliescu approved the program Tuesday. In a televised Fourth of July address, U.S. Ambassador Alan Green, Jr. warned the Romanian government that ``expressions of adherence to democratic ideas are not enough.'' ``Democracy is not established by rhetoric or good intentions alone. These must be accompanied by concrete steps to secure the conrnerstones of freedom ... A democratic government ... encourages peaceful dissent, it guarantees freedom of expression.'' Washington has criticized last month's government action in suppressing a 53-day opposition rally in central Bucharest, especially the use of miners from outside Bucharest to track down and beat opposition students and intellectuals.

DOC.HEAD: NEC Unveils Fastest Mainframe Computer
LaserPhoto TOK4
DOC.TEXT: Japan's NEC Corp. on Wednesday unveiling what it called the world's fastest general-purpose computer, saying it has moved ahead of its U.S. and Japanese rivals. The company said its new ACOS System 3800 computers were designed for maximum speed and memory-processing capacity. The top of the line, the model 60, is capable of speeds of up to 500 million instructions per second and can store up to 128 trillion bits of data _ the equivalent of about 200,000 years of a typical English-language newspaper, NEC said. Last month, Japan's Hitachi Ltd. announced its M-880 series of mainframe computers, with a maximum speed of 155 million instructions per second, which it said was then the fastest in the world. IBM's top model has a speed of 122 million instructions per second, it said. The Hitachi computers are compatible with IBM machines, while NEC's mainframes are not, making direct comparisons difficult. But the new NEC computers appeared to put the company significantly ahead of its rivals in the competition for top speed. IBM, the world's largest maker of computers, is reportedly developing a new mainframe computer expected to debut next year. General-purpose mainframe computers are intended for varied office and business use, while supercomputers are designed specifically for scientific calculations and therefore can operate more rapidly. NEC's executive vice president, Yukio Mizuno, said the System 3800 computers are designed to handle large data bases for one or more companies. ``Up until now, large mainframes generally served a single company, but increasingly they are being used to create networks between several companies, such as a manufacturer and its wholesalers,'' he said. Seven versions of the computers are available, ranging from one to six processors, the company said. A processor is the ``brain'' of a computer, and several processors give a machine an ability to process information more rapidly. Monthly lease fees range from $330,000 to $1.9 million, NEC said. It said it plans to sell about 200 systems over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Tanker Runs Aground
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian tanker loaded with oil ran aground and punctured its hull Wednesday between the Detroit River and Lake Erie, but a U.S. Coast Guard officer said no fuel spilled. The 330-foot tanker Nancy Gauchier, carrying 4,300 tons of oil, lost power while passing through the Livingstone Channel and ran onto rocks, said Petty Officer Steve Attaway. The tanker has a double hull, as required by Canadian law. The inner hull wasn't punctured, so there was no release of oil, Attaway said. The ship regained power and was anchored six miles out in Lake Erie while officials assessed the damage. Attaway said he was unsure how big the hole was. The Canadian Coast Guard decided the vessel should remain where it is until weather improves. ``At that point, she will proceed with a tug escort through Canadian waters to Port Colborne for offloading and survey by Canadian Coast Guard,'' Attaway said. The channel is south of Windsor, which is just across the Detroit River from Detroit, and runs from the lake to the river. It's on the Canadian side of the lake and river border. The ship, owned by Socanav Inc. of Montreal, was headed from Sarnia to Port Colborne.

DOC.HEAD: Tourism Minister Quits Under Fire
DOC.TEXT: Tourism Minister Olivier Stirn resigned Wednesday following criticism over a political meeting he organized in which people were paid to fill up a roomful of empty seats. The office of Socialist Premier Michel Rocard announced the resignation in the late evening, just hours after Stirn told French TV news that he would not step down. The brief statement said Stirn was resigning at his own request and that Minister for Foreign Trade Jean-Marie Rausch would take over the tourism duties. Stirn, in his own statement later, said he was a victim of the ``political game'' and media pressure. He attributed the incident to a ``small error by an entourage without bad intentions.'' ``I am and remain a faithful servant of the state,'' he said. The French media disclosed Tuesday night, at the end of a two-day symposium addressed by several government ministers, that several hundred people had been hired to fill up an empty house. Stirn, who sponsored the symposium entitled ``Headquarters for Progress,'' admitted that was the case but said the hiring was done without his knowledge by overzealous party members. ``About 50 unemployed were paid,'' he said. ``I think it is regrettable, but we should not get dramatic about it.'' Numerous government ministers and opposition members said Stirn should resign to avoid disgracing all politicians. Some called the incident ``scandalous'' and ``revolting.'' The symposium opened Monday morning to a roomful of 37 people, including participants, journalists and photographers. By afternoon, only about 20 people were present, according to press reports, a situation repeated Tuesday morning. But by mid-afternoon, however, the house was suddenly full. People applauded vigorously during speeches by Socialist Party First Secretary Pierre Mauroy, former Premier Laurent Fabius and others. But the house emptied when Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement rose to speak, reporters at the symposium said. It was subsequently revealed that the audience's three-hour contract expired at 6:15 p.m., just as the defense minister began his speech. Stirn later conceded that two party members, embarrassed by the lack of attendance, had contracted without his knowledge with two agencies which furnish people for crowd events. The incident was disclosed accidentally after a cameraman was approached by a person leaving the meeting, asking for his envelope of 300 francs, or $55, French TV reported.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli-Backed Militia Kills Three Arab Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Israeli-backed Lebanese militiamen killed three Arab guerrillas after they spotted them outside the buffer zone north of Israel's border with Lebanon, the army said Wednesday. The South Lebanon Army militiamen opened fire on a group of guerrillas near the town of Jazzin Tuesday night after a mine exploded in the area, the army said. The militia searched the area of the shooting after daylight Wednesday and discovered three bodies of guerrillas, the army reported. The milita sustained no casualties, the military said. Army radio said the guerrillas were believed to be members of the Fatah faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization. That faction is led by PLO chairman Yasser Arafat. The incident occurred just north of Israel's self-proclaimed security zone. The 2,500-member South Lebanon Army patrols the zone with the aid of more than 1,000 Israeli troops. The 2-to-10-mile wide strip was set up by Israel after it withdrew the bulk of its invasion force from Lebanon in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Scientist Seeking Re-Entry to U.S. Meets With Congressman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Deported Scientist listed in News Advisory.
DOC.TEXT: A NASA rocket scientist and alleged Nazi war criminal who wants to return to the United States joined a congressman at a news conference Wednesday just a half-mile over the U.S. border. Rep. James Traficant, D-Ohio, said Arthur Rudolph, who played a major role in designing and building the rocket that took Americans to the moon, passed a lie-detector test in which he denied any involvement in Nazi war crimes. Traficant said Rudolph, who voluntarily left the United States in 1984 in a deal with the U.S. government, deserves a hearing on his request to return. ``Arthur Rudolph without question answered truthfully to all of these questions,'' Traficant told the news conference in a hotel. ``Had Dr. Rudolph failed, I would not be here today.'' The Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, which has investigated alleged Nazi war criminals living in the United States, has ``run roughshod over this particular fellow,'' Traficant said. ``If all of their cases, once analyzed, look like this case and some others that are into focus, then there should be an investigation into the Office of Special Investigations.'' Traficant has also defended John Demjanjuk, a retired Cleveland auto worker on death row in Israel who was convicted of Nazi atrocities. The congressman has sharply criticized the OSI for trying to discredit some witnesses in the Demjanjuk case. The OSI accused Rudolph of working thousands of slave laborers to death building Nazi V-2 missiles during World War II. After the war, the U.S. Army brought into this country Rudolph and more than 100 other members of the Wernher von Braun rocket team. Rudolph became chief coordinator for the Saturn V rocket, supervising its planning, design, testing and production for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. But in 1984, facing what the OSI said was evidence of his involvement in war crimes, Rudolph voluntarily renounced the U.S. citizenship he had been granted, admitted his complicity in war crimes and left the country in a deal that let him keep his NASA pension. Now 84, Rudolph sat beside Traficant as the congressman said the scientist was coerced into the agreement and wants to return to the United States because he does not want to be remembered as a war criminal. ``Dr. Rudolph has decided that history and how they'll record his name may be more important than the hassles which he'll undertake,'' Traficant said. Rudolph, blinking under camera flashes and television lights, refused to address the media, saying, ``I've been advised by my attorney not to answer any questions.'' Rudolph has signed a document authorizing the OSI to turn over any evidence of his involvement in war crimes to Traficant, the congressman said. ``Under the waiver of the Privacy Act, I will expect to be receiving from OSI all of its so-called sealed evidence,'' Traficant said. OSI head Neal M. Sher said in 1984 that Rudolph, while chief operations director for German V-2 missile production, participated in the persecution of forced laborers, of whom as many as 20,000 are estimated to have died. Sher has described Rudolph, who said he belonged to the Nazi party, as a self-confessed war criminal. But Traficant claims an Army investigation absolved Rudolph of war crimes in 1947. On Tuesday, Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said the department still considers valid the agreement Rudolph signed in 1984. But Rudolph claims that not only did he not persecute any laborers, he was an advocate for those suffering. After leaving the United States, Rudolph went to West Germany, where a government attempt to prosecute him for war crimes failed to turn up enough evidence. Rudolph arrived in Canada on Sunday and faces an immigration hearing in Toronto on Friday to determine if he can stay. Asked about reports Rudolph might try to enter the United States illegally, Traficant said Rudolph ``is not going to be breaking any laws.''

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Has A Job For You
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf, ``He said,'' to clarify that 20,000 job openings are expected over next 30 years; DELETES following graf: ``Duffy said,'' because statement makes no sense as given and it has not been possible to get clarification. There are far more than 800 science graduates annually
DOC.TEXT: The government is looking for a few good men and women to help clean up radioactive contamination at its nuclear weapons plants over the next 30 years. The job is challenging, with plenty of time outdoors. And officials guarantee a career for just about any college science student. The Department of Energy said it will take 50 percent more money and twice as many people as previously estimated to carry out a five-year cleanup plan at the waste sites. ``We've got to convince the people in the colleges to go and look at this as the career of the future... It's an exciting career, an interesting career, one that is involved with new technology,'' said Leo Duffy, head of DOE's cleanup office. He said there are at least 20,000 job openings over the next 30 years in the field and an annual budget in billions of dollars. He said the department intends to do a better job of publicizing the benefits of working as an environmental scientist, seeking better ways to contain and dispose of radioactive waste. ``Environmentally, they are going to be out there in the wide open spaces of the West... the sage brush, the rabbits and the elk and the antelope,'' he said. In a typical day, he said, a scientist would ``go to work in the morning in a jeep pulling a boat... go fishing for awhile, picking up samples of fish, trapping some animals and taking them back to the laboratory.'' As the department tries to lure workers into the field, Duffy said it will face the same image problems it faces every day. ``Technology does not always interest every man and woman,'' he said. ``Distrust in Department of Energy past practices is a problem. The fact you've got radioactivity is a major problem,'' Duffy said the lack of scientists and adequate technology are the biggest hurdles to cleaning up weapons plants that have dumped high-level radioactivity into the soil and water. ``We've got a problem,'' he said. ``We have a major program initiated for fiscal year 1990 of approximately $2.6 billion... and we don't have the capability...to support it.'' The government now estimates cleanup costs for 1991-1995 will be $28.6 billion, nearly 50 percent more than the $19.5 billion projected last fall. The General Accounting Office predicts costs will total $150 billion to $200 billion over the life of the 30-year project. ``The worst thing we can do is go out and throw money at this program and wind up with a scandal in three years that will damage both the department's credibility and the ability to clean up our sites,'' Duffy said. In addition to recruiting and training workers, Duffy said the DOE has to do a better job of persuading private entrepreneurs to get into the business. The department said the fear of being sued is deterring businesses from getting involved in the cleanup. ``Anybody who makes a mistake in those kind of areas is betting on their company,'' Duffy said. ``When we are talking about the kind of money to clean up an individual site _ anywhere from $1 billion to $25 billion _ there are not too many companies in the United States that are willing to bet their assets on that.''

DOC.HEAD: Priest Arrested for Child Pornography
DOC.TEXT: A 77-year-old priest has been charged with taking pornographic pictures of children in the town in central France where he served for 42 years, court and church officials said Wednesday. The British-born priest, Nicolas Glencross, was charged Saturday by a Paris judge with inciting minors into lewd behavior. He has been jailed pending further court proceedings. The charges were confirmed Wednesday by Glencross' superior, Roman Catholic Bishop Michel Moutel. ``Priests are men, with their weaknesses and their limits,'' Moutel said. ``It's proper that they can be called to account for their acts.'' Glencross was charged with taking photographs of children, mostly boys, for use in pornographic publications which were uncovered by Paris police, court officials said. Glencross was arrested eight days ago in the Loire Valley town of Saint-Leger-des-Vignes, where he had been a priest since 1948. He was brought to Paris for questioning before formally charges were issued Saturday. According to news reports, Glencross was well-known in the town for his paintings and drawings of children, some of which were shown in exhibitions. He customarily asked to take photographs of the children before commencing the portraits, townspeople said.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Told To Face Facts About School Woes
With AM-Teachers
DOC.TEXT: Teachers must face facts on how badly U.S. schools are performing and work harder to persuade administrators to embrace reform, teacher union leader Albert Shanker said Wednesday. ``Most of our members don't believe this. It isn't my school that's bad, it's that big city down the road,'' Shanker said in his keynote address at the American Federation of Teachers annual convention. ``We ought to look at the facts,'' he said. ``We shouldn't be the ones making believe that nothing's wrong.'' He cited statistics showing that 95 percent of Japanese high school graduates do math as well as the top 5 percent of U.S. students. And he urged teachers to get the reform ball rolling by helping create at least one school per district that looks genuinely different from those operating today. ``Let's have schools in which teachers do very little talking, where kids are doing the work, where they can do it over different periods of time, where they can work either privately or in groups. And let's put as much technology in schools as we can,'' Shanker said. Too often, schools have tried one of these reform ideas, but not most or all of them, Shanker said. While exhorting the 3,200 teacher delegates to go back home and level with the public about how serious the education crisis is, Shanker renewed his attacks on school administrators for failing to respond to union reform initiatives. ``I'm very disappointed because we're out there alone. I don't sense very much enthusiasm on the part of management,'' he said in an hourlong address. The 744,000-member AFT's four-day annual gathering concludes Thursday. The 2 million-member National Education Association will hold its annual convention Thursday through Sunday. Among the day's other events, AFT delegates approved a union boycott of the Japanese automakers Nissan, Honda and Isuzu for allegedly resisting unionization in its U.S. plants. And Shanker, 61, was elected unopposed to a ninth two-year term as AFT president. Union favorite Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., also addressed AFT delegates, and won frequent applause for blasts at President Bush for failing to fund education reforms. ``If the administration has its way, and we keep on short-changing reform, the next generation of students won't even be able to read their president's lips,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Capitol Pledges Legal Help to Retailers Over Explicit Warning Labels
DOC.TEXT: Capitol Records promised to provide legal help to store operators threatened with arrest for selling its recordings that bear labels warning consumers of sexually explicit lyrics. ``The music industry has proven its willingness to address the issue of explicit material through our use of voluntary, uniform stickers,'' Capitol President Hale Milgrim said in a statement released Tuesday. ``However, it is becoming evident that other forces see stickering as an excuse to censor artists,'' Milgrim said. ``This is intolerable and a violation of the First Amendment.'' Milgrim said some retailers are afraid to order recordings with the stickers. To allay those fears, Capitol will provide lawyers for anyone threatened with harassment or arrest for selling its labeled recordings, he said. Capitol said it will serve notice of that promise with a label of a different kind: ``Retailers: Capitol records vehemently opposes censorship of artistic expression and will assist in the defense of any attempt to stop the legitimate sale of this LP-CD-cassette.'' ``We feel that an artist has the right to express his or her distinctive viewpoints through music and that retailers should be able to make this music available to the public without the fear of being arrested or harassed,'' Milgrim said. The first Capitol records carrying the voluntary industry label and the retailer notification label will be released in August. They are releases by C.P.O. and King Tee as well as the ``Return of Superfly'' soundtrack.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Damages Offices of Anti-Apartheid Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: A bomb damaged the offices of an anti-apartheid newspaper Wednesday, a day after right-wing extremists claimed responsibility for recent attacks against whites wanting to end segregation. The pre-dawn explosion at the empty offices of the Afrikaans-language newspaper Vrye Weekblad was the fifth attack in as many nights against whites opposed to apartheid. The bomb caused only minor damage. No one has been hurt in any of the explosions, all in Johannesburg. A man claiming to belong to a right-wing extremist group, the White Wolves, said his organization was responsible for the recent blasts. He made the claim in a phone call Tuesday to The Citizen, a pro-government newspaper. The editor of Vrye Weekblad, Max du Preez, said an unidentified caller phoned him at home Wednesday morning and warned that the attack was ''only a beginning.'' The attacks on the four preceding nights were at the office and the home of one anti-apartheid city council member, at the home of another city council member and at a synagogue. The synagogue was covered with graffiti comparing Jews to the African National Congress, the country's leading black opposition group. A number of Jews are active in anti-apartheid groups. The caller to The Citizen newspaper said all the places attacked were considered part of ''the same target.'' The Johannesburg City Council said security had been tightened at the homes of all 51 council members. The council is controlled by the anti-apartheid Democratic Party. The White Wolves have claimed responsibilty for several attacks in the past two years. Police say they have not been able to determine if such an organization actually exists, or if white extremists acting independently have simply adopted the name. President F.W. de Klerk's reforms and stated intention of ending apartheid have outraged right-wing whites, who have vowed to resist any lessening of white privilege. Both de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela have warned that heavily armed right-wing whites could undermine black-white efforts to negotiate a new constitution and end apartheid. In another development, a member of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party said the party would defy a new law requiring public facilities be open to all races. Parliament last month repealed the law permitting the segregation of libraries, swimming pools and other facilities, and local municipalities have until Oct. 15 to comply. But Pikkie Coetzee, a member of Parliament, said the facilities won't be integrated in the dozens of towns where the Conservatives control local councils. ``People are going to hate each other, and there could be conflict,'' Coetzee told The Star newspaper of Johannesburg. ''If hundreds of blacks arrive (to use facilities), there just won't be space.'' The Conservatives, the official opposition in the white chamber of Parliament, oppose violence and have distanced themselves from the recent bomb attacks. Most right-wing whites are Afrikaners, the Dutch-descended settlers of South Africa who account for about 3 million of the 5 million whites. Under the country's apartheid system, whites maintain political and economic control. The 28 million blacks have no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: National Vet Groups Rally for Better Health Care
With AM-July Fourth Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Three national veterans groups sounded a call to arms at an Independence Day rally, urging the country's 27 million vets to unite behind a petition drive for better health benefits. ``We've had all we can stand. The system is underfunded and we're not going to take it anymore,'' said Larry Rivers, executive director of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, which has 3 million members nationwide. The VFW joined the Paralyzed Veterans of America and AMVETS in calling the rally in Williams Park, which drew at least 2,000 veterans from across the state, many in uniform and bedecked with campaign ribbons. The masters of ceremony were Adrian Cronauer and Chris Noel, whose radio voices reached hundreds of thousands of American troops in Vietnam. Cronauer was portrayed by Robin Williams in the movie ``Good Morning Vietnam.'' Vendors sold hot dogs and popcorn, red, white and blue balloons danced in the breeze, and the vets wore American flags in their lapels or breast pockets. Under the theme ``united again,'' a petition was launched urging the Bush administration and congressional leaders to stop cuts in veterans' benefits. Veterans' leaders say the $12.4 billion budget being discussed for veterans' health care is insufficient to keep pace with inflation. Without another $1 billion, the country's 172 Veterans Affairs medical centers will be unable to provide in 1991 the level of care offered in 1988, said R. Jack Powell, executive director of the Paralyzed Veterans, which has 14,000 members. ``Veterans were there for the country when America needed them,'' Powell said. ``The question today is whether the country will be there for them in terms of health care.'' Mall shoppers can buy eyeglasses in an hour, Powell said, but veterans at the VA often must wait three months. A veteran can wait eight months or more for a hip replacement operation, he added, and six months to be admitted to a cardiac-care unit. ``You tell a veteran you're going to provide cardiac care _ but in six months _ and he's at risk of a heart attack within an hour,'' said Powell, who retired from the Army in 1971 after a land mine in Vietnam left him paralyzed. Owen Ball, a 70-year-old World War II veteran and a member of the rally's honor guard, said he has unsuccessfully fought the VA for years to get a hearing aid. He lost part of his hearing in a bomb explosion in London in 1944. As veterans, like the rest of the population, age, the need for health care grows more acute, Powell said. ``If something isn't done about it, the country is going to end up with an increased burden on Medicaid and other indigent, non-compensated care,'' he said, noting that budget squeezes have closed clinics at VA hospitals and left an estimated 3,500 beds unused because of staff shortages. The groups chose Florida for the rally because it has a veteran population of 1.5 million, with thousands more moving in yearly. It also has a large active-duty military population and four, soon to be five, VA hospitals.

DOC.HEAD: Jubilant Germans Cheer Soccer Team Reaching World Cup Final
DOC.TEXT: Jubilant West Berliners flocked to the city's main Kurfuerstendamm boulevard Wednesday night, launching fireworks and shouting ``Germany! Germany!'' to celebrate West Germany's reaching the World Cup soccer finals. West Germany won, 4-3, in a penalty-kick victory over England at Turin, Italy, and will meet Argentina on Sunday in the finals. In Turin, police used truncheons to disperse unruly crowds near that city's main train station after the game. A 23-year-old German was stabbed in the back and badly hurt when a fight broke out among rowdy fans before the kickoff. British Embassy spokeswoman Kay Coombs said in Turin there was a brief scuffle involving about 40 English, Italian and German fans in a park near the railway station and that when police dispersed the people, they found the wounded German and one Englishman with a head injury, who refused treatment. After the game, police used clubs and kicked people as they sought to scatter large groups gathered at street corners near the station. The crowd set off firecrackers, provoking more clashes. Hundreds of police in riot gear positioned themselves on streets to keep the crowd under control. Shortly after midnight, minor clashes occurred between police and crowds gathered outside the station. English fans were not involved, police said, although there was some friction between German and Italian fans. By 1 a.m. Thursday, most of the crowd had dispersed. Throughout West Germany, people rushed into the streets, honking horns, lighting fireworks, waving flags and cheering the soccer victory, which put West Germany into the World Cup finals for the third straight time. A caravan of cars filled with fans waving German flags drove up and down West Berlin streets to the cheers of spectators. Some pounded on car roofs. Traffic on ritzy Kurfuerstendamm was at a standstill. Germans drove through the streets in Frankfurt and Bonn, as well, honking horns. In downtown Frankfurt, fans hung out of windows shouting ``Deutschland wunderbar!'' ``It's a super day for Germany,'' said Michael Hindel, a 30-year-old truck driver from West Berlin. ``It was a fantastic match, and we played extremely well. I'm certain we can win it all in the finals.'' ``It's all very exciting,'' said Manfred Solleder, a 45-year-old businessman from West Berlin. ``We were lucky to win, but I think it was a good thing, especially now during the mood of reunification. It will be a nice thing for the East Germans to have a winning team to identify with.'' The two Germanys merged their economies Sunday in a prelude to full unification, expected in December. Martina Schmidt, a 19-year-old student from East Berlin, said a shot at winning the World Cup and German unification in the same year was ``almost too unreal to believe.'' ``What more could you ask?'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Terrorists Blow Up Three Medellin Police Posts
DOC.TEXT: Terrorists apparently working for the Medellin cocaine cartel blew up three police posts and shot one officer to death, police said Wednesday. So far this year, 159 police have been killed in Medellin, the country's second largest city and the focus of the government's 10-month-old war on drugs. Medellin Police Chief Col. Jorge Ferrero said national police are sending 500 more officers to the city. In recent weeks, the police force has been doubled to around 5,000 members. No casualties occurred Tuesday when the three police posts were blown up, a Medellin police communique said. It said each of the three bombs contained about seven pounds of dynamite.. Young, motorcycle-riding assassins on Tuesday shot an off-duty policeman 12 times as he walking unarmed to his house, the statement said. Two other policemen were wounded Tuesday night when gunmen attacked the residence of Mayor J. Mario Rodriguez of Envigado, a Medellin suburb long considered the headquarters of the Medellin drug cartel. The police statement said the mayor was not harmed. Drug traffickers and police are at war in Medellin, Colombia's second largest city with 3 million people. On April 2, the Medellin drug cartel offered $4,300 for every law officer killed. Police blame drug traffickers for exploding five car bombs this year, killing 60 people and injuring hundreds. Army Gen. Harold Bedoya, commander of the 4th Brigade, at a news conference last week reiterated authorities' offer to pay $400,000 for information leading to the arrest of Pablo Escobar, reputed head of the Medellin cartel and the man believed responsible for the violence sweeping the city of 3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Workers Strike; Striking Banana Workers Soften Demands
LaserPhoto TEG2
DOC.TEXT: Striking banana workers softened their salary demands slightly Wednesday as talks continued for the fifth day with U.S. banana giant Chiquita. Labor unrest continued to spread in this Central American country. Police used hacksaws to cut through chains on the doors of post offices to remove postal workers from offices they had occupied on Tuesday. But mail service remained halted Wednesday. Water and electricity workers threatened to go on strike. Some 10,000 Chiquita workers began their strike on June 25. Since then, another 11,000 workers in other industries have gone on strike in support of the banana workers. Four thousand health workers have been on strike since June 11 to protest the government's decision to privatize food, security and cleaning services at 19 public hospitals. Army medics have been called in to assist at some hospitals. Negotiations continued in an effort to end the strike against Chiquita Brands International Inc. Bananas are Honduras' leading export and the Cincinnati-based Chiquita, formerly United Brands, is one of the most powerful institutions in Honduras. Carlos Aragon, Chiquita's labor relations superintendent, said the workers were now seeking a 50 percent pay raise, retroactive to March 1990. The workers, who earn an average of $15.32 a day, had been demanding a 60 percent pay starting in July. ``We are making an effort to reach a satisfactory agreement but a rapid solution to the problem is not yet in sight,'' said Aragon, contacted by telephone in San Pedro Sula, 125 miles north of Tegucigalpa, the capital. ``The economic aspect is basic in this matter ... and it will take us more time to resolve it,'' he said. In another development, private sector organizations issued a statement saying strikes by government employees were hurting the econony. They said there have been 13 strikes by government workers _ seven of them in May _ so far this year, costing a total of $3.8 million. ``This chaotic situation provokes uncertainty and increases the risk for investment in Honduras,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Gene Hackman Hospitalized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf of film credits. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Actor Gene Hackman was hospitalized after falling ill while traveling through Oregon, a hospital spokeswoman said Wednesday night. Hackman, 60, was in fair condition and undergoing tests at St. Vincent Hospital & Health Center, said spokeswoman Denise Tomasovic. She declined to elaborate on the nature of his illness. The actor checked himself into the hospital on Tuesday, the spokeswoman said. Hackman's movie credits include ``The French Connection,'' ``Superman,'' ``Hoosiers,'' ``The Conversation'' and ``No Way Out.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists `Badger' British Parliamentarians
LaserPhoto LON6
DOC.TEXT: Forty environmentalists wearing badger masks turned up outside the House of Commons on Wednesday in support of a parliamentary bill which seeks to outlaw any interference with badgers' burrows. Hunting the animals for sport is on the increase in the British countryside, said the lobbyists, members of the Royal Society for Nature Conservation. Hunters dig badgers out of their burrows and then set dogs to attack and kill the animals. The conservation society and other animal rights supporters have condemned the activity as a barbarous cruelty and a threat to the survival of the species. The parliamentary bill is sponsored by legislator Tony Banks of the opposition Labor Party. It is what is known as a private member's bill, meaning that the government, which writes the bulk of the legislation that passes through Parliament, is not involved in its progress. Private members' bills frequently fail to become law, getting squeezed out of the parliamentary timetable because of the crush of other business.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Company President Sentenced to Three Years in Fraud Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf, `They also ...,' to UDPDATE with Boeing comment; picks up 7th graf, `Tashima also ...'
DOC.TEXT: A judge sentenced a defense contractor to three years in prison and fined him $750,000 for faking quality tests on engine bolts used in thousands of military and commercial aircraft. ``This is a very egregious case motivated primarily by greed and avarice,'' U.S. District Judge A. Wallace Tashima said Tuesday in sentencing Norman D. McHaffie, 56, former president of McHaffie Inc. of Sylmar. ``The actions of McHaffie literally weakened and endangered the national defense,'' Tashima said. No accidents were attributed to McHaffie bolts. The bolts were used in the Air Force B-1B strategic bomber, the Navy-Marine Corps F-18 Hornet fighter-attack aircraft, the Navy-Air Force A-7 Corsair II jet attack fighter, the Navy F-14 Tomcat fighter and the Air Force F-16 Fighting Falcon. They also were used in thousands of Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. commercial jets, the government said. Jack Gamble of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said executives at the world's largest manufacturer of jetliners cooperated in the government investigation. ``We did quality checks on every (McHaffie-tested) bolt we had, and we had no bad bolts,'' Gamble said. Tashima also sentenced McHaffie's quality control supervisor, James Hicks, 45, of Sepulveda to 18 months in prison for participating in the scheme to submit false test certifications to the government. A shop floor manager, William Whitham, 37, of Lancaster, was previously sentenced to 20 weekends in prison. McHaffie pleaded guilty in April to conspiracy and two counts of submitting false test certifications to the Department of Defense. The other men also admitted wrongdoing. Prosecutors contended that McHaffie saved more than $1.5 million by failing to properly test some 9 million bolts between 1979 and 1989. Assistant U.S. Attorney Stephen A. Mansfield said it was the longest-running fraud against the government by a defense contractor uncovered so far. McHaffie told Hicks and Whitman to create fake test data and fabricate reports to conceal the fraud, according to a federal complaint filed March 29. The government alleged bolts sent to General Electric Co.'s engine division failed testing by an outside laboratory. The discovery that many of the company's bolts failed to meet testing requirements also led to a massive effort to discard them from parts suppliers, prosecutors said. General Electric alone spent at least $4 million to test a sample of bolts, the government said. McHaffie shut down in June 1989 and sold off its assets.

DOC.HEAD: France Explodes Nuclear Device; New Zealand Issues Protest
DOC.TEXT: France on Wednesday exploded a nuclear device at its South Pacific test site, the Defense Ministry said. The nuclear test drew an immediate protest from New Zealand It was the fourth such test announced since May, when President Francois Mitterrand promised during a visit to Polynesia to make them public. In the past, France had refused to confirm or deny reports of nuclear tests, despite protests from Pacific nations over its policy. The Defense Ministry said the latest test at the Mururoa atoll yielded less than 35 kilotons. New Zealand's Department of Scientific and Industrial Research in Wellington said the test measured approximately 20 kilotons. New Zealand's prime minister, Geoffrey Palmer. immediately issued a statement expressing his disappointment at the test and its timing. He said it offers further evidence that France cares little for the protests of South Pacific nations. ``It is particularly insensitive that they should be testing now, a matter of days before'' a group of leaders from South Pacific nations meet in the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu, he said. Palmer said he was also disappointed that the test should come a day after France had announced it would be an observer at the Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference. ``We saw this as a positive signal that France shared the concern of treaty members, including New Zealand, on the horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons technology to more countries,'' Palmer said. ``But now we see that France is continuing to ignore opposition to vertical proliferation _ the acquisition of more and improved weapons by existing nuclear weapons states.'' Palmer said France knew that by continuing to use the South Pacific to perfect its nuclear weapons, it was acting in a manner completely unacceptable to New Zealand and other countries in the region. Since changing its policy on announcing the tests, France has said it exploded nuclear devices on June 2, June 7 and June 26 at Mururoa.

DOC.HEAD: Super Collider Officials to Start Buying Land
DOC.TEXT: Officials plan to begin buying land for the superconducting super collider project on Friday. The Texas National Research Laboratory Commission has scheduled a noon ceremony near this town about 30 miles south of Dallas to buy its first parcel for the giant particle smasher. ``It's going to be a major milestone in this project,'' said Ed Bingler, executive director of the commission. Neither the landowner nor the price were disclosed. Officials will have to acquire more than 10,000 acres to build the super collider, a 54-mile oval in a tunnel in which protons and other particles will be accelerated to extreme speeds and smashed for scientific study. Subsurface rights will be purchased for another 6,400 acres. The commission is buying the property and the rights, but ownership will be transferred to the federal government. It is estimated that land acquisition will cost $40 million to $100 million. The $8 billion super collider is expected to be in operation in the late 1990s.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped 12 cents an ounce on Hong Kong markets Thursday, opening at $361.85. It closed at $361.97 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Director of Canadian AIDS Group Says He Helped Eight Commit Suicide
DOC.TEXT: The director of an AIDS support group says he's helped eight AIDS sufferers commit suicide by providing them with large doses of prescription drugs. ``I've been at the bedside of more than 100 people at the moment of their death. Eight of those people I've helped,'' said David Lewis, 38, who also is being treated for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Lewis, a director of the Vancouver Persons With AIDS Society, said he obtained prescription drugs and put enough for a fatal overdose within reach of the patients, who usually are bedridden. ``I think it's immoral and unethical to not help someone die if that's what they want,'' he said Tuesday. Lewis said he wouldn't help people commit suicide over nothing more than emotional despondency, but maintained that people nearing death and in pain from AIDS face different circumstances. ``I've not pushed pills down anybody's throat,'' he said, ``but I've certainly complied with people's desires.'' It is a crime in Canada to counsel or assist a suicide. Some people have been tried for such acts in the United States but there is no record of a conviction in Canada. Lewis said he received legal advice that he would not be convicted if he withheld the names of the eight people. ``There's nothing really that we can do about that without some disclosure of who the victims were,'' Vancouver police Constable Bob Cooper said Wednesday. ``We would have to prove Mr. X committed suicide and that he was assisted in doing so by Mr. Y.'' Cooper said police weren't about to start an investigation based on a newspaper interview but planned to meet with prosecutors for a general discussion of euthanasia. British Columbia Solicitor General Russ Fraser deferred questions Wednesday to provincial Attorney General Bud Smith. ``I'll check with him myself,'' Fraser said. Phillip Scarisbrick, a Vancouver lawyer speaking for the Canadian Bar Association, said Lewis could face criminal charges. ``If this fellow flaunts his activities enough, they'd be forced to prosecute him,'' Scarisbrick added. However, Brian Greenspan of Toronto, president of the Ontario Criminal Lawyers' Association and vice chairman of the Canadian Bar Association's criminal justice section, said Lewis might not be liable under the law. ``I'm really not sure if he's committed an offense,'' Greenspan said. He explained that to obtain a conviction, prosecutors would have to prove that Lewis helped someone commit suicide rather than merely provided an opportunity to commit suicide. Prosecutors also can exercise discretion in deciding whether to file charges, he added. ``It's not a black-and-white issue as to whether you prosecute or don't,'' Greenspan said. Euthanasia for AIDS patients is ``a political hot potato,'' however, so authorities might be reluctant to act, Scarisbrick said. Canadian law ``turns a blind eye to certain behavior,'' said professor Earl Winkler, who teaches ethics at the University of British Columbia. ``I think people like David Lewis have a lot of courage,'' he said. Lewis said he knows some people oppose to his activities, ``but I suspect those are people who are not themselves with a terminal illness.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Says Size of United German Military a Subject for Vienna Talks
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl is ready to have the size of a united German military negotiated at ongoing conventional arms reduction talks in Vienna, his chief spokesman said Wednesday. The West German leader and the heads of the 15 other North Atlantic Treaty Organization members gather in London Thursday and Friday to discuss the future role of the Western alliance in a rapidly changing Europe. Kohl's spokesman, Hans Klein, said the West German chancellor considered discussions on a united Germany's military strength to be among the highest priorities of the Vienna arms talks. As the two Germanys rush toward unification, Moscow has raised concerns over such issues as the size of a united German army, the military alignment of a unified Germany and what to do with the approximately 380,000 Soviet troops now in East Germany. Klein did not mention any possible limit on the size of a united Germany's armed forces. News reports over the weekend said the Defense Ministry wanted to halve East Germany's military and limit the total strength of a combined German military to no more than 400,000. East Germany has about 100,000 soldiers; West Germany about 495,000. However, West Germany has already said it plans to reduce its total troop strength to 400,000 in five to six years. Klein said Kohl would also re-emphasize at the NATO summit his commitment to full membership for a united Germany in the Western alliance, which the Soviets have so far rejected. He will also support a greater role for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has been pressing for a formal role for the 35-nation conference in European security matters, with regular meetings of leaders of the member countries. The Soviets have proposed the conference serve in the future as an umbrella security organization in place of NATO and the crumbling Warsaw Pact. The United States has opposed the idea.

DOC.HEAD: $15 Million Judgment Entered in Manhattan Against Marcos
DOC.TEXT: A $15.1 million judgment has been entered against former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos in a Washington state case in which she and her late husband were found liable in the murders of two anti-Marcos activists. Mrs. Marcos was acquitted Monday with Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi of federal racketeering and fraud charges that she helped loot her homeland's treasury of $222 million and spent it on art and real estate, much of it in New York. The $15.1 million judgment, entered June 19 in a federal court in New York and June 27 in a state court here, clears the way for the slain men's families to attach Marcos property in New York. The judgments were published in the New York Law Journal on Tuesday. On Dec. 15, a civil jury in a federal court in Seattle found Marcos, the late deposed president of the Philippines, and Mrs. Marcos liable in the 1981 murders of the two Filipino activists. Marcos' estate and his widow were ordered to pay more than $15 million to the survivors of Silme Domingo and Gene Viernes. The jury awarded Domingo's wife and two young daughters $12.8 million, and Viernes' wife $2.3 million. Richard Hibey, lead attorney for the Marcoses, blamed the verdict on the couple's unpopularity and said he would appeal, which could delay payment of the award for years. The jury decided that the Marcoses were conspirators in the deaths of the two men and were negligent in failing to control their intelligence agents in the United States. Domingo and Viernes, both 29 and leaders of the Alaska Cannery Workers Union, were slain in the union's Seattle office on June 1, 1981, four weeks after they successfully sponsored a resolution calling for an investigation of anti-union activity in the Philippines. The case alleged that a Marcos friend in San Francisco used $15,000 from a corporation he controlled to pay for the murders, and that the Marcoses had a network in the United States to monitor, harass and intimidate their opponents. Three men were convicted in 1981 and 1982 of murdering Domingo and Viernes, but those trials did not result in a finding that there was a Marcos-linked conspiracy. The Marcoses fled a popular revolt in their homeland in 1986 and moved to Hawaii. Ferdinand Marcos died there in September before the racketeering case in which his wife was acquitted went to trial.

DOC.HEAD: Cyprus Applies For Full EC Membership
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday applied for full membership in the European Economic Community, a move it believes will help unite war-divided Cyprus. ``This is a great day for Cyprus, and we're very proud,'' President George Vassiliou, leader of the east Mediterranean island's Greek Cypriot majority, told reporters. Cyprus, with a population of nearly 700,000, has been associated with the EC for 17 years. It is the only non-member that has signed a customs union with the 12-member bloc. The island has been cut in two since 1974, when the Turkish army invaded in the wake of a short-lived coup by supporters of union with Greece. The Turks seized the northern one-third of the island, which was proclaimed a breakaway Turkish Cypriot republic in 1983. Only Turkey recognizes the Turkish sector. Turkey applied for European Community membership in 1987. But its application has been held up, partly because of the community's reluctance to admit new members before its scheduled economic integration in 1992. The community is also believed to have reservations because of alleged human rights violations in Turkey and the Turkish presence in northern Cyprus. Turkey objects to Cyprus seeking membership of the European bloc without the consent of the Turkish Cypriot minority, who form an estimated 18 percent of the island's population. Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, has threatened to boycott a new round of U.N.-sponsored peace talks with Vassiliou if the Greek Cypriots applied for EEC membership. The talks on a U.N. proposal for a two-zone federation have been deadlocked for months. Turkey has also rejected U.N. resolutions demanding the withdrawal of an estimated 30,000 Turkish troops and 50,000 mainland settlers from north Cyprus and the return of 200,000 Greek Cypriot refugees who fled or were expelled from the north. The Turks insist the troops and settles must stay as a security guarantee. Ankara also rejects the return of Greek Cypriots to their former homes.

DOC.HEAD: Former Israeli Prime Minister Recovering After Operation
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin is recovering well a day after doctors operated on him to repair a broken hip, a hospital spokeswoman said. Begin, 76, fell in his home Tuesday, breaking his right hip for the second time. Hospital spokeswoman Devorah Weissman said doctors expected Begin would remain in the hospital for two weeks of physical therapy and rehabilitation. ``Mr. Begin is recuperating well and showing good progress,'' said Weissman, spokeswoman for Jerusalem's Shaarei Tzedek Hospital. ``He's been moved to a private room in the regular orthopedic ward and he's been up out of bed already.'' Begin was also hospitalized for two weeks in May with pneumonia. Begin served as prime minister from 1977 to 1983, when he stepped down from office without explanation. He took over as prime minister in May 1977 when his Likud bloc handed the left-leaning Labor Party its first national electoral defeat in almost 30 years. He left office six years later reportedly depressed about the high casualties the Israeli army was taking in Lebanon as the result of the June 1982 invasion launched under his leadership and the death of his wife, Aliza. Since resigning, Begin has lived in seclusion, rarely emerging from his apartment at the edge of the Jerusalem forest. He receives visits only from a small circle of aides and former colleagues.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Wins World Open Chess Tournament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to ADD that Gleck from Moscow; SUBS graf 5-6, `Also tying ...,' to give hometowns for other competitors.
DOC.TEXT: International master Igor Gleck of the Soviet Union won the 18th annual World Open chess tournament Wednesday. The 28-year-old Muscovite defeated fellow Soviet Vitaly Tseshkovsky in the final round to score 7{ out of a possible nine points and gain the $17,870 first prize. The competition is billed as the biggest open chess tournament in the world. This year's event featured 1,158 players battling for a total purse of $178,688. A nine-way tie for second place included three American grandmasters: Joel Benjamin of New York City, Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., and Larry Christiansen of New York City and Soviet emigre Alex Yermolinsky of Piscataway, N.J.
