Also tying for second were British grandmaster Julian Hodgson of London, Ferdinand Hellers of Stockholm, Sweden, and three Soviets: Naum Rashkovksy of Moscow, Ilya Smirin of Minsk and Alexander Shabalov of Riga. The competition was split into several sections for players of different rankings. The competition, held in Philadelphia since 1985, featured players from 45 states and 20 countries, said tournament organizer Bill Goichberg. Goichberg said this year's event was missing many top U.S. and overseas grandmasters because of a scheduling clash with a world championship qualifying tournament in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Arrests Strike Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with police releasing union leaders. Pickup pvs 3rd graf, `It was...'
DOC.TEXT: Riot police briefly arrested the six leaders of a 3-day-old government workers strike Wednesday as the walkout called by pro-Sandinista unions gained momentum. Police had detained the strike leaders at the Sandinista Workers Center just before they were scheduled to give a news conference. Lucio Jimenez, head of the National Workers Front, said he and five others were arrested for ``disturbing the peace.'' ``We were freed because of pressure from the public and the students,'' Jimenez said at the University of Central America within minutes of his release. No comment was immediately available from authorities. It was the first time leaders of organized labor were arrested during the 2-month-old administration of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. The arrests came after Mrs. Chamorro, who defeated Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega in the Feb. 25 national elections, called the strike ``strictly political.'' She accused the Sandinista party of trying to sabotage her efforts to revive the economy. ``What every strike, sabotage or anarchy does is to reduce the good effects of my government's economic policy and the ones who suffer most are the people,'' she said in a televised message late Tuesday. The Sandinista National Liberation Front officially threw its support behind the strike Wednesday and said it ``is the fruit of the economic, political and social measures dictated by the government.'' The arrested leaders included Lucio Jimenez, secretary general of the Sandinista Workers Center; Edgardo Garcia, secretary general of the Sandinistas Farm Workers Association and Jose Angel Bermudez, secretary general of the National Employees Union. Unions called out the nation's 100,000 government workers Monday to protest what it said were ``massive firings'' since Mrs. Chamorro took office April 25. The strike at first attracted little support and only a few thousand workers walked off their jobs. Salaries, which were raised 100 percent to settle a May strike that paralyzed the country, were not an issue. The Sandinistas said the strike was also called to protest government economic policies which they claim ``favor the rich'' and could lead to social unrest. The Chamorro administration plans to cut spending by selling most state-owned industries and trimming the bureaucracy. It also wants to dismantle 10 years of Sandinista efforts to create a socialist system in Nicaragua. Wednesday hundreds of customs workers walked off their jobs and joined the strikers. At the Selin Shible customs office in Managua, about 40 trucks waiting to have their cargo checked went unattended. Telecommunications and postal workers stepped up their work stoppages from one to two hours a day on Wednesday. Union representative Sonia Ortiz said they would increase ``little by little the stoppage until we reach total strike.'' Thousands of employees in government agriculture, construction, metalworking and textiles were also striking. Jose Angel Bermudez, leader of the National Employees' Union, said walkouts will increase ``because the strike is scaled.''

DOC.HEAD: Spoleto Director Karl Allison Dies at 42
DOC.TEXT: James Karl Allison Jr., director of planning and development for the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., and a former Broadway producer, died Wednesday in Perugia, Italy. He was 42. Allison suffered a cerebral hemorrhage Sunday while in a Spoleto, Italy hospital visiting a sick member of the festival orchestra, festival spokesman Tom Kerrigan announced in New York. Allison was taken to a hospital in Perugia. Allison, who was known as Karl, joined the board of directors of Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., in 1988, and later took the staff position. In January, he put together a benefit at New York's Lincoln Center that raised $321,000 for the festival in the aftermath of Hurricane Hugo. His credits as a Broadway producer include ``Blithe Spirit'' with Richard Chamberlain and Geraldine Page, ``Wild Honey'' with Ian McKellan, ``You Can't Take it with You'' with Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst, and ``Aren't We All'' with Rex Harrison. He produced the long-running off-Broadway hit ``Greater Tuna.'' Gian Carlo Menotti, who founded the Festival of the Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, and the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., said, ``Karl Allison was a friend and a colleague whose energy and hard work we valued deeply. His death is a terrible loss.'' Funeral services were planned in Charleston, S.C., home of Allison's parents.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Strike Paralyzes Greece
DOC.TEXT: A general strike on Wednesday brought Greece to a vitual standstill, with civil servants joining private employees and shop owners to challenge the conservative government's austerity and development programs. Transport services were disrupted, power supplies were erratic, traffic was snarled and air pollution was reported at record highs in this capital city of more than 3 million. It was the fourth 24-hour national strike this year. A union official estimated strike turnout at about 70 percent nationwide. But the Federation of Greek Industries, which represents the bulk of private industry, called the strike a ``general failure.'' A spokesman put the strike at private industries at about 5 percent. The official and spokesman spoke on condition of anonymity. Workers are protesting price increases and other measures taken by Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis following his April 8 election. The government is struggling to contain inflation, now running at 22 percent, and a projected $2 billion deficit. It estimates each national strike costs the ailing economy $100 million and 16 million work hours. The strike was called jointly by the General Confederation of Greek Workers, the civil servants union and smaller labor organizations. The unions claim about 2 million members. Protest rallies were held throughout Greece. Parliamentary committees are debating a bill aimed at stimulating investment. Labor leaders say the measure allows for more flexible working hours, and claim this will do away with the eight-hour working day. ``The bill may be voted through Parliament, but we won't allow it to be implemented,'' confederation president Lambros Kanellopoulos told an open-air rally in Athens. Public Power Corporation and Telecommunication company employees joined the walkout to protest elimination of privileges granting them discounts on their electricty and phone bills. Their walkout began Monday, resulting in power cuts in parts of the country. Flights on Olympic Airways, the national carrier, were disrupted by two three-hour walkouts. A public transportation standstill forced commuters to miss work or hitch rides on major thoroughfares. Private cars and taxis jammed Athens, raising air pollution levels. PAKOE, an independent environment agency, reported more than 700 people hospitalized because of respiratory problems.

DOC.HEAD: 90-Year-old Acquitted in Rampage that Killed Three
DOC.TEXT: A 90-year-old man was a free man Wednesday after jurors acquitted him of bludgeoning to death three housemates in a retirement home rampage. ``Thank you to the jury and the judge. That's all I want to say,'' Henry Thomas said as he left the Pasco County courthouse late Tuesday, cleared of the New Year's Day 1989 slayings. One of his attorneys cried as the verdict was read following five hours of jury deliberations. ``It's a great day,'' said Thomas, who had spent the last 18 months in jail. He was taken in his wheelchair from the courthouse to the East Pasco Detention Center and released. Two residents died at the scene and a third, left with a fractured skull, died a month later. Three others recovered from injuries. Defense attorneys had argued there was too much doubt that Thomas did, or even physically could have, carried out the beatings. They said three residents of the group home described the attacker as a young man. Police arrested Thomas, his clothes spattered with blood, and said he had attacked the victims with his heavy oak cane. His cane had traces of blood and a bone fragment. Thomas said he saw and heard intruders and fled out the front door when they began beating his roommates. He was picked up 12 hours later. Despite his age, prosecutors portrayed Thomas as a strong, fit man, a onetime boxer who got the better of a man 70 years his junior while in a cell in May. During the jail confrontation, Thomas had an arm lock on a 20-year-old until a guard broke it up when he heard the young man call for help. Authorities said the retired fruit picker had trouble getting along with other elderly residents in the Reflections I home that housed nine people about 45 miles northeast of Tampa. Thomas shared a 10-foot-by-9 room with two others. They said he argued often, becoming angry over such incidents as when his things were moved by others. Assistant Public Defender William Eble, in tears as the verdict was read, said Thomas would be reunited with his family. Members of the Thomas family linked hands to pass through a line of reporters, continuing to refuse to talk. Eble and Assistant Public Defender John Carballo helped Thomas stand as the verdicts were given. As he listened to Circuit Judge Wayne Cobb issue a formal finding of innocence, Thomas lifted the index finger of his right hand in a saluting gesture to the judge. Cobb nodded in return. The verdicts prompted emotional applause in the courtroom. While some celebrated, Charles and Helen Tear struggled with the outcome. Helen Tear owned the home, and her father-in-law, Frank Tear Sr., was among those killed. ``I was angry at the applause,'' Mrs. Tear said. ``Obviously, this was like a party.'' The Tears testified for the prosecution and believe that Thomas committed the murders. ``I turned this over to the Lord a long time ago,'' Charles Tear said. ``If this is His will, then I accept it.'' Prosecutor Phil Van Allen had no comment on the verdict.

DOC.HEAD: Body Could Be One of Flood Victims, Investigator Says
DOC.TEXT: A body pulled from the Ohio River on Wednesday could be the 25th victim of flash floods that ravaged the area last month, an official said. The body was spotted by a pleasure craft about 200 yards south of the mouth of Wegee Creek and about five miles south of Shadyside, said Chuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator. West Virginia authorities recovered the body about 9 p.m. and were expected to turn it over to the Belmont County coroner's office for an autopsy Thursday, Vogt said. The body was not identified Wednesday night, he said. Vogt said the body probably was one of the missing victims of the June 14 flood because it was found in an area where a crane had removed debris. About 5{ inches of rain fell near this eastern Ohio village in three hours on June 14, sending walls of water down Wegee and Pipe creeks. The bodies of 24 people have been recovered while nine officially remain missing, pending identification of the body recovered Wednesday, Vogt said.

People in Wisconsin lead a new coast-to-coast survey in obesity, binge drinking and drinking and driving. The source is the Centers for Disease Control's annual Behavioral Risk Factor Survey, a 36-state effort to measure America's nasty health habits. The CDC released the results this week. Americans in participating states were asked about the things they do to jeopardize their health, such as smoking, staying fat, going on drinking binges and not wearing seat belts. In Wisconsin, 28 percent of respondents said they were overweight, according to the CDC. Twenty-five percent reported ``binge drinking'' _ five or more drinks in a sitting in the previous month _ and 6 percent admitted drinking and driving.

The government said today it was temporarily suspending plans to kill 30,000 seals to produce dog food and aphrodisiacs after protests from environmentalists around the world. Environment Minister Gert Kotze said he was suspending the culling to study public reaction to plans to kill 25,000 seal cubs and 5,000 adult male seals on the northwest coast later this month. ``This is not backtracking at all, but its fair towards the public and conservationists to consider their objections, and I want time to do that,'' Kotze told state-run radio. South African and international environmentalists had protested a Taiwanese business group's plans to kill the seals for export. Seal bodies would be used for pet food while the males' genitals are prized as aphrodisiacs.

Italians were shocked and bewildered over their elimination in the World Cup soccer semifinal, reacting with tears, anger and defiant chants. Italy's dream of a fourth World Cup title was shattered Tuesday night when its team lost a penalty kick shootout to Argentina 4-3, breaking a 1-1 tie. Italians watched their TV screens in disbelief. ``In other countries soccer is only a game. Here in Italy soccer is something in the heart. I cannot describe how bad I feel,'' said Emiliano Mari of Rome.

President Bush leaves tonight for the NATO summit in London with a package of proposals, including one on revamping nuclear strategy, that he says are being favorably received by the allies. While on a six-day vacation at his seaside home, Bush has been talking by telephone with world leaders and consulting with top advisers in advance of the Thursday-Friday summit. He spoke with the prime ministers of Denmark and Belgium on Tuesday before capping his day by viewing early Fourth of July fireworks from the deck of the Coast Guard training barque Eagle. The president is taking to London a series of proposals dealing with how to restructure the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the face of the declining threat from the Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies.

Mikhail S. Gorbachev is drawing unprecedented attacks from all shades of reds at a turbulent Communist Party congress, but even his critics say they will vote to keep him in the top party job. ``If we have to vote, I shall vote for Gorbachev, simply because there is no other alternative,'' said delegate Vitaly G. Karpenko, echoing a sentiment heard across the spectrum in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses. The 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party is expected to elect the party general secretary before it adjourns sometime next week, and the smart rubles are riding on Gorbachev, who first won the job five years ago. Hard-liners and radical reformers are gravitating toward Gorbachev because both sides believe only he can prevent the disintegration of the party.

Members of Congress say they want assurances from the Energy Department that dramatic cost increases in cleaning up nuclear weapons waste will yield a safer environment, not bigger profits for contractors. The department said Tuesday it will take about 50 percent more money and twice as many people as earlier projected to clean up radioactive waste at weapons plants over the next five years. ``I think there is support on the (Capitol) Hill for this, but people are going to start asking what is being cleaned up? What is being accomplished?'' Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash., said Tuesday. ``I worry about how much of the money is going into the pockets of the contractors and how much actual cleanup is being done,'' he said.

For release Thurs PMs, July 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: With So Much Ahead, Bush and Congress Will Have to Get Along
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES reference to minimum wage legislation in 3rd graf ``Bush has ... federal employees.'' ADDS mention of crime bill to 17th graf: ``In addition ... and crime.''
DOC.TEXT: The 101st Congress has nearly all its important work remaining for its frantic final weeks of legislating _ with success riding on cooperation with President Bush. Deficit reduction, clean air and child care are three big issues on the agendas of both Bush and the Democratic Congress. To accomplish them, they'll have to put aside the pattern that dominated the first 18 months of their relationship. Bush has proven a dozen times that he can veto bills and not be overridden. He's beaten back congressional attempts to expand federal financing for abortions and loosen restrictions on politicking by federal employees. On the other hand, he can't always get what he wants if the Democrats don't want to give it to him. He has been denied his first choice for Secretary of Defense, a cut in the capital gains tax and an amendment to the Bill of Rights to ban flag burning. ``We've been between the 20 yard lines in the 101st,'' said Rep. Ed Jenkins, D-Ga. ``Nobody's moving across anybody's goal line.'' That confrontation and stalemate pattern is likely to continue on the so-called ``values'' issues, such as abortion and possibly on federal funding of ``indecent'' art. Just last week, Bush vetoed legislation to mandate unpaid leave for workers who need to take care of new babies or sick relatives. Chances for an override appear slim. But the overall relationship between Bush and Congress appears to be turning. The legislative successes widely expected when Bush, a former House member, took office could be on the way. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle expect they'll break the ice on the big, meat-and-potatoes legislating that will mark them all as failures if it isn't done. ``I don't think we've got to enact every single one, but certainly many of them for this to be fairly characterized as a successful Congress,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Rep. Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., chairman of the House Republican Conference, said Bush was well positioned to come out a winner. ``Bush is not just talented, but extremely clever'' politically and legislatively, he said. The biggest problem is time. Congress has less than nine working weeks scheduled before its early October pre-election adjournment, and issues with little chance of passage, such as campaign finance reform and a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, will eat time. Much of the current discussion in Congress hinges on the budget talks, since money for any new initiatives must be balanced against the demand for reducing the deficit. Discussing the budget and his pledge for cooperation on that front, Bush lamented last week that if he had a Republican Congress ``we might not even be talking about this today.'' The comment was a political bone for GOP lawmakers hurt by Bush's decision to support raising taxes as part of a deficit reduction plan. Besides losing one of their best issues, Republicans were angry at Bush's close cooperation with the Democrats. In addition to the budget, Bush will be under pressure to accept the Democratic Congress' bills on child care, rights for the disabled, tougher standards for oil tankers, farm programs and crime. The administration is negotiating with Congress on those issues prior to final passage in an effort to get bills that Bush won't feel compelled to veto. He's already struck a compromise with the Senate on a major new housing bill. All of those bills fall in the category of what one top House Democrat called Bush's ``I'm for that, too'' approach to politics. But Mitchell complained in an interview that in the case of the oil tanker bill, Bush has been ``a major obstacle to action.'' The House and Senate passed different versions of the legislation last year but a final resolution has been held up. Mitchell said he's willing to force confrontation on that and other issues unless the president gets on board. ``I think we have set the agenda, and ... ultimately he will not be able to prevent the Congress from establishing a good record in this session,'' said Mitchell, who is in his first term as Senate leader and eager to prove himself. Senate GOP leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., reminded the Democrats last week that cooperation from Bush wasn't enough. ``Now comes the really hard part: Getting down to specific spending and revenue proposals,'' Dole said of the budget summit. He viewed the football field a little differently. ``We are now on the 20 yard line, only 80 yards left to go.''

DOC.HEAD: Businesses Increasingly Targeted By Phone Scam Artists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CLARIFY that businesses are becoming sted have become main target of phone fraud.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Businesses, not individuals, are becoming the victims of choice in the thriving crime of telephone fraud, industry experts believe. Phone fraud accounts for $500 million in losses, or about 1 percent of the $50 billion in revenues earned by long distance carriers annually, says the Communications Fraud Control Association, a McLean, Va.-based group. Traditionally, long distance ripoffs consisted mainly of calling card fraud _ mostly unauthorized use of individuals' or businesses' carrier-issued calling card billing numbers. Other phone service thieves used so-called ``black boxes'' that emit a tone to allow access to long distance lines. But individual calling card fraud is being taken over rapidly by another scam _ one that victimizes business telephone systems called private branch exchanges or PBXs. ``Abusers are now going after the more vulnerable PBXs and are having a field day,'' said Rami Abuhamdeh, whose association is financed by telephone companies and law enforcement agencies. PBX scams target a feature on the phone system that allows company employees to dial into the home office _ usually on an 800 or WATS line _ from outside. Then, after punching in a personal identification number, they get a second dial tone and can make calls as if they were sitting at their desk. Calls made using this feature, called reorigination, allow the company to save the additional charges that long distance carriers assess for calling card use. To get the 3-to-4 digit security codes, computer ``hackers'' use programs on their own personal computers. Equipped with a telephone modem they can automatically dial numbers sequentially until they hit upon the right combination to access an outgoing line. A hacker can even start the program before he goes to bed and by the time he wakes up in the morning, he'll have hacked out the code number, said Bob Fox of United Telecom@US Sprint. Abuhamdeh claims that thieves are targetting PBXs in part because larger long distance companies have beefed up their security against calling card fraud. Access codes also have been sold by disgruntled employees at some companies. According to Fox, calling card fraud at US Sprint is down to insignificant numbers. But for businesses victimized by PBX fraud, losses can be staggering. Fox said $30,000 to $40,000 in extra charges are not unusual. Abuhamdeh said New York City's Human Resources Administration lost $700,000 in two months after someone inside the agency sold codes to outsiders. Among the most innovative attempts at eliminating remote access fraud is a device developed by US Sprint that can recognize the precise voice pattern of a legitimate customer. The customer, after registering his voice pattern with the long distance carrier, simply says his identification number into the phone and the voice recognition device verifies the user's identity. ``It applies to both long distance comanies and PBX users. The technology is at point right now where it's changing every day and becoming better,'' Abuhamdeh said. Companies can take immediate steps to fight against PBX fraud by increasing remote access code numbers to as many digits as the system allows and not using numbers in sequential order, Fox says. Fox also recommends that companies turn off the reorigination feature of a PBX during hours when it is not normally used and review remote access records as frequently as possible. Voice recognition systems and PBX fraud were among the main items on the agenda of the Communications Fraud Control Association's annual conference last month in Pentaggon City, Va. Over 150 attendees representing more than 100 firms and organizations participated in the conference.

DOC.HEAD: Gift and Novelty Dealers See Big Bucks in Bart Simpson
DOC.TEXT: Bart Simpson may be a cocky upstart in the land of television, but the spiky-haired cartoon kid already is a champ in the gift and novelty industry. Products bearing his image _ including T-shirts, college insignia sweat shirts, refrigerator magnets, key rings, buttons and posters _ are the hottest items at the Atlanta National Gift & Accessories Market. Buyers attending the quarterly Atlanta show are stocking up for the fall and winter months, so exhibit space in the 200-plus showrooms is stocked heavily with back-to-school and Christmas items. Bart, Homer and the rest of the clan from the Fox TV show ``The Simpsons'' have arrived with a bang, exhibitors said. And unlike Batman _ ubiquitous last year but virtually absent now _ the popular nuclear family looks to be a long-running hit for novelty dealers. ``To say it's the hottest item we've had is an understatement. He's the hottest thing I've seen in 10 years,'' said Chris Nilan, sales manager for Nilan's Alley Inc., which sells novelty items to stores throughout the Southeast. Nilan, showing off a wall full of Bart knickknacks, said he expects to reap $2 million in sales from Simpsons merchandise within the next six months. That's about four times what he made from E.T., the extraterrestrial movie character that sparked a craze in the 1980s. ``This has a wider demographic appeal,'' Nilan said Wednesday, the second day of the 10-day show. ``The kids love it and the parents love it too. And the yups think he's the neatest thing since Hershey bars.'' Nilan said demand for Simpsons items has been made even more intense because the creators of the program are limiting the licensing of products. ``The people who didn't react early are not going to have it,'' he said. Not everyone loves Bart, though. Nilan said he has stopped carrying T-shirts with the Simpson kid and the slogan ``Underachiever, and proud of it'' because of complaints from parents that it was sending out ``the wrong message.'' Exhibit space at the show also prominently features dozens of items emblazoned with other pop icons such as the New Kids on The Block, Dick Tracy and Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles, as well as standbys Mickey Mouse, Bugs Bunny and the Muppets. Then there are such items as dancing Coca-Cola cans and Statues of Liberty. They are flexible table top radios that _ like last year's hit novelty item, the dancing flower _ sway to the music. Such items carry on the tradition of oddly appealing but utterly useless objects as the pet rock and the mood ring. ``That's the gift industry's dream _ who is going to come up with the next pet rock,'' said Suzanne Pruitt, a spokeswoman for the Atlanta Market Center, which hosts the show. The gift show also offers a number of accessories for the hard-to-please executive. Darrah & Co. Ltd., a regional wholesaler, is taking orders for the Stress Express, a desktop launching pad that ejects a miniature helicopter. ``It's for the busy executive who is stressed out and can't think of anything better to do,'' said Michael Gabelman, a sales representative for Atlanta-based Darrah. ``You set up landing pads around the office.'' Gabelman added that one of his best-selling items recently has been a line of recycled stationery products being marketed in response to the heightened interest in the environment. Despite the cartoon-inspired items and offbeat novelties, the industry also relies heavily on traditional themes, said Ms. Pruitt. One showroom, called ``Classic Collections,'' features such things as hand-painted welcome signs and old-fashioned bird houses. Ms. Pruitt also noted that a seminar at the show is devoted to showing shop owners how to establish a bridal registry. ``Marriage is back in,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Appeals To Houston Summit For Debt Relief
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has appealed to world leaders preparing for the Houston economic summit to forgive part of Poland's foreign debt. In letters to the heads of state of Japan, Canada, West Germany, the United States, Great Britian, Italy and France, Mazowiecki ``expressed readiness for broad cooperation in seeking a solution acceptable to all parties concerned,'' the official PAP news agency reported Wednesday. The seven leaders are to meet for three days starting Monday in Houston, Texas, to discuss international economic issues. Polish economists and their Western advisers, including the World Bank, have said restructuring the country's $42 billion debt is crucial for the success of its economic overhaul. Poland's Western debt is the largest in Eastern Europe. Its repayment obligations would consume virtually of its export earnings, leaving little money to invest in its struggling economy. In February, the government announced it would freeze payments on its debts. Later that month, it reached agreement on rescheduling $10 billion in debt with the Paris Club, an informal grouping of creditor governmemts that holds about $27 billion of Poland's debt. About $9 billion is held by private banks, and the rest is owed to international organizations. The February accord reduced by about a quarter Poland's yearly payment obligations, but Poland has been urging its Western partners to cancel part of the debt as a practical necessity and as a way to support the country in its transformation to democracy. Western governments have backed Poland's ambitious effort to transform its socialist economy into a capitalist system, but have been reluctant to cancel debts. Much of the credit was extended to the the Communist regime of the 1970s. It was used for massive, but poorly conceived, industrial projects that failed to produce anticipated profits, and for a flood of consumer goods in an attempt to win public affection.

DOC.HEAD: Consultant Says Humor Can Help Sales
DOC.TEXT: If laughter can fend off disease, it should be able to help revive an ailing business. That's the premise pushed by Malcolm Kushner, an author and self-styled ``humor consultant.'' He claims people who elicit laughs at work get more done and go further than their sourpuss colleagues. ``I teach people to communicate the fact that they have a sense of humor,'' said Kushner, 37, whose ``The Light Touch: How to Use Humor for Business Success'' (Simon and Shuster, $18.95) recently hit book stores. He can't teach the delivery of Jay Leno or the lightning-quick wit of Robin Williams. But Kushner tries to point out where humor fits in the workplace, as well as what's appropriate and what's not. Racial and sexual slurs are always inappropriate, but Kushner says a competitor can be used effectively as the butt of a joke. His example: ``How can you tell when a (competitor's) executive has been using a word processor?'' Answer: ``There's white-out on the screen.'' Humor acts as a magnet that draws people in, and it can help make a point, Kushner asserts. It also softens stress, motivates people, helps resolve conflicts and shields hostile remarks, he says. ``Managing, selling, negotiating, planning, decision making _ all the fundamental tasks associated with business life become a little bit simpler when people are prejudiced in your favor,'' he writes in his book. Lee Iacocca, Ronald Reagan and Mario Cuomo have shown that successful people don't have to be afraid to joke around, Kushner says. Indeed, having fun at your own expense can be a powerful tool, he says. ``For eight years, Ronald Reagan poked fun at how old he was ... and we loved it,'' Kushner said in a recent interview. ``When the Iran Contra (scandal) hit, everyone wanted to give the guy the benefit of the doubt. Imagine the same scandal hitting Nixon or Carter. We would have said, `Nail the guy.' The first day.'' Kushner quit his job as a lawyer with a San Francisco firm eight years ago and took up humor consulting. He's had some tough clients, including the Internal Revenue Service and the San Francisco Sheriff's Department. He's also worked with many Fortune 500 companies, focusing on the Silicon Valley, which is close to his Santa Cruz home. Bob Brownson, a senior marketing executive for Digital Equipment Corp. in Maynard, Mass, said he has hired Kushner twice, at a rate of about $1,500 for a one-day seminar and $3,000 for a dinner presentation. ``He did an excellent job of improving the quality of our meetings so that we could get on with the more important business. He got us to lighten up and look at ourselves in a little more realistic way,'' he said. ``You work so hard in our business, you begin to believe that selling a computer is the most important thing in the world. And it's not.'' Kushner cites a 1983 Stanford University study that found laughter can have the same health-improving effects as regular exercise. Although he has no statistics to prove it, Kushner says the same medicine might improve the financial health of a company. His book outlines dozens of techniques for introducing humor into conversation and presentations. Humorous personal anecdotes are great icebreakers, and old jokes are useful as analogies, he says. Self-effacing humor can make a person more likeable, he says. His book cites Fred Hoar, an executive with Miller Communications in Mountain View, Calif., as an example in a chapter called ``Building Yourself Up by Putting Yourself Down.'' ``A veteran Silicon Valley advertising and public relations executive, Hoar knows that his name has an unfortunate connotation, particularly when linked with his profession,'' Kushner writes. The executive starts his presentations by saying, ``My name is Fred Hoar.'' ``That's F-R-E-D.''

DOC.HEAD: 24 Donor Nations Widen Aid to Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thoughout with agreement, comments.
DOC.TEXT: Two dozen rich nations Wednesday extended their aid program for Poland and Hungary to four other East European nations that have shed their communist ways for free-market economies. The countries remained divided on the question of extending aid to the Soviet Union, however. West Germany wants quick action on such aid while the United States and Japan want to wait for further reforms there. The agreement to grant financial aid to Bulgaria, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and East Germany came at a meeting of foreign ministers of the Oranization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group of industrial democracies. The ministers excluded Romania from the aid package because of doubts about its commitment to democratic reforms. Wednesday's meeting did not fix specific aid figures. These will emerge in the months ahead as each donor makes its own pledges in food, money, credits, loan guarantees and other assistance. ``It was a conference designed to take stock, see whether we should and could decided to add countries'' to the aid package, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd told reporters. Aid to the new East European beneficiaries is bound to run into billions of dollars in the long term. Already the 24 donor nations have pledged more than $12.4 billion in food, economic and environmental aid to Poland and Hungary since they began coordinating their aid program last summer. The aid effort is coordinated by the European Community Commission, the executive body for the group of 12 West European countries. In a communique, the ministers said the four additional beneficiaries of aid merited help in view of the reforms they have begun ``based on the rule of law, the respect of human rights, the introduction of multi-party systems, the holding of free and fair elections and the establishment of market economies.'' Of Romania, where newly elected officials relied on miners last month to suppress anti-government protests, they said: ``Recent events in Romania have not created the conditions in which the implementation of coordinated assistance should be extended to that country under present circumstances.'' Aid to the Soviet Union will be discussed at next week's summit of the leaders of the world's seven most industrialized nations in Houston, Texas. The issue also is under review within the EC. ``We cannot expect the Soviet Union to resolve problems regarding the transition to a market economy on their own,'' West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told reporters. ``They urgently need help, not only financial but in the form of advice. It is in the common Western interest to give this support to the Soviet Union because a deterioration of the situation will put (Soviet President Mikhail S.) Gorbachev off course and in danger.'' But U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said he wants to see more reforms in the Soviet Union. ``We take note of the fact that the Soviet Union is spending somewhere between 18 and 25 percent of its gross domestic product on military expenditures,'' he told reporters. ``And ... we have problems with the expenditure of somewhere between nine and $15 billion a year to support regimes around the world that in the past at least have been hostile to the views and interests and principles of the United States.'' The Soviet Union, unlike the four countries that were added to the western aid program Wednesday, has not asked for western aid. But the issue of Western aid has become linked to efforts to win Soviet backing for immediate and full membership of a united Germany in the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Wednesday's meeting was attended by officials from Poland, Hungary and the four new beneficiary countries. Bulgarian Foreign Minister Boiko Dimitrov said of country's economic reforms, ``The stupendous task that we are facing is insurmountable without substantive international support.'' Witold Trzeciakowski, who led the Polish delegation, said ``only a continuing support of the developed countries will allow the Polish people to persevere in this difficult and dangerous transition process.'' East Germany was accepted as a new aid recipient although it has merged its economy with West Germany's. The OECD's member nations are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Pickens Plans to Increase Shares in Koito
DOC.TEXT: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman rebuffed in his attempts to get a seat on the board of Koito Manufacturing Co., plans to turn up the pressure by boosting his stake in the Japanese auto parts supplier. Pickens said he will move quickly to raise his stake in Koito to 33 percent from 26 percent, despite having his request for four board seats soundly rejected at Koito's annual stockholders meeting last week. ``We'll probably start this week,'' Pickens said Wednesday. ``We'd like to move up to one-third ownership if we can.'' Pickens has spent $1 billion on his stake so far. He said it would cost about $200 million more to buy the 10 million shares that would bring him to 33 percent. With such a stake, Pickens said Japanese law would allow him to take part in some decisions made by Koito management. ``The reason is that it gives us additional power as a stockholder,'' Pickens said. ``That threshold is important in corporate Japan.'' Pickens and Koito have been battling for the past 16 months. Pickens, the company's largest shareholder, has demanded seats on Koito's board. Koito has said Pickens is interested only in ``greenmail'' and points to his reputation as a corporate raider. Greenmail is a practice of buying up large amounts of a company's stock to force the company to buy it back at a premium to maintain control. Pickens and a delegation of about 50 Americans stormed out of Koito's annual meeting last week after a stormy session that pitted his delegation against the company's Japanese shareholders. He said he had a tape recording of insults that Japanese shareholders yelled to the American delegation during the meeting. He said the Japanese called the Americans dumb and repeatedly told them to go home. ``The translator was telling us some of them but I wasn't aware that this was going on'' at the time, Pickens said, addingg that he received a translation of the tape this week. Pickens has long contended that Koito management is biased against foreigners and participates in Japan's keiretsu system, which links companies and their suppliers. Pickens believes that Toyota Motor Co., Koito's second-largest stockholder and the biggest buyer of its parts, has played a major role behind the scenes to keep him and his representatives off the company's board. He has contended that Toyota uses its muscle to win lower prices from Koito and thereby gain profits at the expense of Koito shareholders. Pickens plans to take his complaints to the International Economic Summit in Houston next week. ``I will certainly talk to anybody that will listen about the unfairness that I see in corporate Japan,'' he said. ``We are fools to open our markets to the Japanese when they don't allow us to participate in theirs.''

DOC.HEAD: Saatchi Agrees to Sell U.S. Consulting Group
DOC.TEXT: Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC, the London-based advertising conglomerate, said it agreed to sell the U.S. consultancy Gartner Group Inc. for $70 million. Information Partners L.P., a Boston-based investment group, will pay cash and a promissory note or shares for Gartner. The sale of Gartner, a Connecticut market information and product data supplier, is part of Saatchi's plan to sell off its consulting businesses to reduce debt and concentrate on communications operations, the company said Wednesday. Information Partners, which specializes in communications concerns, has proposed paying $55 million in cash and $15 million in either a subordinated promissory note or exchangeable preferred stock, the company said. Saatchi said it is paying an estimated $4 million for an accurate evaluation of Gartner's net asset value. The sale is expected to go through within the next six weeks, the company said. Saatchi paid $86 million for Gartner in June 1988. In the six months to March 31, Gartner had a pretax loss of $1.8 million following a $1.8 million profit in the year to Sept. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Advertising Was in the Can
DOC.TEXT: Advertisements touting General Motors Corp.'s Buick Division as the most trouble-free U.S.-made car were already being made by the time a survey showing that ranking was released. GM learned last month that for the second year in a row, Buick would rank in the top 10 in the J.D. Power and Associates Initial Quality survey. Advertising departments worked overtime to cash in on the ranking, Buick advertising director Jay Qualman said Tuesday. Tuesday, the day after the survey was released, a dozen television commercials were poised for broadcast nationally to brag about the Power survey's ranking. ``We've been working around the clock to get it ready to run,'' Qualman said. Carmakers use the Power survey much as they do car- or truck-of-the-year awards given out by automotive magazines: If a company's vehicle ranks high, they brag about it. If not, they ignore it. ``We do look at those (awards) very hard,'' Qualman said. Consumers should expect to see ads from automakers whose vehicles ranked high on the survey. Quality is increasingly important to buyers, and the industry acts accordingly. GM is in the midst of a program called ``Putting Quality on the Road,'' in which every GM employee is acting as a surrogate salesperson urging friends and acquaintances to consider buying GM products. Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca in May wound up a six-city tour praising his company's cars as having quality as good as any others. For years, Ford Motor Co. has hung on to the advertising line: ``Quality is Job One.'' Although domestic automakers have been harping on quality in their advertising, overseas companies consistently rank higher than their U.S. cousins in Power surveys. In the latest survey detailed in The Power Report, a monthly publication by the Agoura Hills, Calif.-based marketing company, Toyota Motor Corp.'s Lexus Division got the best scores among car brand names. It was followed by Mercedes-Benz, Toyota and Nissan Motor Corp.'s Infiniti Division. Buick was fifth. Within a day of the survey's official release, Toyota and Mazda issued news releases crowing about their cars' and trucks' showings in the survey. In a list of specific models, the Toyota Cressida was ranked the most trouble-free car sold in the nation, followed by the Mercedes E-Series, Toyota Camry, Lexus LS400 and Mercedes S-Class. The highest ranking U.S.-made car was the Buick LeSabre in sixth place. On the truck side, Mazda ranked highest with its pickup rated the most trouble-free model. The highest-ranking U.S. truck brand was Ford at No. 4. Among specific models, Ford also had the highest ranking among U.S. makers, with its Bronco II holding down the No. 5 spot among all trucks. The Power Initial Quality survey compiled responses from about 26,000 buyers of 1990 model cars and about 6,500 answers from among 19,000 truck buyers. Each was asked about problems encountered during the first three months of ownership in a dozen broad areas including squeaks and rattles, paint and water leaks. Automakers and their specific vehicles were ranked on a basis of number of problems reported per 100 vehicles sold. The top-ranked Lexus division, for instance, had 82 problems reported per 100 vehicles while the Lexus LS400 car had 74 problems per 100. The results are spelled out in a 200-plus page report with attached charts and graphs that is supplied to Power's carmaker clients, who pay tens of thousands of dollars for the information.

DOC.HEAD: Flag Sales Flying High
LaserPhoto
Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of American flags are enjoying new glory this year in a sales boost that flag companies attribute to increased patriotism and the bitter debate about burning Old Glory. ``It's been a banner year, and that's not just a flag company joke,'' said Steve Sevits, vice president of sales for the Uneeda Flag company located near Albany. By Independence Day, the flag season is in full swing. But it's not just the traditionally patriotic holidays _ Memorial Day, Flag Day, Presidents Day and the Fourth of July _ that accelerate sales. Flag companies say the Supreme Court's June ruling against state laws that ban burning of the American flag also has boosted sales. ``The flag-burning issue got the patriotic movement going again,'' said David Liberman, president of the Valley Forge Flag Co. in Great Neck, N.Y. ``People became more conscious of it and went out and bought a flag. Retail stores even increased their stock.'' Sevits claimed his company's sales were up 17 percent this year. ``People are seeing more flags around so they want one,'' he said. Sales of fire-retardant flags also are up. Sevits said he sells truckloads of flags made from Koralex, a polyester fiber that resists burning. ``Not only are they fire retardant, but they also float in the breeze instead of snap. Snapping wears out a flag more quickly,'' he said. Sevits estimated that a flag displayed outdoors typically will last from 10 to 15 years, depending on weather conditions. Flag industry sales figures are hard to come by, because most companies are privately owned and manufacturers and dealers are reluctant to disclose figures. But flag dealers and others in the industry generally say sales have been rising for more than a decade. ``I've been selling flags for 13 years and I've seen sales go up each year,'' said David Jolly, owner of D&M Merchandisers Inc. in Cohoes, N.Y. ``I think patriotism is the reason for the increase.'' Business began booming for many flag companies in the mid 1970s as the nation prepared to celebrate the 1976 bicentennial, Liberman said. ``It was the biggest flag-selling period in history,'' he said. Sales escalated in 1979 with the taking of American hostages in Iran. The 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, the 1984 and 1988 presidential elections and the flag-burning issue have continued boosting sales, Liberman said. He said flag sales reflect the political state of affairs more than than economics. ``Patriotism is cool now, so sales are good,'' Liberman said. Valley Forge sells millions of flags of various types each year at prices ranging from $1 to $2,000, said Liberman, who has worked for 20 years at the company his grandfather started after World War I. The company sells American flags, state flags, flags of other nations and custom flags and banners. Seventy percent of its business is in sales of Old Glory, Liberman said. He said 10 percent to 15 percent of all U.S. households own American flags. Sevits declined to release sales figures for his company. He said Uneeda Flag sells thousands of flags to customers in New York, New England and Hawaii and has provided flags for exhibits in Alaska and Europe. The 3-by-5 foot American flag models, the biggest sellers, cost $25 to $30. Sevits said many customers spend another $300 for a 20-foot flagpole. He said his most expensive flag, which measures 30-by-60 feet, sells for $2,000. But there isn't great demand for it. ``I guess you'd use one of those on an aircraft carrier if you're heading into Beirut,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Struggling Carrier Uses Reality Ads, But They Get Mixed Review
DOC.BYLINE: Also in Wednesday AMs report. ^By DAN SEWELL
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines confronts its problems with an ambitious campaign that combines personality advertising with grainy realism about a company in crisis, but publicity experts question whether the plan will work. The ``100 Days'' commercials, starring court-appointed trustee Martin Shugrue, are running prime-time and during newscasts in 33 markets. The company won't say how much it's spending in the campaign, in which Shugrue admits Eastern must climb out of a ``large, deep hole.'' ``Eastern's been a troubled carrier for a long time, and there's been a build-up of negatives,'' said Michael Henderson, senior vice president for advertising. The appointment of Shugrue on April 12 by a federal bankruptcy court gave Eastern's marketers a chance to present a new image. ``He represents the most dynamic portrayal of a new beginning. He's new, he's fresh and he doesn't carry any baggage with him,'' Henderson said. The 100 Days campaign shows Shugrue fielding questions from Eastern employees at a hangar and talking with passengers. There are references to Eastern's bad labor relations history and crippling Machinists strike, which began March 4, 1989, and led to a filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five days later. One passenger mentions ``maintenance,'' not an issue that airline advertising usually addresses. But Shugrue emphasizes change, pledging that Eastern will be better each of the 100 days. ``Starting today when you fly Eastern, you won't see many signs of the months behind us,'' he says. He tells employees: ``...the human equation will be paramount at Eastern. If that thinking is a change from what you've experienced before, so be it.'' Those commercials have angered Eastern's unions, who say Shugrue can't claim improved labor relations when he's made little progress in union negotiations. Eastern's commercials intentionally look unprofessional, with microphones squealing and plane engines roaring. ``It looks like it was filmed by some guy across the aisle with his home videocam,'' said David Williams, of New England Consultants. ``It's unrehearsed and realistic. That's where a lot of sincerity comes from.'' Williams is among many advertising specialists impressed with the campaign. But some are skeptical about whether it will help turn Eastern around. ``When you've got a bad name, no amount of well-executed advertising can change it,'' said Al Ries, a Connecticut-based consultant. ``If you really want to communicate the fact that Eastern has changed, you should change the name.'' Ries said besides Eastern's troubled history, the name Eastern makes it sound like a regional carrier irrelevant to people elsewhere. Allegheny Airlines changed its fortunes after becoming USAir, he said. He recalled Eastern used personality advertising before, when Frank Borman, a nationally known hero as an Apollo astronaut, was chief executive. If Borman couldn't change Eastern's image, Ries said, it's doubtful Shugrue can. But Henderson said Shugrue, a veteran airline executive, is well-known in the travel industry. The campaign is targeted mainly at luring business travelers and lessening reliance on unprofitable cut-rate fares. The 100 days campaign comes while Shugrue is enjoying a honeymoon with Eastern's creditors. He was appointed trustee after the creditors lost patience with the management led by Chairman Frank Lorenzo, whose parent company Texas Air Corp. has since changed its name to Continental Airline Holdings. The creditors have said they are willing to give Shugrue time to save Eastern. They've dropped, for now, proposing liquidation of the airline, which is still in the reorganization phase of federal bankruptcy protection laws. But Shugrue's honeymoon with Eastern's unions seems to be over. The Machinists say he has done little to settle their strike, and Eastern pilots, who ended their sympathy strike last November, are unhappy that few pilots have been given their jobs back. Riled by the 100 Days commercials, 600 union members demonstrated June 30 at Miami International Airport, urging the public to boycott Eastern. ``He's trying to be Lee Iacocca, and he's no Lee Iacocca,'' said Frank Ortis, president of Machinists Local 702. The Chrysler Corp. commercials featuring Iacocca are generally considered the most successful use of a corporate chief in personality advertising. ``If Shugrue really wants to make Eastern better, he would get the dedicated professionals who built this airline back to work,'' Ortis said. ``That's the only way Eastern is going to survive.''
