DOC.HEAD: US, Western Allies Asked to Send Economic Aid to Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The United States and other Western countries are being urged to rush to the rescue of the faltering Soviet economy with an emergency aid package of up to $20 billion. Without such assistance, supporters of the plan say, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could be toppled from power at a time when the West is tantalizingly close to signing agreements with the Soviets on arms control and other important issues _ on close to its own terms. But opponents say the assistance could end up as a massive waste of money that would simply allow Gorbachev to delay measures needed to institute a market-oriented economy. President Bush will be lobbied extensively by both camps in coming days, first by other Western leaders at the NATO summit in London on Thursday and Friday and then at the annual economic summit which begins in Houston on Monday. The Houston meeting, bringing together the leaders of the world's seven richest economies, will be the first such meeting in the United States since 1983. Bush and his counterparts from Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada will be grappling with a contentious trade fight over agricultural subsidies as well as considering proposals to protect the global environment and relieve the crushing debt burden on Third World countries. But the Soviet aid question is likely to dominate the discussions. Both French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl are pushing to give Gorbachev the $15 billion to $20 billion in Western assistance he is seeking in outright grants and loans. Just a few months ago, the Bush administration curtly dismissed the idea of Western aid to the Soviets when it was proposed by House Democratic Leader Richard Gephardt. But since that time the administration has come under pressure to reverse its opposition, especially from Kohl, who wants Soviet acquiescence in a speedy unification of East and West Germany. Conservatives contend such aid would amount to paying ransom money at a time when the Soviet government is still spending heavily on its own military and supporting client states in Cuba, Angola and Afghanistan. Asked about Soviet aid on Tuesday, Bush repeated his assertion that ``economic reform is essential'' before aid is extended. He said billions of dollars had been wasted in the early 1970s in Western loans to Poland before that country was ready to make needed reforms. ``I have explained to our economic summit partners and to the Soviets and to others that we have specific problems with ... giving money to the Soviet Union at this point,'' Bush told reporters in Kennebunkport, Maine. But Gorbachev stressed in an interview Monday that the Soviet Union needs Western assistance now, not after further economic reforms are taken. ``I should say at this point we need more cooperation, while the government is working out measures for the transition to a market economy, to make this process less painful, to make it easier,'' Gorbachev said in an interview with CBS News after the opening of the Communist Party Congress. Behind the scenes, the administration appears to be trying to work out a compromise on the aid question. What may emerge at the Houston summit is a two-track approach in which Western nations willing to provide direct assistance would be allowed to do so while the United States and other countries such as Britain, Japan and Canada would limit their help to technical assistance. Among areas being explored by the administration are providing experts in such fields as housing, banking, accounting and management training to give advice to the Soviets on ways to set up a free-market system. Bush signaled his tolerance for a dual approach last week when he said that he didn't want to get into a position of telling Kohl ``what his lending policy or his finance policy should be.'' The Houston summit could end up with a vague statement of support for Gorbachev that would give individual countries room to pursue their own policies. On trade, Bush has proclaimed that his No. 1 priority in Houston is breaking a deadlock on global free trade talks. The United States is demanding a phase-out of all trade-distorting farm subsidies within 10 years, but Europeans are fighting the effort, which they say could cost 2 million to 3 million European jobs. The dispute is threatening to scuttle an ambitious four-year effort to liberalize the world trading system under the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The administration believes that overhauling the GATT rules offers the best hope of expanding export opportunities for American farmers and businesses and thus lowering the country's huge trade deficit. The farm subsidies cost consumers and taxpayers worldwide $245 billion last year. Without progress in attacking the subsidies, the United States believes many Third World countries will balk at supporting efforts to expand GATT rules to cover trade in services, such as banking and insurance, and beef up protection against copyright piracy, which cost American companies $60 billion annually in lost sales. The perennial issue of how to ease the $1.3 trillion Third World debt burden will also be addressed in Houston. Last week, Bush proposed to forgive part of the $12 billion in debt owed by Latin American countries to the U.S. government. In discussing the plan, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady conceded that it could set a precedent for offering similar relief to debt-strapped Eastern European governments such as Poland. At last year's economic summit in Paris, one-third of the final communique was devoted to the issue of protecting the global environment. Issues such as global warming and deforestation are expected to be addressed in Houston as well.

DOC.HEAD: Union: Checchi Wants To Explore Eastern Acquisition
DOC.TEXT: An Eastern Airlines union official thinks it would be ``a great marriage'' if Northwest Airlines bought the troubled carrier, but others say Eastern's pension liabilities and labor troubles would make a deal difficult. ``It's a fairy tale,'' said Rich Siakel, a spokesman for Northwest's pilot's union in Bloomington. ``There are pieces that make sense, but not the whole thing.'' Some said Northwest may be primarily interested in Eastern's Atlanta and Miami hubs or its East Coast routes. The prospect of an acquisition was raised Tuesday by a union spokesman who said Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi wants to meet with the Machinists union to discuss the possibility of Northwest buying Eastern. ``Everything is just exploratory at this point,'' said Jim Conley, a spokesman for the International Association of Machinists in Washington. Conley said Machinists officials met Monday in Washington to discuss the problems integrating Eastern employees into Northwest's operation. He said the meeting was a prelude to one with Checchi, but said he does not know when that meeting will take place. Robin Matell, spokesman for Miami-based Eastern, said a June memo to employees said Pan Am and Northwest had shown interest in buying Eastern, but meetings and discussions were not an indication of an imminent takeover. ``Eastern's desire is to create a successful, independent airline, but it's impossible to rule out a merger or buyout,'' the memo said. Officials at Eagan, Minn.-based Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest carrier, would not comment on whether Eastern is a possible takeover target. But Checchi repeatedly has made public his intention to expand Northwest, possibly by buying an entire airline or parts of one. Eastern, the nation's ninth-largest airline, has been reorganizing under bankruptcy court protection from creditors since March 1989, when Machinists walked off the job. Pilots and flight attendants called off sympathy strikes last November. Since April, Eastern has been run by court-appointed trustee Martin Shugrue, who was an adviser to a group of investors led by Checchi in a $3.65 billion buyout of Northwest last year. The leader of the machinists' union at Eastern, Frank Ortis, said a Northwest-Eastern merger ``would be a great marriage.'' ``It's speculation, but in our opinion, it would be a great merger and a great buy,'' he said. ``Northwest is a great airline. Mr. Checchi appears to be very good with public relations and labor relations.'' The Machinists form the largest union at Northwest and Eastern, representing nearly 24,000 workers at Northwest and 8,500 at Eastern. Siakel, of Northwest's pilots union, said an Eastern acquisition would invite the kinds of service problems Northwest encountered with its 1986 takeover of Republic Airlines. When Northwest and former Republic employees were working side by side and earning vastly different wages, a deterioration of morale and service gave rise to the nickname ``Northworst.'' William Genoese, head of the airline division for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said Checchi's primary interest in Eastern is acquiring its Atlanta and Miami hubs. Northwest's only existing southern hub, in Memphis, ``is not producing the way they thought it would. It doesn't have the traffic,'' Genoese said. But Shugrue is only interested in selling Eastern if someone buys all of it, Genoese said. ``I don't see anything really developing,'' said Genoese, whose union represents flight attendants at Northwest. Northwest also would benefit from Eastern's routes on the East Coast, where Northwest is ``relatively weak,'' said Morton Beyer, president of Avmark, an aviation consulting firm in Arlington, Va. Beyer said deterrents to a merger would be consolidating the two work forces and the huge unfunded pension liability Northwest would inherit. Eastern calculates its unfunded pension liability at $390 million, but a spokeswoman for the federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. said the liability is about $800 million. ``Yes it is a deterrent,'' Beyer said of the pension issue, ``but how big a deterrent is actually debatable.'' He said a $390 million cost item would not automatically kill a deal potentially worth more than $3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Plans to Buy Western Union Telex and Other Services
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has agreed to buy selected parts of Western Union Corp.'s Business Services unit for $180 million. Western Union, of Upper Saddle River, has been having financial troubles for the past few years and is in the midst of a restructuring. Under the agreement announced Tuesday, AT&T would buy the assets used to provide Western Union's EasyLink electronic mail service and its Telex and packet-switched services. AT&T would take on Western Union's 1,160 Business Services employees and the unit's customer base, said John Smart, president of Business Communications Services, in a news release from AT&T's Basking Ridge offices. The agreement does not include Western Union Priority Services, which provides Mailgram, Priority Letter and Custom Letter services. It leaves the company with approximately 2,500 employees, said Western Union spokesman Warren Bechtel. The transaction completes the transformation of Western Union from a telecommunications company to a financial services and paper-based messaging business, said Robert J. Amman, president and chief executive officer of Western Union. The deal would also help the company pay a major portion of its new first priority notes issued to bondholders as part of the company's restructuring, said Amman. On June 14, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved Western Union's plan to swap $530 million in debt for new notes and stock. Western Union wrote off $603 million in special charges in the first quarter of 1988, in connection with the planned sale of the company's microwave voice-switching facilities. In 1988, the company reported $32 million in losses. Faced with making a $51 million biannual interest payment by June 15, the company told regulators in March that it would have to seek bankruptcy court protection if it couldn't meet its debt interest payments. AT&T spokeswoman Lynn Newman said the Western Union unit earned more than $629 million last year and AT&T is looking forward to its continued profitability. ``It wasn't a huge amount of money for a buy, but we're getting a good match with our existing electronic messaging system ... and we've got the added customer base,'' said Newman. The sale needs regulatory approval and is conditioned on completion of a Western Union debt restructuring plan. The companies said the deal should be completed by September.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Study: Slower Growth Especially In Soviet Bloc And Developing Nations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The world economy is slowing down and growth has virtually halted in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union as some governments undertake drastic market-oriented reform, a U.N. study says. The 1990 World Economic Survey, released Tuesday, says world economic output increased by 3.1 percent in 1989, compared with 4.4 percent in 1988. Industrialized market economies continued to expand, growing by 3.5 percent, and although the figure was lower than the 4.3 percent of 1988 it was stronger than had been expected, the report says. Economic growth in the developing world as a whole slowed from 4.5 percent in 1988 to 3.4 percent in 1989. Economic performance varied greatly by region. The report agreed in general with the findings of the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which said last week that the economies of the industrialized world remain on a steady course. Like the OECD report, it warned against inflation, especially in East European countries that are changing from state-controlled to market economies. ``Economic growth in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union came to a virtual halt in 1989,'' the report says, adding that output increased by just 1.2 percent. U.N. economists said they do not expect a bright picture for the immediate future in countries restructuring their economies, although the long-term prospects could improve with painful reform. ``The danger of rapid inflation in the reforming socialist countries is a major concern,'' says the report, ``requiring prudent monetary and fiscal policies during the transition to more market-oriented economies.'' In several Latin American countries hyperinflation is a serious problem, it says, and stabilization policies are likely to prove costly in the short term. Long-term prospects are uncertain. The survey, compiled by the U.N. Department of International Economic and Social Affairs, says the economies of South and East Asia grew by 6.2 percent last yeasr, compared with 8.2 percent in 1988, the survey said. China's growth rate delined sharply, from 11.4 percent in 1988 to 3.9 percent in 1989. Latin America and the Caribbean saw just a 0.7 percent increase and per capita output fell for the second consecutive year. Inflation was unprecedented in the region. In Africa, economies expanded by 2.8 percent in 1989, below the rate of population growth, and per capita output fell as a result. In West Asia, economic recovery continued with a 2.5 percent growth rate. Economic stabilization measures stalled growth in Mediterranean countries. The survey proposed establishment of a Central European Payments Union, similar to the European Payments Union established after World War II, as a temporary measure to assist reforming Eastern European countries in their transition to market-oriented economies with convertible currencies.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major foreign currencies today in thin, early European trading. Gold prices were mixed. Traders said the dollar was suffering from the market's interest in the German mark following German monetary union on Sunday. ``The market is liking what it's hearing about monetary union,'' said a Frankfurt trader. ``It's very pro-mark right now and the dollar is falling a little into the background because of it.'' Ian Francis, assistant foreign exchange director at Morgan Grenfell and Co. in London, said the dollar could fall further if Friday's U.S. employment data indicates that U.S. economic growth is slow. Some dealers said the U.S. currency could turn up sharply if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev fails to get the support he needs for his economic reforms from the Soviet Communist Party Congress meeting in Moscow. ``The dollar could turn with a vengeance,'' said Carlo Galazzi, senior dealer at Nikko Bank (U.K) Ltd. in London. Dealers said trading was quiet because of the U.S. Independence Day holiday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.38 yen to a closing 150.30 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 149.77 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6458 West German marks, down from 1.6509 _1.3900 Swiss francs, down from 1.3930 _5.5235 French francs, down from 5.5400 _1.8543 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8578 _1,207.30 Italian lire, down from 1,210.50 _1.1612 Canadian, down from 1.1622 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7885, compared with $1.7800 late Tuesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $361.25 a troy ounce this morning, down from $361.75 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $361.40, up from $361.00 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $3.92 to close at a bid $362.46. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.93 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $4.96.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Plunges, Stocks Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar plunged against the yen and other major currencies in Tokyo today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index inched up and Japanese bonds rallied strongly. The dollar closed at 150.30 yen, down 1.38 yen from Tuesday's 151.68-yen finish. It opened at 150.25 yen and ranged between 149.90 yen and 150.65 yen. The U.S. currency had edged up 0.28 yen on Tuesday, but its fall since last Thursday now totals 4.12 yen. Dealers said the dollar's low opening in Tokyo Wednesday followed its decline in overseas markets. ``In addition to the yen, the dollar was lower against almost all the other major currencies,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. There was no specific economic factor behind the selling, she added. ``Today's dollar-selling was technical adjustments, trying to push it below the 150-yen level,'' she said. Other dealers said expectations of lower U.S. interest rates caused the dollar's weakness. Lower interest rates tend to make a country's currency less attractive to overseas investors. About $16.06 billion changed hands in spot trading. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 31.32 points, or 0.10 percent, closing at 32,445.92. The index rose 254.37 points on Tuesday. The Nikkei was up 100.66 points at the end of the morning session but gradually fell in the afternoon, when market players sold high-tech issues due to the yen's appreciation, traders said. Construction, real estate and steel issues did well, but trading was inactive because institutional investors remained on the sidelines, said Masashi Yamane, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co. Estimated first section volume was 550 million shares, down from Tuesday's 450 million. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 87.11 points from 86.64 on Tuesday, pushing the yield down to 7.165 percent from 7.265 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Australia Worried About Possible Cash Crisis in Savings Banks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Figures are in U.S. dollars. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A run on deposits has forced a state government to close a group of lending institutions to prevent a chain reaction like the one that hit their American equivalent, the savings-and-loan industry. Victoria state also pledged Tuesday that all of the small uninsured depositors at the failed Farrow Corp., the southeastern state's largest such institution, would get all their money back. Some 220,000 Australians had faced the loss of their life savings in the failure of Farrow. The corporation is comprised of three so-called building societies, which like American S&Ls were primarily established to make home-mortgage loans. The decision to refund the depositors could cost the financially troubled state up to $800 million, though the final toll will be determined after the assets of Farrow Corp. are sold off. Banks that loaned the company money will get first shot at those funds. Analysts say Farrow's risky loans caused the firm to go under _ a practice also blamed for the failure of S&Ls in the United States that is projected to cost American taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars. Some critics have called for Victoria Premier John Cain to resign over the financial crisis, which conceivably could lead to the fall of the state government. Victoria, Australia's second most populous state with 4.1 million people, includes the coastal city of Melbourne. There also could be repercussions on the federal level, where the Labor government of Prime Minister Bob Hawke scored a narrow victory earlier this year following the loss of nine Parliament seats in Victoria. Government-appointed administrator Ken Russell announced Sunday night that Farrow would not be allowed to reopen. The action followed a run on deposits that dropped Farrow's liquidity from about $316 million in February to about $47 million last week. Russell initially warned that some depositors could lose some of their money. Depositors then pressured Victoria and threatened to file suit, pointing out that then-state Treasurer Rob Jolly had assured them in February that their funds were secure. In response, Cain said Tuesday the government would ensure that all small depositors would be repaid in full over an unspecified time and would get 20 percent to 25 percent as soon as possible. To offset a possible crisis in confidence in other building societies and avoid a domino effect of runs on deposits, Cain said Monday they would be brought into the banking sector gradually. Major banks will support them in the meantime through a line of credit guaranteed by the state government. Legislators representing the city of Geelong had said that without state help, the 150,000 residents would be hit hard. Geelong was home to one of the failed building societies, Pyramid, and half its depositors live there. ``Businesses using the group for banking can't get running funds; employees aren't getting paid,'' said David Henshaw, a member of the Victorian Parliament. Russell said the closure resulted from his failure to find a buyer for Farrow. The societies' assets now will be sold, with those proceeds first going to banks that had lent to Farrow. Analysts say the failure was due to a high-risk loan strategy that fell apart as the commercial property market collapsed. Analysts say the strategy began after the son of Farrow's founder, Bill Farrow, and David Clarke took over the 50-year-old group in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Oil Companies Boosting Foreign Operations
DOC.TEXT: Oil companies operating in the United States relied more on foreign production than domestic and spent more money overseas to look for new oil for the first time last year, according to an industry survey. The shift reflects the steady decline in domestic oil production in recent years, in part a consequence of relatively weak world oil prices, and increased concerns about the environmental impact of oil exploration and production in the United States, the survey released Tuesday by Arthur Andersen & Co. said. ``The broad conclusion we can draw from this year's study is that the world oil industry is entering a new era, and U.S. exploration and production companies are successfully adapting to the changing environment,'' said Victor A. Burk, managing director of oil and gas industry services for Arthur Andersen. For the first time last year, the companies surveyed had greater foreign oil reserves than domestic reserves, saw oil production from foreign sources surpass domestic production, and spent more on exploration and production for new oil overseas than in the United States. The 11th annual study is based on data on reserve quantity, value, cost and other details filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by 236 public companies for the five years from 1985 through 1989. Companies in the study included U.S. and Canadian firms and three major foreign companies with significant U.S. operations _ British Petroleum, Royal Dutch@Shell and Broken Hill Proprietary of Australia. In 1989, the companies in the study accounted for more than 60 percent of the total proved oil and gas reserves and production in the United States. The United States has been the most heavily explored country in the world. Burk said companies are shifting their exploration focus abroad because they believe the chances of bigger ``finds'' are better. ``They believe the opportunities right now are greater outside the United States,'' he said. The driving forces behind the changing industry environment include continuing declines in U.S. oil production coupled with an increase in reliance on imports; the dramatic political and economic changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and reduced Soviet oil production; and rapid economic growth and oil demand in east Asian countries, Burk said. In addition, environmental concerns will fundamentally change oil transportation, offshore exploration, refining and utility and industrial fuel choices, he said. ``Major companies are using this period to rationalize their asset portfolios and expand foreign operations,'' he said. ``This in turn creates new opportunities for U.S. independents in acquiring and exploring for reserves, taking advantage of technical innovations, and further improving operating efficiencies.'' Burk also said that in 1989, there was a further reduction in domestic finding costs to an average $7.24, a decline of $1.03, or 12.5 percent, per barrel. Foreign finding costs registered a decline of almost 9 percent to $8.73.
